Quiz Results

Part 75 of 85 (Quiz Attempts 741-750)
← Prev Part 75 of 85 Next →

Quiz Attempt #119696

Total Questions: 50
Question 1
Which of the following is an example of IEEE 802.3?
  • A.LAN
  • B.MAN
  • C.WAN
  • D.PAN
Correct Answer: LAN

IEEE 802.3 is the standard for Ethernet, which is the most common technology used in Local Area Networks (LANs).
It defines how data is transmitted over cables and how devices communicate within a limited area such as an office, school, or building.

Question 2
The following table shows the cumulative percentage of the total number of students appearing in the Hindi and Punjabi examination and the cumulative number of students appearing in the Hindi examination and scoring marks in five different categories, namely, 80 and above; 70 and above; 60 and above; 50 and above; and 40 and above. Based on the data in the table, answer the questions that follow.Marks-wise distribution of studentsMarks (Out of 100)Cumulative percentage of students who appeared in Hindi and PunjabiCumulative number of students who appeared in Hindi80 and above1510870 and above3526460 and above6542450 and above9055440 and above100624Note:(1) Total number of students who attended the exam is 1200.(2) No student failed in the examination.(3) Each student appeared in only one exam, that is, either in Hindi or in Punjabi exam.What is the sum of the number of students who scored 70 or more than 70 but less than 80 marks in Hindi and the number of students who scored 80 or more than 80 marks in Punjabi?
  • A.330
  • B.228
  • C.272
  • D.284
Correct Answer: 228

.

Marks (Out of 100)

Cumulative % appeared in Hindi and Punjabi

Cumulative number appeared in Hindi

Students in Hindi

Cumulative number appeared in Punjabi+Hindi

Students in Punjabi + Hindi

Students in Punjabi

80 and above

15

108

108

15% of 1200 = 180

180

72

70 and above

35

264

156

35% of 1200 = 420

240

84

60 and above

65

424

160

65% of 1200 = 780

360

200

50 and above

90

554

130

90% of 1200 = 1080

300

170

40 and above

100

624

70

100% of 1200 = 1200

120

50

 

Students scoring 70–79 in Hindi = 156

Students scoring 80 & above in Punjabi = 72

Sum = 156 + 72 = 228

Question 3
The following table shows the cumulative percentage of the total number of students appearing in the Hindi and Punjabi examination and the cumulative number of students appearing in the Hindi examination and scoring marks in five different categories, namely, 80 and above; 70 and above; 60 and above; 50 and above; and 40 and above. Based on the data in the table, answer the questions that follow.Marks-wise distribution of studentsMarks (Out of 100)Cumulative percentage of students who appeared in Hindi and PunjabiCumulative number of students who appeared in Hindi80 and above1510870 and above3526460 and above6542450 and above9055440 and above100624Note:(1) Total number of students who attended the exam is 1200.(2) No student failed in the examination.(3) Each student appeared in only one exam, that is, either in Hindi or in Punjabi exam.What is the ratio of the number of students who scored 50 or more than 50 marks but less than 60 marks in Hindi to the number of students who scored 40 or more than 40 marks but less than 50 marks in Punjabi?
  • A.12 :11
  • B.8 :7
  • C.3 :1
  • D.13 :5
Correct Answer: 13 :5

Students in Hindi

Question 4
The following table shows the cumulative percentage of the total number of students appearing in the Hindi and Punjabi examination and the cumulative number of students appearing in the Hindi examination and scoring marks in five different categories, namely, 80 and above; 70 and above; 60 and above; 50 and above; and 40 and above.   • B.54
  • C.44
  • D.52

Question 5
The following table shows the cumulative percentage of the total number of students appearing in the Hindi and Punjabi examination and the cumulative number of students appearing in the Hindi examination and scoring marks in five different categories, namely, 80 and above; 70 and above; 60 and above; 50 and above; and 40 and above. Based on the data in the table, answer the questions that follow.Marks-wise distribution of studentsMarks (Out of 100)Cumulative percentage of students who appeared in Hindi and PunjabiCumulative number of students who appeared in Hindi80 and above1510870 and above3526460 and above6542450 and above9055440 and above100624Note:(1) Total number of students who attended the exam is 1200.(2) No student failed in the examination.(3) Each student appeared in only one exam, that is, either in Hindi or in Punjabi exam.What is the difference between the number of students who scored 70 or more than 70 marks but less than 80 marks in Punjabi and the number of students who scored 40 or more than 40 marks but less than 50 marks in Hindi?
  • A.20
  • B.16
  • C.14
  • D.30

Question 6
The following table shows the cumulative percentage of the total number of students appearing in the Hindi and Punjabi examination and the cumulative number of students appearing in the Hindi examination and scoring marks in five different categories, namely, 80 and above; 70 and above; 60 and above; 50 and above; and 40 and above. Based on the data in the table, answer the questions that follow.Marks-wise distribution of studentsMarks (Out of 100)Cumulative percentage of students who appeared in Hindi and PunjabiCumulative number of students who appeared in Hindi80 and above1510870 and above3526460 and above6542450 and above9055440 and above100624Note:(1) Total number of students who attended the exam is 1200.(2) No student failed in the examination.(3) Each student appeared in only one exam, that is, either in Hindi or in Punjabi exam.What is the average of the number of students who scored 50 or more than 50 marks but less than 60 marks in Punjabi and the number of students who scored 50 or more than 50 marks but less than 60 marks in Hindi?
  • A.180
  • B.150
  • C.200
  • D.140

Question 7
The role of a teacher in the simulation model is that of _______.
  • A.Explaining
  • B.Designing
  • C.Describing
  • D.Choosing activity
Correct Answer: Explaining

In the simulation model, the teacher’s role is mainly to explain the situation, context, and rules of the simulation to students before they participate. The teacher helps learners understand what to do, guides them during the process, and facilitates discussion afterward to draw learning outcomes. Thus, the teacher acts as an explainer and facilitator, not just a designer.

Question 8
The CBCS (Choice Based Credit System) in higher education promotes:
  • A.Rigid curriculum structure
  • B.Flexibility in course selection
  • C.Limited student choices
  • D.Only theoretical learning
Correct Answer: Flexibility in course selection

The Choice Based Credit System (CBCS) allows students to choose courses from a wide range of core, elective, and skill-based subjects. It promotes flexibility and academic freedom, enabling learners to design their own learning path according to their interests and career goals.

Question 9
Arrange the problem-solving strategy.A. Generate many possible solutionsB. Determine how to implement the solution and evaluate the success of the solutionC. Make a decisionD. Evaluate each solutionE. Define the problemChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.B, E, A, D, C
  • B.E, A, D, C, B
  • C.A, B, C, D, E
  • D.C, A, B, E, D
Correct Answer: E, A, D, C, B

E – Define the problem: Clearly understand what the problem is.

A – Generate many possible solutions: Think of all possible ways to solve it.

D – Evaluate each solution: Examine the pros and cons of each option.

C – Make a decision: Choose the best possible solution.

B – Determine how to implement and evaluate success: Apply the solution and check if it works effectively.

Question 10
Learning for all implies:A. Inclusive educationB. Equitable educationC. Inclusive and equitable educationD. Quality educationE. Categorized-based educationChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B and D only
  • B.A and E only
  • C.C only
  • D.D only
Correct Answer: C only

“Learning for all” means that every learner, regardless of background, ability, or social status, should get equal opportunities to learn. This idea combines both inclusiveness (no one is excluded) and equity (everyone gets what they need to succeed).


Hence, it refers to inclusive and equitable education together.

Question 11
Match List–I with List–II.List–I (Learning Style)A. ConvergentB. DivergentC. AssimilationD. AccommodativeList–II (Strengths)I. Creating theoretical modelII. Practical application of ideasIII. Carrying out plans and tasks that involve students in new experiencesIV. Imaginative ability and generation of ideasChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A–I, B–II, C–III, D–IV
  • B.A–II, B–I, C–III, D–IV
  • C.A–II, B–IV, C–I, D–III
  • D.A–IV, B–I, C–III, D–II
Correct Answer: A–II, B–IV, C–I, D–III

According to Kolb’s Learning Style Theory:

Convergent learners (A–II): excel in applying ideas practically to real problems.

Divergent learners (B–IV): are imaginative and generate multiple ideas.

Assimilative learners (C–I): are strong in creating theoretical models and concepts.

Accommodative learners (D–III): learn best through hands-on experience and carrying out tasks.

Question 12
What is Exploratory Research?
  • A.It describes social situations, social events, social systems, social structures etc. The researcher observes/studies and then describes what he finds.
  • B.It studies subjects about which either no information or limited information is available.
  • C.It explains the causes of social phenomena. Describing the magnitude and nature of crimes committed by females in India is one aspect of female crime, but explaining why they commit crime is its explanatory aspect.
  • D.It is based on common-sense knowledge based on the accumulated experiences and beliefs of the people.
Correct Answer: It studies subjects about which either no information or limited information is available.

Exploratory research is used when the topic is new or not well understood. Its main goal is to explore and gain basic insights rather than test hypotheses. It helps researchers identify key issues, variables, and directions for future detailed study.

Question 13
What is Explanatory Research?
  • A.It studies subjects about which either no information or the limited information is available.
  • B.It describes social situations, social events, social systems, social structures etc. The researcher observes/studies and then describes what he finds.
  • C.It explains the causes of social phenomena. Describing the magnitude and nature of crimes committed by females in India is one aspect of female crime, but explaining why they commit crime is its explanatory aspect.
  • D.It is based on common-sense knowledge based on the accumulated experiences and beliefs of the people.
Correct Answer: It explains the causes of social phenomena. Describing the magnitude and nature of crimes committed by females in India is one aspect of female crime, but explaining why they commit crime is its explanatory aspect.

Explanatory research goes beyond describing facts — it tries to find out the reasons or causes behind a phenomenon.
For example, instead of just describing the number of crimes by females, explanatory research seeks to understand why females commit crimes.


Hence, its purpose is to explain cause-and-effect relationships in social or behavioural studies.

Question 14
Standard deviation (S) and coefficient of variation (CV expressed as a percentage) of different datasets are given in A–D below. Compute the mean of each dataset and arrange them in ascending order.A. S = 4, CV = 40/9B. S = 5, CV = 6.25C. S = 14, CV = 70/3D. S = 16, CV = 160/7Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.C, B, D, A
  • B.C, D, B, A
  • C.A, D, B, C
  • D.D, B, C, A
Correct Answer: C, D, B, A

 Mean=S×100CV

 

Now calculate each mean:

A. S=4,  CV=409

Mean=4×10040/9=400×940=90

B. S=5,  CV=6.25

Mean=5×1006.25=5006.25=80

C. S=14,  CV=703

Mean=14×10070/3=1400×370=60

D. S=16,  CV=1607

Mean=16×100160/7=1600×7160=70

Means obtained:

A = 90

B = 80

C = 60

D = 70

Question 15
Which of the following are the risks of plagiarism for the researcher who plagiarises?A. Losing of the inspirationB. Losing of the obtained titlesC. Destruction of obtained solutionsD. Destroying the public imageChoose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.A and C only
  • B.B and C only
  • C.B and D only
  • D.C and D only
Correct Answer: B and D only

If a researcher commits plagiarism, they risk serious consequences such as:

Losing obtained titles or degrees (B): Institutions can revoke academic titles or awards.

 

Destroying public image (D): Their reputation and credibility in the academic community are permanently damaged.
Hence, the main risks are loss of academic recognition and damage to reputation.

Question 16
Match List–I with List–IIList–I[Populationmean(μ)and1N∑xi2]A.μ=9,1N∑xi2=117B.μ=10,1N∑xi2=200C.μ=11,1N∑xi2=202D.μ=12,1N∑xi2=160List–II[Population standard deviation (σ)]I. 10II. 4III. 6IV. 9Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A–III, B–IV, C–I, D–II
  • B.A–II, B–I, C–IV, D–III
  • C.A–III, B–I, C–IV, D–II
  • D.A–I, B–IV, C–II, D–III
Correct Answer: A–III, B–I, C–IV, D–II

Formula for population standard deviation (σ):

σ=1N∑xi2-μ2

A. μ=9,  1N∑xi2=117

σ=117-92=117-81=36=6

⟹ A – III

 

B. μ=10,  1N∑xi2=200

σ=200-102=200-100=100=10

⟹ B – I

 

C. μ=11,  1N∑xi2=202

σ=202-112=202-121=81=9

⟹ C – IV

 

D. μ=12,  1N∑xi2=160

σ=160-122=160-144=16=4

⟹ D – II

Question 17
Who directed the first talkie feature film made in India?
  • A.ArdesharIrani
  • B.Ritwik Ghatak
  • C.Dada Saheb Phalke
  • D.Bimal Roy
Correct Answer: ArdesharIrani

The first Indian talkie (sound) film was “Alam Ara”, released in 1931, directed by Ardeshar Irani.
It marked the beginning of the sound era in Indian cinema, featuring dialogues and songs for the first time.

Question 18
Who directed the first film made in India?
  • A.Satyajit Ray
  • B.Dada Saheb Phalke
  • C.Prithvi Raj Kapoor
  • D.ArdesharIrani
Correct Answer: Dada Saheb Phalke

The first Indian film was Raja Harishchandra (1913), directed and produced by Dada Saheb Phalke.
It was a silent film and marked the beginning of Indian cinema, earning Phalke the title “Father of Indian Cinema.”

Question 19
What is the correct chronological order of the following television programmes released onDoordarshanin India (from earliest to latest)?A.MahabharathaB. ChandrakantaC. Hum LogD. RamayanaE.BuniyadChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B, C, D, E
  • B.C, E, D, A, B
  • C.B, C, A, D, E
  • D.B, A, D, E, C
Correct Answer: C, E, D, A, B

Here’s the chronological order of the famous Doordarshan TV programmes:

Hum Log (C) – 1984 (India’s first television soap opera)

Buniyaad (E) – 1986–87 (based on the Partition of India)

Ramayana (D) – 1987–88 (mythological series by Ramanand Sagar)

Mahabharata (A) – 1988–90 (epic series by B.R. Chopra)

Chandrakanta (B) – 1994 (fantasy serial based on Devaki Nandan Khatri’s novel)

 

Hence, the correct sequence is C, E, D, A, B.

Question 20
What among the following films are directed by Satyajit Ray?A. MadhumatiB.ApurSansarC. SujataD.AparajitoE. Pather PanchaliChoose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.B, D and E only
  • B.A and C only
  • C.A, B, C and D only
  • D.A, B and C only
Correct Answer: B, D and E only

Satyajit Ray, one of India’s greatest filmmakers, directed the famous Apu Trilogy —

Pather Panchali (E) – 1955

Aparajito (D) – 1956

Apur Sansar (B) – 1959

These films depict the life journey of a boy named Apu.
Madhumati (A) was directed by Bimal Roy, and Sujata (C) was also directed by Bimal Roy, not Satyajit Ray.

Question 21
Match List-I with List-IIList-I (Meaning)A. WhoB. Says whatC. In which channelD. To whomList-II (Terms)I. ReceiverII. CommunicatorIII. MessageIV. MediumChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A-III, B-II, C-I, D-IV
  • B.A-I, B-IV, C-III, D-II
  • C.A-II, B-III, C-IV, D-I
  • D.A-IV, B-II, C-I, D-III
Correct Answer: A-II, B-III, C-IV, D-I

This matching is based on Lasswell’s Model of Communication, which explains the process through five elements — Who says what, in which channel, to whom, and with what effect.

A. Who → Communicator (II) – the sender of the message.

B. Says what → Message (III) – the content being communicated.

C. In which channel → Medium (IV) – the means through which the message travels.

D. To whom → Receiver (I) – the person or audience who receives the message.

Question 22
Find the number that can replace the question mark (?) in the series given below:7, 12, 32, 122, ?, 3602, 25202
  • A.602
  • B.610
  • C.702
  • D.622
Correct Answer: 602

7×2−2=12

→ 12×3−4=32

→ 32×4−6=122

→ 122×5−8=602

→ 602×6−10=3602

→ 3602×7−12=25202.

Question 23
In a certain code language:‘NOIDA’ is written as: 1, 4, 9, 15, 14‘INDIA’ is written as: 1, 9, 4, 14, 9How ‘HELLO’ will be written in this language?
  • A.15, 12, 12, 5, 8
  • B.5, 12, 12, 15, 8
  • C.8, 5, 12, 12, 15
  • D.12, 5, 12, 8, 15
Correct Answer: 15, 12, 12, 5, 8

Each position is coded as the alphabetical value of the mirrored letter in the word (i.e., pair 1↔5, 2↔4, 3↔3).

 

For HELLO → mirror is OLLEH → values: O(15), L(12), L(12), E(5), H(8).

Question 24
Which of the following statement(s) is/are wrong?A. A man runs at a speed of 20 km/hr and covers a distance of 400 m. The time taken by the man to cover 400 m is 8 minutes.B. A person covers a certain distance at x km/hr and an equal distance at y km/hr. The average speed during the whole journey is2xyx+ykm/hr.C. A cyclist covers a distance of 750 m in212minutes. The speed of the cyclist is 18 km/hr.D. A speed of x km/hr is equal to5x18m/sec.Choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.AOnly
  • B.A and B Only
  • C.A and C Only
  • D.B, C and D Only
Correct Answer: AOnly

A. Time Taken = 0.420 = 150 hr = 1.2 mins

B. Average speed = 21x+1y = 2xyx+y

C. Speed = 75052 m/min = 300 m/min = 18 km/hr

D. x km/hr = x×10003600 = 5x18 m/sec

Question 25
When a producer allows 36% commission on the retail price of his product, he earns a profit of 8.8%. What would be his profit if the commission is reduced by 24%?
  • A.36.6%
  • B.49.6%
  • C.59.6%
  • D.45.6%
Correct Answer: 49.6%

SP = Retail Price – Commission = R(1-0.36) = 0.64R

Profit % = 8.8%

SP = C(1+0.088) = 1.088C

Comparing both

0.64R = 1.088C

Or R = 1.0880.64 C = 1.7C

New commission = 36 – 24 = 12%

S1 = 0.88R = 0.88 × 1.7C = 1.496C

Thus, Profit = 49.6%.

Question 26
A sum was put at simple interest at a certain rate for 3 years. Had it been put at 1% higher rate, it would have fetched ₹5100 more. Find the sum.
  • A.₹170,000
  • B.₹150,000
  • C.₹175,000
  • D.₹200,000
Correct Answer: ₹170,000

Difference in Interest = P×1×3100

or 5100 = P×1×3100

or P = 170000.

Question 27
Which of the following statements contradict each other?A. All ducks are birds.B. Some ducks are birds.C. Some ducks are not birds.D. No ducks are birds.Choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.A and D Only
  • B.B and C Only
  • C.B and D Only
  • D.C and D Only
Correct Answer: B and D Only

Statement B: Some ducks are birds → means at least one duck is a bird.

Statement D: No ducks are birds → means zero ducks are birds.

 

Both cannot be true simultaneously, because if at least one duck is a bird (B), it’s impossible that no ducks are birds (D). They are logically contradictory — one must be false if the other is true.

Question 28
If the statement “No birds are animals” is given as false, which of the following statements can be inferred to be true?A. Some animals are not birds.B. Some birds are not animals.C. Some animals are birds.D. Some birds are animals.Choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.A and B Only
  • B.C and D Only
  • C.B Only
  • D.A, B, C and D
Correct Answer: C and D Only

“No birds are animals” means → there is no overlap between birds and animals (i.e., the two groups are completely separate).

If that statement is false, it means that there is at least some overlap between birds and animals.

 

So, some birds are animals must be true.

 

Some animals are birds also says the same thing as “Some birds are animals.”

 

Thus, C and D are correct.

Question 29
“This is the richest fraternity on the campus; therefore Mr. X who is a member of this fraternity must be one of the richest young men on the campus.”Which fallacy is involved in this argument?
  • A.Fallacy of division
  • B.Fallacy of irrelevant conclusion
  • C.Red Herring
  • D.Slippery slope
Correct Answer: Fallacy of division

The fallacy of division occurs when someone assumes that what is true of a whole must also be true of its parts.

 

Here: The fraternity (as a group) is rich.

The argument wrongly assumes that each individual member, including Mr. X, must therefore be rich.

 

That’s exactly the fallacy of division — attributing a property of the group to its individual members.

Question 30
Arrange the following in order of increasing extension.A. Social ScienceB. Political ScienceC. SciencesD. Politics of International RelationsChoose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.C, A, B, D
  • B.A, C, B, D
  • C.B, D, A, C
  • D.D, B, A, C
Correct Answer: D, B, A, C

Politics of International Relations → Very specific field (smallest extension).

Political Science → Broader than (1), since it includes many branches like comparative politics, public administration, etc.

Social Science → Includes Political Science, Sociology, Economics, etc.

Sciences → The broadest category, including both natural and social sciences.

 

Hence, in increasing order of extension (from narrowest to broadest):

D → B → A → C.

Question 31
According to the classical Indian school of logic, which of the following instruments of knowledge is defined as the knowledge of the relation between a word and its denotation and is produced by the knowledge of resemblance or similarity?
  • A.Pratyakṣa(perception)
  • B.Anumāna(inference)
  • C.Upamāna(comparison)
  • D.Śabda(verbal testimony)
Correct Answer: Upamāna(comparison)

“The knowledge of the relation between a word and its denotation, produced by the knowledge of similarity (sādṛśya-jñāna).”

 

Example: If a person is told, “A gavaya (wild ox) is like a cow,” and later sees a wild ox in the forest resembling a cow, he recognizes it as gavaya.

Thus, the knowledge gained here (linking the word gavaya to its referent) is through Upamāna.

Question 32
Which of the following technologies is used in second generation of computer?
  • A.Vacuum tubes
  • B.Transistors
  • C.Integrated Circuits
  • D.VLSI
Correct Answer: Transistors

The second generation of computers (1956–1963) used transistors instead of vacuum tubes.
Transistors made computers smaller, faster, more reliable, and energy-efficient compared to the bulky first-generation machines that used vacuum tubes.

Question 33
Which of the following is the correct sequence of increasing access time of storage/memory devices?A. Magnetic tapeB. RAMC. Cache memoryD. Hard diskE. RegistersChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B, C, D, E
  • B.B, E, C, A, D
  • C.E, C, B, D, A
  • D.C, E, B, A, D
Correct Answer: E, C, B, D, A

Access time means how quickly data can be read or written.
From fastest to slowest (increasing access time):

Registers (E) – fastest, located inside the CPU.

Cache memory (C) – very fast, stores frequently used data.

RAM (B) – main memory, slower than cache.

Hard disk (D) – magnetic storage, much slower.

Magnetic tape (A) – sequential access, slowest.

Question 34
With reference tocyber attacks, which of the following statements are correct?A. Malware is a malicious software designed to cause damage to a single computer, server or computer network.B. Types ofmalwareinclude computer viruses, worms, trojan horses, ransomware and spyware.C. Pegasus is a malicious software classified as ransomware.D. India is not a signatory to the Budapest convention on cybercrime.Choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B and C only
  • B.B, C and D only
  • C.A, B, C and D
  • D.A, B and D only
Correct Answer: A, B and D only

A. ✅ True — Malware is indeed a malicious software designed to harm computers or networks.

B. ✅ True — Viruses, worms, trojans, ransomware, and spyware are all types of malware.

C. ❌ False — Pegasus is spyware, not ransomware. It secretly monitors user activity.

D. ✅ True — India has not signed the Budapest Convention on Cybercrime.

 

Hence, the correct combination is A, B and D only.

Question 35
Match List–I with List–II:List–I(Operating system)A. UNIXB. MS-DOSC. Android OSD. Utility programsList–II(Task)I. Assist users in system maintenance taskII. Mobile deviceIII. Single user operating systemIV. Multi-user operating systemChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A-III, B-IV, C-I, D-II
  • B.A-I, B-II, C-IV, D-III
  • C.A-IV, B-III, C-II, D-I
  • D.A-III, B-I, C-II, D-IV
Correct Answer: A-IV, B-III, C-II, D-I

A. UNIX → IV (Multi-user operating system): Allows multiple users to work simultaneously.

B. MS-DOS → III (Single-user operating system): Supports only one user at a time.

C. Android OS → II (Mobile device): Designed mainly for smartphones and tablets.

D. Utility programs → I (Assist users in system maintenance tasks): Help with file management, antivirus scanning, backup, etc.

Question 36
Which of the following are true about coliform bacteria?A. They are used to test water contamination.B. Coliform bacteria are harmless and cause no disease.C. They are found naturally in the human intestinal tract.D. Their presence in water is an indication offecalcontamination.Choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.A and D only
  • B.B and C only
  • C.A, C and D only
  • D.A, B, C and D
Correct Answer: A, B, C and D

All the given statements are true about coliform bacteria:

(A) They are used to test water contamination — true.

(B) Most coliform bacteria are harmless and do not cause disease — true (though some rare strains like E. coli O157:H7 can).

(C) They are found naturally in the human intestinal tract — true.

(D) Their presence in water indicates fecal contamination — true.

 

Therefore, all four statements A, B, C, and D are correct.

Question 37
Why is the concentration of CO₂ more in the Northern Hemisphere than the Southern Hemisphere?A. Land mass is more in the Northern Hemisphere.B. Ocean body is more in the Southern Hemisphere.C. Fossil fuel is burnt more in the Northern Hemisphere.D. Northern Hemisphere is colder than the Southern Hemisphere.Choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.A and C only
  • B.B, C and D only
  • C.A, B and C only
  • D.B and D only
Correct Answer: A, B and C only

(A) The Northern Hemisphere has more landmass, which means more population, industries, and vehicles.

(B) The Southern Hemisphere has more oceans, which absorb a significant portion of CO₂, keeping its concentration relatively lower.

(C) Fossil fuel burning is much higher in the Northern Hemisphere due to industrialization.
Together, these three reasons — more land, more fossil fuel burning, and more ocean absorption in the south — explain why CO₂ concentration is higher in the Northern Hemisphere.

Question 38
Increasing the ratio of fissile Uranium (U-235) in natural uranium is known as:
  • A.Enhancement
  • B.Concentration
  • C.Accumulation
  • D.Enrichment
Correct Answer: Enrichment

Increasing the proportion of the fissile isotope U-235 in natural uranium is called enrichment.
It raises the U-235 concentration (e.g., from ~0.7% in natural uranium to several percent) using methods like gas centrifuges or gaseous diffusion so the fuel becomes suitable for reactors or weapons depending on level.

Question 39
What is the correct sequence, from initial to final, of surface waste water treatment?A. DisinfectionB. SedimentationC. FiltrationD. ScreeningChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B, C, D
  • B.A, B, D, C
  • C.D, B, A, C
  • D.D, B, C, A
Correct Answer: D, B, C, A

The proper sequence of surface wastewater treatment steps is:

Screening (D): Removes large floating materials like plastics and leaves.

Sedimentation (B): Allows heavier particles to settle at the bottom.

Filtration (C): Filters out fine suspended impurities.

Disinfection (A): Kills harmful microorganisms using chlorine, ozone, or UV light.

Hence, the order from initial to final is D → B → C → A.

Question 40
Which of the following are differences between Modified Mercalli Scale (MMS) and Richter Scale (RS)?A. RS measures the energy released while MMS measures both energy and devastation.B. RS uses linear scale while MMS uses logarithmic scale.C. Value of RS is constant in an earthquake while MMS varies depending upon distance.D. Levels in RS are more than MMS.Choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.A and B only
  • B.B and C only
  • C.C and D only
  • D.A and C only
Correct Answer: A and C only

(A) ✅ True: The Richter Scale (RS) measures the energy released during an earthquake, while the Modified Mercalli Scale (MMS) measures the intensity or impact (damage and human perception).

(B) ❌ RS is logarithmic, not linear; MMS is descriptive, not numerical.

(C) ✅ True: RS value is constant for an earthquake, but MMS values vary by location and distance from the epicenter.

(D) ❌ RS theoretically has no upper limit, while MMS has 12 levels.

Hence, the correct answer is A and C only.

 

Question 41
In an ancient period, the Diksha Guru performed his duty as:
  • A.Guru of secular subjects
  • B.Spiritual guide for both girls and boys
  • C.Spiritual guide of boys
  • D.Tutor
Correct Answer: Spiritual guide of boys

In ancient times, the Diksha Guru was a spiritual mentor who gave diksha (initiation) into spiritual knowledge and discipline. Traditionally, this initiation was provided only to boys, particularly during the Upanayana (sacred thread) ceremony, marking the start of their formal education and spiritual life under the Guru’s guidance.

Question 42
Which international organization coordinates the Education for All programme at the global level?
  • A.UNDP
  • B.UNESCO
  • C.IMF
  • D.UNEP
Correct Answer: UNESCO

The Education for All (EFA) programme is a global movement led and coordinated by UNESCO (United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization).
Its goal is to ensure universal access to quality basic education for all children, youth, and adults, promoting inclusive and lifelong learning opportunities worldwide.

Question 43
Arrange the following events in the correct chronological sequence.A. Establishment of the University of MadrasB. Introduction of the Indian Universities ActC. Establishment of UGCD. First National Education Policy of IndiaChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B, C, D
  • B.A, D, C, B
  • C.B, C, A, D
  • D.C, B, A, D
Correct Answer: A, B, C, D

Here is the chronological order of the events:

Establishment of the University of Madras – 1857 (one of the first three universities in India).

Introduction of the Indian Universities Act – 1904 (to improve university administration).

Establishment of UGC – 1953 (University Grants Commission for higher education coordination).

First National Education Policy – 1968 (based on Kothari Commission recommendations).

 

Hence, the correct sequence is A → B → C → D.

Question 44
As per the National Education Policy 1986, the major functions of the National Apex Body are:A. To allocate resourcesB. To evaluate the examination systemC. To advise government on policyD. To encourage inter-disciplinarily and promotion of interfaces among different areasE. To conduct research in higher educationChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, C, E only
  • B.B, D, E only
  • C.C, D, E only
  • D.A, C, D only
Correct Answer: A, C, D only

As per the National Education Policy (NEP) 1986, the National Apex Body (like UGC) had key roles such as:

(A) Allocating resources to universities and higher education institutions.

(C) Advising the government on higher education policy matters.

(D) Encouraging interdisciplinarity and promoting collaboration among different academic areas.

Hence, the major functions included resource allocation, policy advice, and promotion of interdisciplinarity — making A, C, and D the correct combination.

Question 45
Match List–I with List–II:List–I (Name of the Institutions)A. NIEPAB. RUSAC. QAAD. HEFAList–II (Function)I. Ensuring QualityII. Providing loans to higher education institutionsIII. Infrastructure development for upgrading existing colleges into model collegesIV. Promoting research in planning and managementChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A–I, B–III, C–II, D–IV
  • B.A–I, B–II, C–III, D–IV
  • C.A–I, B–IV, C–III, D–II
  • D.A–IV, B–III, C–I, D–II
Correct Answer: A–IV, B–III, C–I, D–II

A. NIEPA (National Institute of Educational Planning and Administration) → (IV) Promoting research in planning and management of education.

B. RUSA (Rashtriya Uchchatar Shiksha Abhiyan) → (III) Infrastructure development for upgrading existing colleges into model institutions.

C. QAA (Quality Assurance Agency) → (I) Ensuring quality in higher education.

D. HEFA (Higher Education Financing Agency) → (II) Providing loans to higher education institutions for infrastructure and development.

Question 46
Read the following passage carefully and answer the questions.Forced by circumstances and in search of success and status, educated young men and women settle far away from their parents. Some go abroad. The very education that the parents manage to give to their children turns against them in the end. Their children go away in search of green pastures leaving them alone. International community as well as our government is aware of their problems. The UNO proclaimed the year 1999 as ‘International Year for the Aged’. In our own country too, the year 2000 was proclaimed ‘The Year for the Aged’.Article 41 of our constitution clearly makes it incumbent on the state to look after the aged. There is a social welfare ministry responsible for the welfare of the aged. Laws are made from time to time to protect the rights of senior citizens. For example, under law, parents cannot be evicted from a house without due process of law under section 105 of the Criminal Procedure Code. A magistrate can order a person to maintain his/her old parents under the Maintenance of Parents Act. The Hindu Adoption and Maintenance Act says that the aged parents can demand for maintenance from their children. The Domestic Violence Act also provides parents with the rights to seek relief from any kind of abuse.Ques.According to the passage, who usually leaves their parents in lurch?
  • A.Disobedient wards
  • B.Frustrated youth
  • C.Career seeker children settled in distant places
  • D.The ones who have job insecurity
Correct Answer: Career seeker children settled in distant places

According to the passage, educated young men and women move far away or even abroad in search of success, career, and status.
As a result, they leave their aged parents alone, often unintentionally, due to work and life circumstances. Hence, it is the career-seeking children settled in distant places who leave their parents in the lurch.

Question 47
Read the following passage carefully and answer the questions.Forced by circumstances and in search of success and status, educated young men and women settle far away from their parents. Some go abroad. The very education that the parents manage to give to their children turns against them in the end. Their children go away in search of green pastures leaving them alone. International community as well as our government is aware of their problems. The UNO proclaimed the year 1999 as ‘International Year for the Aged’. In our own country too, the year 2000 was proclaimed ‘The Year for the Aged’.Article 41 of our constitution clearly makes it incumbent on the state to look after the aged. There is a social welfare ministry responsible for the welfare of the aged. Laws are made from time to time to protect the rights of senior citizens. For example, under law, parents cannot be evicted from a house without due process of law under section 105 of the Criminal Procedure Code. A magistrate can order a person to maintain his/her old parents under the Maintenance of Parents Act. The Hindu Adoption and Maintenance Act says that the aged parents can demand for maintenance from their children. The Domestic Violence Act also provides parents with the rights to seek relief from any kind of abuse.Ques.The year 1999 was proclaimed as:
  • A.National year for the aged
  • B.Universal year for the aged
  • C.International year for the aged
  • D.SAARC year for the aged
Correct Answer: International year for the aged

As mentioned in the passage, the United Nations Organization (UNO) proclaimed the year 1999 as the “International Year for the Aged” to highlight the issues and welfare of elderly people around the world.

Question 48
Read the following passage carefully and answer the questions.Forced by circumstances and in search of success and status, educated young men and women settle far away from their parents. Some go abroad. The very education that the parents manage to give to their children turns against them in the end. Their children go away in search of green pastures leaving them alone. International community as well as our government is aware of their problems. The UNO proclaimed the year 1999 as ‘International Year for the Aged’. In our own country too, the year 2000 was proclaimed ‘The Year for the Aged’.Article 41 of our constitution clearly makes it incumbent on the state to look after the aged. There is a social welfare ministry responsible for the welfare of the aged. Laws are made from time to time to protect the rights of senior citizens. For example, under law, parents cannot be evicted from a house without due process of law under section 105 of the Criminal Procedure Code. A magistrate can order a person to maintain his/her old parents under the Maintenance of Parents Act. The Hindu Adoption and Maintenance Act says that the aged parents can demand for maintenance from their children. The Domestic Violence Act also provides parents with the rights to seek relief from any kind of abuse.Ques.Under section 105 of the Criminal Procedure Code, parents cannot be evicted from a house:
  • A.Without due process of law
  • B.In any situation
  • C.Without submitting their will
  • D.Unless their property is transferred to their legal heir
Correct Answer: Without due process of law

As stated in the passage, under Section 105 of the Criminal Procedure Code, parents cannot be evicted from a house without due process of law.
This means no one can forcefully remove them unless it is done legally through a proper court procedure.

Question 49
Read the following passage carefully and answer the questions.Forced by circumstances and in search of success and status, educated young men and women settle far away from their parents. Some go abroad. The very education that the parents manage to give to their children turns against them in the end. Their children go away in search of green pastures leaving them alone. International community as well as our government is aware of their problems. The UNO proclaimed the year 1999 as ‘International Year for the Aged’. In our own country too, the year 2000 was proclaimed ‘The Year for the Aged’.Article 41 of our constitution clearly makes it incumbent on the state to look after the aged. There is a social welfare ministry responsible for the welfare of the aged. Laws are made from time to time to protect the rights of senior citizens. For example, under law, parents cannot be evicted from a house without due process of law under section 105 of the Criminal Procedure Code. A magistrate can order a person to maintain his/her old parents under the Maintenance of Parents Act. The Hindu Adoption and Maintenance Act says that the aged parents can demand for maintenance from their children. The Domestic Violence Act also provides parents with the rights to seek relief from any kind of abuse.Ques.Who is empowered to give order to the concerned for the maintenance of their parents?
  • A.A retired judge
  • B.The judge of the High Court
  • C.Local Sarpanch
  • D.A magistrate
Correct Answer: A magistrate

According to the passage, a magistrate has the authority to order a person to maintain his or her old parents under the Maintenance of Parents Act.
This ensures legal protection and financial support for elderly parents from their children.

Question 50
Read the following passage carefully and answer the questions.Forced by circumstances and in search of success and status, educated young men and women settle far away from their parents. Some go abroad. The very education that the parents manage to give to their children turns against them in the end. Their children go away in search of green pastures leaving them alone. International community as well as our government is aware of their problems. The UNO proclaimed the year 1999 as ‘International Year for the Aged’. In our own country too, the year 2000 was proclaimed ‘The Year for the Aged’.Article 41 of our constitution clearly makes it incumbent on the state to look after the aged. There is a social welfare ministry responsible for the welfare of the aged. Laws are made from time to time to protect the rights of senior citizens. For example, under law, parents cannot be evicted from a house without due process of law under section 105 of the Criminal Procedure Code. A magistrate can order a person to maintain his/her old parents under the Maintenance of Parents Act. The Hindu Adoption and Maintenance Act says that the aged parents can demand for maintenance from their children. The Domestic Violence Act also provides parents with the rights to seek relief from any kind of abuse.Ques.Which of the following Act/Section does give parents rights to seek relief from any kind of abuse?
  • A.Hindu Adoption and Maintenance Act
  • B.Section 105 of CPC
  • C.The Domestic Violence Act
  • D.Section 98 of CPC
Correct Answer: The Domestic Violence Act

As mentioned in the passage, The Domestic Violence Act provides parents the right to seek relief from any kind of abuse, whether physical, emotional, or economic.
It protects senior citizens living with their children or family members from mistreatment and neglect.

Quiz Attempt #119697

Total Questions: 50
Question 1
The following table shows the cumulative number ofsaleof Red Electric Vehicles (EVs) out of the total number of Red and White EVs sold and the cumulative percentage of the total number of EVs sold in five different months from May to September. Based on the data in the table, answer the questions that follow.Month-wise Sale Distribution of EVsMonthsCumulative number ofsaleof Red EVsCumulative percentage of sale of EVs (Red and White in colour)May36025 %Till June45641 %Till July81661 %Till August103279 %Till September1232100 %Note: Total number of EVs (Red and White) sold in all the 5 months is 2400.What is the number of Red EVs sold in August?
  • A.180
  • B.200
  • C.160
  • D.216
Correct Answer: 216

Red EVs sold in August = 1032 – 816 = 216.

Question 2
The following table shows the cumulative number ofsaleof Red Electric Vehicles (EVs) out of the total number of Red and White EVs sold and the cumulative percentage of the total number of EVs sold in five different months from May to September. Based on the data in the table, answer the questions that follow.Month-wise Sale Distribution of EVsMonthsCumulative number ofsaleof Red EVsCumulative percentage of sale of EVs (Red and White in colour)May36025 %Till June45641 %Till July81661 %Till August103279 %Till September1232100 %Note: Total number of EVs (Red and White) sold in all the 5 months is 2400.What is the difference between the number of White EVs sold in June and the number of Red EVs sold in August?
  • A.120
  • B.90
  • C.104
  • D.72
Correct Answer: 72

Red EVs sold in August = 1032 – 816 = 216

Red EVs in June = 456 – 360 =96

Red + White EVs in June = (41 – 25)% of 2400 = 384

White EV’s in June = 384 – 96 = 288

Difference = 288 – 216 = 72.

Question 3
The following table shows the cumulative number ofsaleof Red Electric Vehicles (EVs) out of the total number of Red and White EVs sold and the cumulative percentage of the total number of EVs sold in five different months from May to September. Based on the data in the table, answer the questions that follow.Month-wise Sale Distribution of EVsMonthsCumulative number ofsaleof Red EVsCumulative percentage of sale of EVs (Red and White in colour)May36025 %Till June45641 %Till July81661 %Till August103279 %Till September1232100 %Note: Total number of EVs (Red and White) sold in all the 5 months is 2400.What is the average number of White EVs sold in May, June and July together?
  • A.270
  • B.224
  • C.216
  • D.308
Correct Answer: 216

Red + white in May, June and July = 61% of 2400 = 1464

Red EVs in May, June and July = 816

White in May, June and July = 648

Average = 6483 = 216.

Question 4
The following table shows the cumulative number ofsaleof Red Electric Vehicles (EVs) out of the total number of Red and White EVs sold and the cumulative percentage of the total number of EVs sold in five different months from May to September. Based on the data in the table, answer the questions that follow.Month-wise Sale Distribution of EVsMonthsCumulative number ofsaleof Red EVsCumulative percentage of sale of EVs (Red and White in colour)May36025 %Till June45641 %Till July81661 %Till August103279 %Till September1232100 %Note: Total number of EVs (Red and White) sold in all the 5 months is 2400.Number of White EVs sold in May is ______ % more than the number of Red EVs sold in September.
  • A.10
  • B.5
  • C.20
  • D.15
Correct Answer: 20

White EVs in May = 25% of 2400 – 360 = 600 – 360 = 240

Red EVs in September = 1232 – 1032 = 200

Required percentage = 240-200200 × 100 = 20%.

Question 5
The following table shows the cumulative number ofsaleof Red Electric Vehicles (EVs) out of the total number of Red and White EVs sold and the cumulative percentage of the total number of EVs sold in five different months from May to September. Based on the data in the table, answer the questions that follow.Month-wise Sale Distribution of EVsMonthsCumulative number ofsaleof Red EVsCumulative percentage of sale of EVs (Red and White in colour)May36025 %Till June45641 %Till July81661 %Till August103279 %Till September1232100 %Note: Total number of EVs (Red and White) sold in all the 5 months is 2400.What is the ratio of the number of EVs sold in May and the average number of red and white EVs sold in August?
  • A.11 :7
  • B.9 :4
  • C.17 :12
  • D.25 :9
Correct Answer: 25 :9

Average number of red and white EVs sold in August = (79-61)% of 24002 = 216

EVs sold in May = 25% of 2400 = 600

Required ratio = 600 : 216 = 25 : 9.

Question 6
Which of the following is one of the advantages of behavioural objectives that determine Teaching and Learning in Higher Education?
  • A.These are teacher-centred.
  • B.These make learning focused and achievable.
  • C.These focus too narrowly on minutiae.
  • D.These limit opportunities from spontaneous unintended outcomes occurring during learning experience.
Correct Answer: These make learning focused and achievable.

Behavioural objectives describe learning outcomes in specific, observable, and measurable terms. They are widely used in higher education to guide both teaching and assessment.

 

Advantages include:

  • They make learning focused, as both teacher and students know exactly what is expected.
  • They make outcomes achievable and measurable, ensuring clarity in instructional design and evaluation.
  • They also help align teaching strategies, learning activities, and assessments.

 

Options (A), (C), and (D) are limitations, not advantages — they suggest overemphasis on control and reduced flexibility.

Question 7
Which of the following is the strategy that support motivation?
  • A.Connections across the curriculum.
  • B.Attributions to intellect rather than effort.
  • C.Work that is too much difficult.
  • D.Emphasis on finishing, not learning.
Correct Answer: Connections across the curriculum.

A key strategy to support motivation in learners is helping them see meaningful connections between what they are learning and its application across different subjects or real-life contexts. When students recognize relevance and interlinkages, their intrinsic motivation and engagement increase.

Question 8
Arrange the steps of classroom action researchA. PlanB. ReflectC. ActionD. ObserveE. Follow upChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.B, A, C, E, D
  • B.C, B, E, D, A
  • C.A, C, D, B, E
  • D.D, E, A, C, B
Correct Answer: A, C, D, B, E

Classroom Action Research follows a systematic cycle that helps teachers improve their teaching practices through reflection and evidence-based change. The correct sequence of steps is:

 

Plan (A): The teacher identifies a problem or area for improvement in the classroom and designs an action plan or strategy to address it.

 

Action (C): The planned intervention or teaching strategy is implemented in the classroom.

 

Observe (D): The teacher collects data and observes the effects of the implemented action on student learning and classroom processes.

 

Reflect (B): The teacher analyses and evaluates the outcomes, identifying what worked well and what needs further improvement.

 

Follow up (E): Based on reflection, the teacher refines or revises the plan and continues the cycle to enhance teaching and learning further.

Question 9
Which of the following are the characteristics of adolescent learners?(A) Increased emotional sensitivity(B) High level of self-discipline(C) Strong need for social belonging(D) Cognitive development for abstract thinking(E) Emotional validityChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A and D Only
  • B.B and C Only
  • C.D, C and E Only
  • D.A, C, D and E Only
Correct Answer: A, C, D and E Only

Adolescence is a crucial stage of development marked by rapid physical, emotional, and cognitive changes. The key characteristics of adolescent learners include:

 

(A) Increased emotional sensitivity:

Adolescents experience heightened emotions and mood swings due to hormonal and psychological changes.

 

(C) Strong need for social belonging:

Peer relationships become extremely important, and adolescents seek acceptance, approval, and identity within social groups.

 

(D) Cognitive development for abstract thinking:

According to Piaget’s formal operational stage, adolescents develop the ability to think abstractly, reason logically, and consider hypothetical situations.

 

(E) Emotional validity:

They begin to seek acknowledgment and validation of their emotions and opinions, wanting their feelings to be understood and respected.

 

However, (B) High level of self-discipline is not typically characteristic of this age group; adolescents are still developing self-regulation and impulse control.

Question 10
Match the List-I with List-IIList-IA. Classroom ManagementB. CollaborationC. Affective domainD. Cognitive domainList-III. Objectives focussing on attitudes and feelings.II. Memory and reasoning objectives.III. Techniques used to maintain a healthy learning environment.IV. A philosophy about how to relate to others.Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A–III, B–IV, C–I, D–II
  • B.A–IV, B–III, C–II, D–I
  • C.A–I, B–II, C–III, D–IV
  • D.A–II, B–I, C–IV, D–III
Correct Answer: A–III, B–IV, C–I, D–II

A. Classroom Management – (III) Techniques used to maintain a healthy learning environment: Classroom management involves strategies, rules, and techniques that help maintain order, discipline, and a positive environment conducive to learning.

 

B. Collaboration – (IV) A philosophy about how to relate to others: Collaboration is based on the belief that learning and problem-solving improve when people work together respectfully and share ideas.

 

C. Affective Domain – (I) Objectives focusing on attitudes and feelings: The affective domain of learning (from Bloom’s Taxonomy) relates to emotions, values, motivation, and attitudes.

 

D. Cognitive Domain – (II) Memory and reasoning objectives: The cognitive domain includes mental processes such as remembering, understanding, applying, analyzing, evaluating, and creating knowledge.

Question 11
What is pure research?
  • A.It is concerned with search for ways of using scientific knowledge to solve practical problems.
  • B.It does not develop and test hypothesis and theories.
  • C.This research is not used to reject or support the existing theories about social phenomena.
  • D.It is also called basic research and is concerned with quest for knowledge and knowing more about the phenomenon without concern for its practical use.
Correct Answer: It is also called basic research and is concerned with quest for knowledge and knowing more about the phenomenon without concern for its practical use.

Pure research, also known as basic research or fundamental research, aims to expand existing knowledge and deepen our understanding of natural or social phenomena without focusing on immediate practical applications.

 

It is driven by curiosity and the desire to develop theories, principles, or laws that explain how things work.

Question 12
What is case study method
  • A.It studies the phenomenon, event, situation or development in a very simplified and shallow manner.
  • B.It is studying the phenomenon, event, situation or development through a thorough and detailed analysis or intensive study.
  • C.This study depends on analysis of responses collected through data.
  • D.It is concerned with search for ways of using common sense to solve practical problems.
Correct Answer: It is studying the phenomenon, event, situation or development through a thorough and detailed analysis or intensive study.

The case study method is a qualitative research approach used to gain a deep and comprehensive understanding of a single individual, group, event, institution, or situation.

 

It involves intensive, in-depth analysis of the selected case using multiple sources of data such as interviews, observations, and documents.

 

The goal is to explore the complexity and uniqueness of the case in its real-life context, rather than simplifying it or generalizing results to a larger population.

 

Hence, a case study is characterized by depth, detail, and contextual understanding, making option (B) the correct answer.

Question 13
Mean (M) and coefficient of variation (CV expressed as a percentage) of different datasets are given in A–D below. Compute the standard deviation of each dataset and arrange in ascending order.A. M = 60, CV = 70/3B. M = 70, CV = 6.25C. M = 70, CV = 160/7D. M = 90, CV = 40/9Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.D, A, B, C
  • B.A, C, D, B
  • C.D, B, A, C
  • D.B, D, C, A
Correct Answer: D, B, A, C

SD = CV ×M100

By putting values, the correct order will be:

D, B, A, C

Question 14
Research misconduct includes which of the following?A.Data fabricationB.PlagiarismC.Data falsificationD.Differences of opinionE.Data validationChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B, C and E Only
  • B.C, D and E Only
  • C.D and E Only
  • D.A, B and C Only
Correct Answer: A, B and C Only

Research misconduct refers to unethical practices that compromise the integrity, accuracy, and honesty of research.

It includes:

 

(A) Data fabrication: Making up data or results that never occurred.

(B) Plagiarism: Using someone else’s ideas, words, or work without proper acknowledgment.

(C) Data falsification: Manipulating, altering, or omitting data to misrepresent results.

Question 15
Match the List-I with List-IIList-I(n = number of Trials, p = Probability of Success)A. n = 5, p = 0.4B. n = 6, p = 0.6C. n = 8, p = 0.5D. n = 7, p = 0.4List-II(Mean and Standard Deviation of Binomial Distribution)I. 2.8 and 1.296II. 2.0 and 1.095III. 4.0 and 1.414IV. 3.6 and 1.200Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A–II, B–III, C–IV, D–I
  • B.A–I, B–IV, C–III, D–II
  • C.A–III, B–II, C–I, D–IV
  • D.A–II, B–IV, C–III, D–I
Correct Answer: A–II, B–IV, C–III, D–I

Mean = np

And Standard Deviation = n×p×(1-p)

We can find out values with this formula.

Question 16
The first film Raja Harish Chandra directed by Dada Saheb Phalke was made in which year in India?
  • A.1913
  • B.1914
  • C.1915
  • D.1931
Correct Answer: 1913

“Raja Harishchandra”, directed and produced by Dadasaheb Phalke, is recognized as the first full-length Indian feature film. It was released in 1913, marking the beginning of Indian cinema.

Question 17
The first talkie film Alam Ara, directed byArdesharIrani was made in which year in India?
  • A.1929
  • B.1930
  • C.1931
  • D.1913
Correct Answer: 1931

“Alam Ara”, directed by Ardeshir Irani, was the first Indian talkie (sound) film, meaning it was the first movie in India with synchronized dialogue and music. It was made in 1931.

Question 18
Write the correct chronological order of the following films as per their release year. (From earliest to the latest)A. PsychoB. Bicycle ThievesC. City LightsD. Citizen KaneE. RashomonChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B, C, D, E
  • B.B, C, A, D, E
  • C.C, D, B, E, A
  • D.B, D, A, C, E
Correct Answer: C, D, B, E, A

C. City Lights – 1931 (Directed by Charlie Chaplin)

D. Citizen Kane – 1941 (Directed by Orson Welles)

B. Bicycle Thieves – 1948 (Directed by Vittorio De Sica)

E. Rashomon – 1950 (Directed by Akira Kurosawa)

A. Psycho – 1960 (Directed by Alfred Hitchcock)

Question 19
What among the following are the barriers to communication?A.Loud musicB.Ill healthC.A telephone that is in poor working orderD.Good healthE.Traffic noiseChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B, C and D Only
  • B.A, B, C and E Only
  • C.B and D Only
  • D.A, D and E Only
Correct Answer: A, B, C and E Only

Barriers to communication are obstacles that distort or hinder the effective transmission of a message between sender and receiver.

 

Except good health, all are the barriers to communication.

Question 20
Match the List I with List IIList-I(Terms)A. Communication EventB. Communication MediaC. Communication TechnologyD. Communication ProfessionalList-II(Examples)I. Radio and TVII. Smartphone and EmailIII. Journalists and AdvertisersIV. Conference and MeetingChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A–IV, B–I, C–II, D–III
  • B.A–III, B–II, C–I, D–IV
  • C.A–II, B–III, C–IV, D–I
  • D.A–I, B–IV, C–III, D–II
Correct Answer: A–IV, B–I, C–II, D–III

A. Communication Event – (IV) Conference and Meeting

A communication event is an occasion where interaction or exchange of ideas takes place — such as a meeting, seminar, or conference.

 

B. Communication Media – (I) Radio and TV

Media are channels used to transmit messages to large audiences. Radio and television are classic examples of mass communication media.

 

C. Communication Technology – (II) Smartphone and Email

Communication technology refers to digital tools and devices that enable communication — such as smartphones, emails, and video conferencing platforms.

 

D. Communication Professional – (III) Journalists and Advertisers

Communication professionals are people who create, manage, and deliver messages — including journalists, public relations experts, and advertisers.

Question 21
Find the wrong number in the series given below:1, 2, 5, 14, 41, 125
  • A.125
  • B.5
  • C.2
  • D.41
Correct Answer: 125

The first term is 1.

To get the second term, 1 + 30 = 2

To get the third term, 2 + 31 = 5

To get the fourth term, 5 + 32 = 14

To get the fifth term, 14 + 33 = 41

Similarly, sixth term = 41 + 34 = 122

 

The last number in the given series is 125, which does not follow the pattern. The correct number should be 122.

Question 22
If in a certain code language 'PERFECT' is written as '73', then how will 'COMPACT' be written in that language?
  • A.69
  • B.71
  • C.75
  • D.77
Correct Answer: 71

P(16) + E(5) + R(18) + F(6) + E(5) + C(3) + T(20) = 73

So the code is the sum of letter positions.

 

New code = 3 + 15 + 13 + 16 + 1 + 3 + 20 = 71.

Question 23
Match the List-I with List-IIList-I(Question)A. What percent of a day is 3 hours?B. What is the average of first nine prime numbers?C. What is the average of first five multiples of 3?D. Sum of the ages of A and B is 12 years more than the sum of the ages of B and C. How many years C is younger than A?List-II(Answer)I. 9II. 12III. 12.5IV. 11.111Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A–I, B–II, C–III, D–IV
  • B.A–II, B–I, C–III, D–IV
  • C.A–III, B–IV, C–I, D–II
  • D.A–III, B–IV, C–II, D–I
Correct Answer: A–III, B–IV, C–I, D–II

A. 324×100 = 12.5%

 

B. 2 + 3 + 5 + 7 + 11 + 13 + 17 + 19 + 23 = 100

Average = 1009 = 11.11

 

C. 3 + 6 + 9 + 12 + 15 = 45

Average = 455 = 9

 

D. a + b = b + c + 12

or a = c + 12

Which means C is 12 years younger than A.

Question 24
The price of a jewel, passing through three hands, rises on the whole by 65%. If the first and second sellers earned 20% and 25% profit respectively, then find the percentage of profit earned by the third seller.
  • A.10
  • B.15
  • C.20
  • D.30
Correct Answer: 10

After 1st seller’s 20% profit → price = 1.2x

After 2nd seller’s 25% profit → price = 1.5x

Overall increase is 65%, so final price = 1.65x

Now the 3rd seller bought it at 1.5x and sold it at 1.65x.

Profit of 3rd seller = 1.65x-1.5x1.5x×100 = 10%

Question 25
Which of the following statements A–D are correct?A. 5% of (25% of 1600) is 50.B. 0.15% of3313% of10,000 is 5.C. If interest earned on ₹15,000 in 3 years at simple interest is ₹5400, then the rate of interest is 12%.D. Ifx3=y4=z5, thenx :y :z =2 :3 :7.Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B and C Only
  • B.B and C Only
  • C.B, C and D Only
  • D.A and D Only
Correct Answer: B and C Only

A. 0.05 × 0.25 × 1600 = 20

B. 0.15% of 33 13 % of 10,000 = 5

C. 5400 = 15000×R×3100

or R = 5400×10015000×3 = 12%

D. x3 = y4 = z5 = k

or x = 3k

y = 4k

z = 5k

x : y : z = 3 : 4 : 5.

Question 26
Which of the following statements are sub-contraries?A.All sparrows are birds.B.No sparrows are birds.C.Some sparrows are birds.D.Some sparrows are not birds.Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.C and D Only
  • B.B and D Only
  • C.A and B Only
  • D.B and C Only
Correct Answer: C and D Only

In traditional logic, sub-contrary statements are two particular propositions (both can be true but cannot both be false).

 

Thus, “Some sparrows are birds” (I) and “Some sparrows are not birds” (O) are sub-contraries because: They can both be true (some sparrows are birds, and some are not, depending on context), But they cannot both be false.

Question 27
If the statement “Some animals are not birds” is given as false, which of the following statements can be inferred to be true?A.All animals are birds.B.No birds are animals.C.No animals are birds.D.Some animals are birds.Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A and B Only
  • B.B and D Only
  • C.A and D Only
  • D.B and C Only
Correct Answer: A and D Only

The contradictory of “Some animals are not birds” is “All animals are birds.”

→ When one is false, the other must be true. So, if “Some animals are not birds” is false, then “All animals are birds” is true.

 

From the true universal affirmative statement “All animals are birds,” we can logically infer the particular affirmative statement “Some animals are birds.”

 

“No birds are animals” and “No animals are birds” are universal negatives (E-type), which directly contradict the truth of “All animals are birds.” Hence, both are false.

Question 28
“It is immoral to use textbooks with profane words in them because it is not right for our children to be exposed to disrespectful and ugly words.”Which logical fallacy is committed in the above argument?
  • A.Argument in circle
  • B.Hasty Generalization
  • C.Strawman
  • D.Fallacy of Division
Correct Answer: Argument in circle

This argument commits the fallacy of circular reasoning (also known as begging the question or argument in a circle).

 

In circular reasoning, the conclusion merely restates the premise in different words, without providing any independent justification.

 

The claim “it is immoral” is just restated as “it is not right,” without giving any new reason or evidence. The argument goes in a circle — assuming what it needs to prove.

Question 29
Arrange the following in order of decreasing extension.A. CheeseB. Food productsC. Dairy productsD. Cottage cheeseChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, D, C, B
  • B.C, B, A, D
  • C.B, C, A, D
  • D.D, A, C, B
Correct Answer: B, C, A, D

Extension (or denotation) in logic refers to the number of members or scope a term covers.

A term with greater extension includes more items and is therefore more general; one with lesser extension is more specific.

 

Now, arranging from most general (largest extension) to most specific (smallest extension):

Food products (B) → most general; includes all types of food.

Dairy products (C) → a subset of food products (milk, cheese, yogurt, etc.).

Cheese (A) → a specific type of dairy product.

Cottage cheese (D) → a specific kind of cheese.

Question 30
“A university student is never seen to be writing or reading during the daytime but she always submits her assignments in time.Thereforeone can conclude that she must be studying and writing during the night time.”According toMīmāṃsāSchool of Classical Indian Philosophy, which instrument of knowledge (pramāṇa) is used in the above argument?
  • A.Anumāna
  • B.Arthāpatti
  • C.Unupalabdhi
  • D.AlaukikaPratyakṣa
Correct Answer: Arthāpatti

In the Mīmāṃsā School of Indian Philosophy, Arthāpatti (postulation or presumption) is a means of knowledge (pramāṇa) used when a fact can only be explained by assuming another fact that is not directly perceived or inferred.

Question 31
HTTP stands for _____.
  • A.Hyper Text Transmission Protocol
  • B.Hyper Text Transfer Protocol
  • C.Hyper Text Testing Protocol
  • D.Hyper Text Transit Protocol
Correct Answer: Hyper Text Transfer Protocol

HTTP stands for Hyper Text Transfer Protocol — it is the foundation of data communication on the World Wide Web. It defines how messages are formatted and transmitted between web browsers (clients) and web servers.

 

When you type a web address (URL) starting with http://, it means the browser is using this protocol to communicate.

Question 32
The IEEE name of Wi-Fi is _____.
  • A.802.3
  • B.802.11
  • C.802.15
  • D.802.2
Correct Answer: 802.11

Wi-Fi is the common name for the IEEE 802.11 family of standards.

IEEE 802.11 defines the set of protocols for Wireless Local Area Networks (WLANs). It specifies how devices communicate wirelessly over short distances using radio waves.

 

802.3 → Ethernet (wired LAN)

802.15 → Bluetooth (Wireless Personal Area Network)

802.2 → Logical Link Control (part of the data link layer)

Question 33
Which is the correct increasing order of memory storage capacity?A. 1 PBB. 1 TBC. 1 KBD. 1 GBE. 1 MBChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.C, D, E, A, B
  • B.C, E, D, A, B
  • C.C, E, D, B, A
  • D.C, D, E, B, A
Correct Answer: C, E, D, B, A

C = 1 KB

E = 1 MB

D = 1 GB

B = 1 TB

A = 1 PB

 

Correct increasing order: C → E → D → B → A

Question 34
Which of the following statements are correct?A.One KB has 1024 bytes.B.Cache memory is a secondary storage.C.Operating system is not an application software.D. Hub is a network device.E.ALU is a control unit.Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, D and E Only
  • B.A, B and C Only
  • C.A, C and D Only
  • D.C, D and E Only
Correct Answer: A, C and D Only

1 Kilobyte (KB) = 1024 bytes (as per binary system used in computers).

Cache memory is a type of high-speed primary memory, not secondary storage.

The Operating System (OS) is system software, which manages hardware and software resources.

A hub is a basic network connecting device that links multiple computers in a network.

The ALU (Arithmetic Logic Unit) and the Control Unit (CU) are two separate components of the CPU.

Question 35
Match the List I with List IIList-I(Hardware)A. ModemB. RouterC. NICD. RepeaterList-II(Function)I. Regenerate signalsII. Physical addressIII. IP addressIV. Conversion ofanalogand digital signalChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A–IV, B–III, C–II, D–I
  • B.A–III, B–II, C–I, D–IV
  • C.A–IV, B–II, C–III, D–I
  • D.A–I, B–II, C–IV, D–III
Correct Answer: A–IV, B–III, C–II, D–I

A. Modem – (IV) Conversion of analog and digital signal

A modem (modulator–demodulator) converts digital signals from a computer into analog signals for transmission over telephone lines, and vice versa.

 

B. Router – (III) IP address

A router directs data between different networks using IP addresses. It determines the best path for data packets.

 

C. NIC (Network Interface Card) – (II) Physical address

A NIC provides a MAC (Media Access Control) address, which is a unique physical address used for communication within a local network.

 

D. Repeater – (I) Regenerate signals

A repeater amplifies or regenerates weak signals to extend the distance of data transmission.

Question 36
International day for biological diversity is observed on
  • A.2 February
  • B.22 April
  • C.22 May
  • D.16 September
Correct Answer: 22 May

The International Day for Biological Diversity is observed every year on 22 May to increase understanding and awareness of biodiversity issues across the world.

 

Theme (recent years): Focuses on conserving ecosystems and promoting sustainable living.

 

Declared by: The United Nations to commemorate the adoption of the Convention on Biological Diversity (CBD) in 1992.

Question 37
Which of the following is a chemical treatment process in context to water treatment?
  • A.Sedimentation
  • B.Coagulation
  • C.Filtration
  • D.Grit Chamber
Correct Answer: Coagulation

In water treatment processes, methods are broadly classified as physical, chemical, or biological:

 

(A) Sedimentation → Physical process where heavy particles settle under gravity.

 

(B) Coagulation → Chemical process where coagulants (like alum or ferric salts) are added to water to neutralize suspended particles, allowing them to clump together (form flocs) for easier removal.

 

(C) Filtration → Physical process for removing fine suspended solids through filter media.

 

(D) Grit Chamber → Physical process for removing heavier inorganic matter such as sand and gravel.

Question 38
Which of the following are sinks of atmospheric carbon dioxide (CO₂)?A. WetlandsB. OceansC. SoilD. ElephantsChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A and B Only
  • B.C and D Only
  • C.A, B and C Only
  • D.A, B, C and D
Correct Answer: A, B, C and D

Carbon sinks are natural systems that absorb more carbon dioxide (CO₂) from the atmosphere than they release.

 

A. Wetlands — Wetlands store large amounts of carbon in their water-saturated soils and vegetation.

B. Oceans — Oceans absorb nearly one-fourth of global CO₂ emissions through dissolution and marine photosynthesis.

C. Soil — Soils act as major carbon reservoirs by storing organic carbon from decayed plants and organisms.

D. Elephants — Elephants are living organisms that breathe out CO₂; they are not carbon sinks.

 

Hence, the true sinks of atmospheric CO₂ are Wetlands, Oceans, and Soil only.

Question 39
How much more energy is released in an earthquake whose value is 4 on Richter Scale than in an earthquake whose value is 3 on Richter Scale?
  • A.Twice
  • B.10 %
  • C.10 times
  • D.50 %
Correct Answer: 10 times

The Richter Scale is a logarithmic scale, meaning that each whole number increase corresponds to a tenfold increase in the amplitude of seismic waves and approximately 31.6 times more energy released.

 

However, the question asks for “how much more energy is released” — in general understanding, this refers to the scale increase itself: An earthquake of magnitude 4 releases 10 times more energy than one of magnitude 3 in wave amplitude.

 

In actual energy terms, it’s about 31.6 times more, but the commonly accepted simplified answer (based on the scale definition) is 10 times.

Question 40
What is the correct sequence, from smaller to larger, of following photovoltaic related systems?A. ModuleB. ArrayC. Solar cellD. Array FieldChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.C, A, D, B
  • B.C, A, B, D
  • C.B, D, A, C
  • D.D, B, A, C
Correct Answer: C, A, B, D

Solar Cell (C) – The smallest unit that converts sunlight directly into electricity.

Module (A) – A group of interconnected solar cells packaged together (also called a solar panel).

Array (B) – Several modules connected together to increase power output.

Array Field (D) – A collection of multiple arrays installed together at a site (like a solar farm).

 

Correct order (smaller → larger): Solar Cell → Module → Array → Array Field.

Question 41
NEP 2020 emphasized the integration of value education to promote
  • A.life skill education among students.
  • B.religious education among students.
  • C.holistic development among students.
  • D.skill development among students.
Correct Answer: holistic development among students.

The National Education Policy (NEP) 2020 emphasizes the integration of value education as a core component of learning to ensure that education nurtures not only cognitive growth but also ethical, emotional, and social development.

 

  • Value education in NEP 2020 aims to:
  • Build character and moral values.
  • Foster empathy, respect, and responsibility.
  • Encourage critical thinking along with compassion.
  • Promote overall holistic development—intellectual, physical, emotional, and spiritual.

 

Hence, value education is intended not just for skill training or religious teaching, but to enable holistic development of learners.

Question 42
The full form of MOOC is
  • A.Massive Open Optional Course.
  • B.Massive Open Online Course.
  • C.Multimedia Open Online Course.
  • D.Multimedia Open Optional Course.
Correct Answer: Massive Open Online Course.

MOOC stands for Massive Open Online Course — a model of online learning designed to provide free or affordable access to education for large numbers of learners across the world.

 

  • Massive: Open to a large number of participants.
  • Open: Freely accessible (no strict entry barriers).
  • Online: Delivered via the internet.
  • Course: Structured learning experience with videos, readings, and assessments.

 

Examples include platforms like SWAYAM (India), Coursera, edX, and Udemy.

Question 43
Arrange the following steps in correct sequence to establish effective governance in higher education institutions.A. Formulate policies that ensure transparency and accountability.B. Involve faculty, staff and students in decision-making process.C. Establish a governing body with clear roles and responsibilities.D. Monitor and evaluate the implementation of policies and strategies.E. Review and update policies based on feedback and changing needs.Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B, D, E, C
  • B.C, A, B, D, F
  • C.B, C, A, E, D
  • D.D, E, C, A, B
Correct Answer: C, A, B, D, F

To establish effective governance in higher education institutions, the process follows a logical and structured order:

 

C. Establish a governing body with clear roles and responsibilities.

– Governance begins with forming an accountable authority that oversees institutional functioning.

 

A. Formulate policies that ensure transparency and accountability.

– The governing body then sets up clear, fair, and transparent policies and guidelines.

 

B. Involve faculty, staff, and students in the decision-making process.

– Inclusive participation ensures collective ownership and effective policy implementation.

 

D. Monitor and evaluate the implementation of policies and strategies.

– Regular monitoring helps identify gaps and ensures adherence to governance principles.

 

E. Review and update policies based on feedback and changing needs.

– Governance must remain dynamic by adapting to institutional and societal changes.

Question 44
In the Vedic Period, as Education was Idealistic in nature, the Acharyas laid stress uponA.Creation of an aptitude for the development of nation.B.Worship of God.C.Fulfillmentof desire and needs.D.Religiousness.E.Formation of character.Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, D and C Only
  • B.B, D and E Only
  • C.A, B, C, D and E
  • D.A, B, D and E Only
Correct Answer: A, B, D and E Only

Education during the Vedic Period was idealistic in nature, focusing on the holistic development of the learner — body, mind, and soul. The Āchāryas (teachers) aimed at nurturing moral, spiritual, and intellectual qualities that would help the learner serve both self and society.

 

They laid stress on:

 

(A) Creation of an aptitude for the development of nation:

Although the term “nation” is modern, the spirit of serving society and the community (Rāṣṭra Dharma) was emphasized even in the Vedas.

 

(B) Worship of God:

Spiritual growth and devotion to the divine were key ideals of education.

 

(D) Religiousness:

Education promoted righteousness, duty, and moral living in accordance with dharma.

 

(E) Formation of character:

The central goal was to develop a disciplined, virtuous, and self-controlled individual.

Question 45
Match the List-I with List-IIList-I(Name of Institutions)A. AICTEB. ICHRC. NITI AayogD. ICPRList-II(Year of Establishment)I. 1972II. 1945III. 1977IV. 2015Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A–I, B–III, C–II, D–IV
  • B.A–II, B–I, C–IV, D–III
  • C.A–II, B–I, C–III, D–IV
  • D.A–I, B–II, C–III, D–IV
Correct Answer: A–II, B–I, C–IV, D–III

Institution

Full Name

Year of Establishment

A. AICTE

All India Council for Technical Education

1945

B. ICHR

Indian Council of Historical Research

1972

C. NITI Aayog

National Institution for Transforming India

2015

D. ICPR

Indian Council of Philosophical Research

1977

 

Question 46
Read the following passage carefully and answer the questions:Self-directed learning, in its broadest meaning, describes a process in which individuals take the initiative with or without the help of others, in diagnosing their learning needs, formulation of learning goals, identifying resources for learning, choosing and implementing learning strategies and evaluating learning outcomes.
