Thus, it is important to attain new knowledge easily andskillfullyfor the rest of his or her life.What is the need for self-directed learning? One reason is that there is convincing evidence that people, who take the initiative in learning, learn more things and learn better than people waiting to be taught. The second reason is that self-directed learning is more in tune with our natural processes of psychological development; an essential aspect of maturing is developing the ability to take increasing responsibility of our own lives to become increasingly self-directed. The third reason has to do with the new development in education — putting a heavy responsibility on the learners to take a great deal of initiative in their own learning. To meet the challenges in today’s instructive environment, self-directed learning is most essential.An individual, by virtue of self-directed learning,
  • A.can independently take initiatives
  • B.remains passive and waits for directions
  • C.always depends on others
  • D.feels helpless in the absence of any support
Correct Answer: can independently take initiatives

The passage clearly defines self-directed learning as a process in which individuals take the initiative—

  • in identifying their learning needs,
  • setting goals,
  • selecting resources and strategies, and
  • evaluating outcomes.

 

It emphasizes independence, responsibility, and self-motivation rather than dependence on others.

 

Hence, an individual who practices self-directed learning can independently take initiatives in the learning process.

Question 47
Read the following passage carefully and answer the questions:Self-directed learning, in its broadest meaning, describes a process in which individuals take the initiative with or without the help of others, in diagnosing their learning needs, formulation of learning goals, identifying resources for learning, choosing and implementing learning strategies and evaluating learning outcomes. Thus, it is important to attain new knowledge easily andskillfullyfor the rest of his or her life.What is the need for self-directed learning? One reason is that there is convincing evidence that people, who take the initiative in learning, learn more things and learn better than people waiting to be taught. The second reason is that self-directed learning is more in tune with our natural processes of psychological development; an essential aspect of maturing is developing the ability to take increasing responsibility of our own lives to become increasingly self-directed. The third reason has to do with the new development in education — putting a heavy responsibility on the learners to take a great deal of initiative in their own learning. To meet the challenges in today’s instructive environment, self-directed learning is most essential.Self-directed learning is useful as
  • A.it is an innovative way of learning
  • B.it is full of challenges
  • C.it enables people to learn more things and learn better
  • D.it is cost-effective
Correct Answer: it enables people to learn more things and learn better

According to the passage, one of the main reasons for the importance of self-directed learning is that:

 

“There is convincing evidence that people who take the initiative in learning learn more things and learn better than people waiting to be taught.”

 

Thus, its usefulness lies in improving both the quantity and quality of learning, not necessarily because it is innovative, challenging, or cost-effective.

Question 48
Read the following passage carefully and answer the questions:Self-directed learning, in its broadest meaning, describes a process in which individuals take the initiative with or without the help of others, in diagnosing their learning needs, formulation of learning goals, identifying resources for learning, choosing and implementing learning strategies and evaluating learning outcomes. Thus, it is important to attain new knowledge easily andskillfullyfor the rest of his or her life.What is the need for self-directed learning? One reason is that there is convincing evidence that people, who take the initiative in learning, learn more things and learn better than people waiting to be taught. The second reason is that self-directed learning is more in tune with our natural processes of psychological development; an essential aspect of maturing is developing the ability to take increasing responsibility of our own lives to become increasingly self-directed. The third reason has to do with the new development in education — putting a heavy responsibility on the learners to take a great deal of initiative in their own learning. To meet the challenges in today’s instructive environment, self-directed learning is most essential.Which of the following best describes self-directed learning?
  • A.Out bound learning
  • B.Instructive learning
  • C.Active learning
  • D.Repulsive learning
Correct Answer: Active learning

Self-directed learning involves learners taking charge of their own learning process — identifying goals, selecting resources, implementing strategies, and evaluating outcomes.

 

This approach requires learners to be actively engaged, curious, and responsible for their progress — all key features of active learning.

Question 49
Read the following passage carefully and answer the questions:Self-directed learning, in its broadest meaning, describes a process in which individuals take the initiative with or without the help of others, in diagnosing their learning needs, formulation of learning goals, identifying resources for learning, choosing and implementing learning strategies and evaluating learning outcomes. Thus, it is important to attain new knowledge easily andskillfullyfor the rest of his or her life.What is the need for self-directed learning? One reason is that there is convincing evidence that people, who take the initiative in learning, learn more things and learn better than people waiting to be taught. The second reason is that self-directed learning is more in tune with our natural processes of psychological development; an essential aspect of maturing is developing the ability to take increasing responsibility of our own lives to become increasingly self-directed. The third reason has to do with the new development in education — putting a heavy responsibility on the learners to take a great deal of initiative in their own learning. To meet the challenges in today’s instructive environment, self-directed learning is most essential.According to the author, modern environment is
  • A.restrictive
  • B.not very conducive
  • C.instructive
  • D.impracticable
Correct Answer: instructive

In the passage, the author mentions:

 

“The third reason has to do with the new development in education — putting a heavy responsibility on the learners to take a great deal of initiative in their own learning. To meet the challenges in today’s instructive environment, self-directed learning is most essential.”

 

Hence, the author explicitly describes the modern environment as instructive, meaning it requires learners to take initiative and responsibility for their own learning.

Question 50
Read the following passage carefully and answer the questions:Self-directed learning, in its broadest meaning, describes a process in which individuals take the initiative with or without the help of others, in diagnosing their learning needs, formulation of learning goals, identifying resources for learning, choosing and implementing learning strategies and evaluating learning outcomes. Thus, it is important to attain new knowledge easily andskillfullyfor the rest of his or her life.What is the need for self-directed learning? One reason is that there is convincing evidence that people, who take the initiative in learning, learn more things and learn better than people waiting to be taught. The second reason is that self-directed learning is more in tune with our natural processes of psychological development; an essential aspect of maturing is developing the ability to take increasing responsibility of our own lives to become increasingly self-directed. The third reason has to do with the new development in education — putting a heavy responsibility on the learners to take a great deal of initiative in their own learning. To meet the challenges in today’s instructive environment, self-directed learning is most essential.The synonym of the word ‘diagnosing’ is
  • A.looking for
  • B.identifying
  • C.inspecting
  • D.observing
Correct Answer: identifying

In the passage, the phrase is —

 

“... individuals take the initiative in diagnosing their learning needs...”

 

Here, diagnosing means finding out or identifying what one needs to learn — similar to how a doctor identifies an illness.

 

Other options like looking for, inspecting, or observing do not convey the precise meaning of determining or recognizing the exact nature of something.

Quiz Attempt #119698

Total Questions: 50
Question 1
The following table shows the marks scored by six students (A–F) in different subjects S1 to S5 having 160, 160, 120, 200 and 240 as maximum marks respectively. Based on the data in the table, answer the questions that follow:Student-wise details of Marks ScoredStudentsS1 (Out of 160)S2 (Out of 160)S3 (Out of 120)S4 (Out of 200)S5 (Out of 200)S6 (Out of 240)A76846656154144B1201008476136132C128726470144160D841309684104168E64128909217470F7096605616496What is overall percentage of marks scored by student A in all the subjects together?
  • A.54 %
  • B.56 %
  • C.57 %
  • D.54 %
Correct Answer: 54 %

Required percentage = 5801080×100 ≈ 54%

Question 2
The following table shows the marks scored by six students (A–F) in different subjects S1 to S5 having 160, 160, 120, 200 and 240 as maximum marks respectively. Based on the data in the table, answer the questions that follow:Student-wise details of Marks ScoredStudentsS1 (Out of 160)S2 (Out of 160)S3 (Out of 120)S4 (Out of 200)S5 (Out of 200)S6 (Out of 240)A76846656154144B1201008476136132C128726470144160D841309684104168E64128909217470F7096605616496Whatisthe average marks scored in the subject S5 by all the students together?
  • A.142
  • B.144
  • C.146
  • D.148
Correct Answer: 146

Total marks in S5 = 154 + 136 + 144 + 104 + 174 + 164 = 876

Average = 8766 = 146

Question 3
The following table shows the marks scored by six students (A–F) in different subjects S1 to S5 having 160, 160, 120, 200 and 240 as maximum marks respectively. Based on the data in the table, answer the questions that follow:Student-wise details of Marks ScoredStudentsS1 (Out of 160)S2 (Out of 160)S3 (Out of 120)S4 (Out of 200)S5 (Out of 200)S6 (Out of 240)A76846656154144B1201008476136132C128726470144160D841309684104168E64128909217470F7096605616496What is the ratio of the total marks scored by student B to the total marks scored by student D?
  • A.26 :27
  • B.36 :37
  • C.16 :17
  • D.46 :47
Correct Answer: 36 :37

Total B = 120 + 100 + 84 + 76 + 136 + 132 = 648

Total D = 84 + 130 + 96 + 84 + 104 + 168 = 666

Ratio = 648 : 666 = 36 : 37.

Question 4
The following table shows the marks scored by six students (A–F) in different subjects S1 to S5 having 160, 160, 120, 200 and 240 as maximum marks respectively. Based on the data in the table, answer the questions that follow:Student-wise details of Marks ScoredStudentsS1 (Out of 160)S2 (Out of 160)S3 (Out of 120)S4 (Out of 200)S5 (Out of 200)S6 (Out of 240)A76846656154144B1201008476136132C128726470144160D841309684104168E64128909217470F7096605616496If for getting first division, a student needs to score minimum 60% marks in aggregate, then the number of students getting first division is:
  • A.5
  • B.3
  • C.2
  • D.4

Question 5
The following table shows the marks scored by six students (A–F) in different subjects S1 to S5 having 160, 160, 120, 200 and 240 as maximum marks respectively. Based on the data in the table, answer the questions that follow:Student-wise details of Marks ScoredStudentsS1 (Out of 160)S2 (Out of 160)S3 (Out of 120)S4 (Out of 200)S5 (Out of 200)S6 (Out of 240)A76846656154144B1201008476136132C128726470144160D841309684104168E64128909217470F7096605616496The marks scored by student B and student C together in subject S1 is ______ % more than the marks scored by student A and student D together in the same subject.
  • A.55
  • B.45
  • C.120
  • D.155
Correct Answer: 55

Marks by B and C together

120 + 128 = 248

 

Marks by A and D together

76 + 84 = 160

 

Difference: 248 – 160 = 88

Percentage more = 88160×100 = 55%

Question 6
Which of the following assessment types would require to carry out an activity or produce a product in order to demonstrate learning?
  • A.Formative Assessment
  • B.Portfolio Assessment
  • C.Summative Assessment
  • D.Performance Assessment
Correct Answer: Performance Assessment

Performance assessment requires learners to perform a task, activity, or create a product that demonstrates their knowledge and skills in a real or simulated situation.

Examples include experiments, presentations, role plays, model-making, or portfolios.

 

In contrast: Formative assessment – checks progress during learning.

Summative assessment – evaluates learning at the end of a unit or course.

Portfolio assessment – compiles evidence of learning over time, but not necessarily a single activity-based demonstration.

Question 7
Which of the following is true regarding extrinsic motivation?
  • A.It is based on factors not related to the activity itself.
  • B.It is the natural tendency to seek out personal interest.
  • C.It is the natural tendency to conquer challenges.
  • D.It motivates us to do something when we don’t need to do.
Correct Answer: It is based on factors not related to the activity itself.

Extrinsic motivation refers to engaging in an activity for external rewards or outcomes, not for the inherent enjoyment of the activity itself.

 

Examples include working for money, studying for grades, or competing for recognition.

Question 8
In the light of cognitive domain, arrange the following classroom equations (A–E) in the correct ascending order:A. UnderstandingB. EvaluatingC. AnalysingD. ApplyingE. RememberingChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.E, A, D, C, B
  • B.E, A, C, B, E
  • C.B, A, E, D, C
  • D.C, E, B, A, D
Correct Answer: E, A, D, C, B

According to Bloom’s Taxonomy (Cognitive Domain), the levels of learning progress from lower-order to higher-order thinking skills in this sequence:

 

E. Remembering – Recalling facts and basic concepts.

A. Understanding – Explaining ideas or concepts.

D. Applying – Using information in new situations.

C. Analysing – Breaking information into parts to explore relationships.

B. Evaluating – Making judgments or assessing value based on criteria.

 

Thus, the ascending order is:

E → A → D → C → B.

Question 9
Which of the following are the basic objectives of Affective Domain?A. Showing some new behaviour as a result of experience.B. Acting consistently with the new value.C. Allowing to assimilate things in the environment.D. Showing some definite involvement or commitment.Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A and B Only
  • B.C and D Only
  • C.A, B, C and D
  • D.A and C Only
Correct Answer: A, B, C and D

The Affective Domain (as described by Krathwohl, Bloom, and Masia) focuses on attitudes, values, emotions, and feelings.

 

Its objectives progress through five hierarchical levels — Receiving, Responding, Valuing, Organisation, and Characterisation by Value.

Question 10
Match the List-I with List-IIList-I(Cognitive domain level)A. EvaluationB. SynthesisC. AnalysisD. ApplicationList-II(Suggested verb)I. DefineII. AppraiseIII. DistinguishIV. DemonstrateChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A–II, B–I, C–III, D–IV
  • B.A–II, B–I, C–IV, D–III
  • C.A–III, B–I, C–IV, D–II
  • D.A–I, B–III, C–IV, D–III
Correct Answer: A–II, B–I, C–III, D–IV

 

Cognitive Domain Level (List I)

Meaning / Focus

Appropriate Verb (List II)

A. Evaluation

Making judgments or assessing the value of ideas or materials

II. Appraise

B. Synthesis

Combining elements to form a new structure or pattern

I. Define: (from the given choices, this fits the constructive process comparatively)

C. Analysis

Breaking information into parts and identifying relationships

III. Distinguish

D. Application

Using knowledge or principles in new situations

IV. Demonstrate

 

Thus, the correct matching is:

A–II, B–I, C–III, D–IV.

Question 11
What is Historical Research method?
  • A.It collects facts by understanding the present situation. Sources of information include interviews of experts, surveys etc.
  • B.It collects facts by predicting the future. Sources of information include questionnaires, telephonic interviews etc.
  • C.It collects facts by using the past in different periods. Sources of information include written records, newspapers, diaries, letters, traveller’s accounts, documents etc.
  • D.It collects facts by using common sense and also tries to solve practical problems. Sources of information include surveys and interviews.
Correct Answer: It collects facts by using the past in different periods. Sources of information include written records, newspapers, diaries, letters, traveller’s accounts, documents etc.

The Historical Research Method involves the systematic collection and evaluation of data related to past events to understand causes, effects, and trends.

It relies on authentic sources such as:

 

  • Written records and official documents
  • Newspapers, diaries, letters
  • Traveller’s accounts and archival materials

 

The goal is to interpret past events objectively to gain insights that can help understand the present or guide future decisions.

Question 12
What ismodelingapproach of research design?
  • A.The research problem is represented by a mathematical model. Solutions and conclusions are derived from that model.
  • B.There is no research problem in this approach. Solutions and conclusions are derived from the objectives.
  • C.The research problem is represented in the subjective manner. Solutions and conclusions are derived from the research questions.
  • D.The research problem is represented in the objective manner. Solutions and conclusions are derived from the research methodology.
Correct Answer: The research problem is represented by a mathematical model. Solutions and conclusions are derived from that model.

In the modeling approach of research design, the researcher represents a real-world problem situation through a mathematical or logical model. This model helps in analyzing relationships among variables and deriving possible solutions or predictions.

Question 13
What is a questionnaire?
  • A.It is data analysis instrument.
  • B.It is data collection instrument.
  • C.It is data computing instrument.
  • D.It is the analysis and result finding instrument.
Correct Answer: It is data collection instrument.

A questionnaire is a data collection tool used to gather information from respondents in a structured manner. It consists of a set of written or printed questions (open-ended or close-ended) designed to obtain facts, opinions, or attitudes related to a research problem.

Question 14
Which of the following statements (A–D) most appropriately explains “Research Ethics”?A. It states how to write a research report flawlessly.B. It gives the methodology of researching within social norms.C. It provides a common set of dos and don'ts of conductingan ethical research.D. It protects the rights and welfare of research participants.Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.C and D Only
  • B.A and B Only
  • C.A and C Only
  • D.B and D Only
Correct Answer: C and D Only

Research ethics primarily concern the principles that guide responsible research conduct.

  • It includes a set of dos and don'ts (C) to ensure integrity and fairness,
  • and it protects the rights and welfare of research participants (D).
Question 15
Match the List-I with List-IIList-I(n = number of trials, p = probability of success)A. n = 16, p = 0.8B. n = 21, p = 0.6C. n = 13, p = 0.7D. n = 23, p = 0.4List-II(Mean of Binomial Distribution)I. 9.1II. 9.2III. 12.8IV. 12.6Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A–II, B–IV, C–I, D–III
  • B.A–III, B–IV, C–I, D–II
  • C.A–I, B–III, C–II, D–IV
  • D.A–III, B–I, C–IV, D–II
Correct Answer: A–III, B–IV, C–I, D–II

A. n = 16, p = 0.8 → Mean = 16 × 0.8 = 12.8

B. n = 21, p = 0.6 → Mean = 21 × 0.6 = 12.6

C. n = 13, p = 0.7 → Mean = 13 × 0.7 = 9.1

D. n = 23, p = 0.4 → Mean = 23 × 0.4 = 9.2

Question 16
What among the following is not a communication professional?
  • A.Journalist
  • B.Advertiser
  • C.News-reader
  • D.Smartphone
Correct Answer: Smartphone

Research ethics refers to the moral principles and guidelines that govern how research is planned, conducted, and reported. It ensures honesty, integrity, and respect for participants and society.

 

A smartphone, however, is a communication tool or device, not a professional.

Question 17
What among the following is not a communication technology?
  • A.Smartphone
  • B.Newspaper
  • C.Email
  • D.WhatsApp
Correct Answer: Newspaper

A newspaper is a medium of communication, not a technology itself.

 

Smartphone, Email, and WhatsApp are all communication technologies that rely on digital or electronic systems for transmitting information.

Question 18
What is the correct chronology of release of the following films? (From earliest to the latest)A. AlamAraB.DoBheegaJameenC. Raja Harish ChandraD.Garam HawaE. SholayChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.B, A, C, D, E
  • B.A, B, C, D, E
  • C.D, A, C, B, E
  • D.A, C, B, D, E
Correct Answer: A, C, B, D, E

Raja Harishchandra – 1913

Alam Ara – 1931 (India’s first talkie film)

Do Bigha Zameen – 1953

Garam Hawa – 1973

Sholay – 1975

Question 19
What among the following are the essential requirements of a film script-writing?A. ShootingB. Continuity-MiddleC. Beginning to EndD. EditingE. ResolutionChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.B and C Only
  • B.A and D Only
  • C.A and E Only
  • D.A, C and D Only
Correct Answer: B and C Only

A. Shooting → This happens after script writing (not part of writing).

B. Continuity–Middle → Yes, continuity and structure (middle part) are part of script writing.

C. Beginning to End → Yes, a script must have a complete structure — beginning, middle, and end.

D. Editing → This happens after filming, not during script writing.

E. Resolution → Part of the story structure (ending/resolution).

 

So, the essential requirements in writing a film script are Continuity-Middle (B) and Beginning to End (C).

Question 20
Match the List–I with List–IIList–I(Place)A. New DelhiB. PuneC.NoidaD. LucknowList–II(Institution)I.BhartenduNatyaAkademyII.Asian Academy of Films & TVIII. National Film Archive of IndiaIV. National School of DramaChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A–I, B–II, C–III, D–IV
  • B.A–II, B–IV, C–I, D–III
  • C.A–IV, B–III, C–II, D–I
  • D.A–III, B–II, C–IV, D–I
Correct Answer: A–IV, B–III, C–II, D–I

A. New Delhi → National School of Drama (NSD) → IV

B. Pune → National Film Archive of India (NFAI) → III

C. Noida → Asian Academy of Film & TV (AAFT) → II

D. Lucknow → Bhartendu Natya Akademy → I

Question 21
In the series given below, if every digit is changed with the next number as per the number series and 9 will change to 0, then how many 9’s are there in the new series?4589720009090103478998
  • A.2
  • B.4
  • C.1
  • D.3
Correct Answer: 3

8 is changed to 9. There is total three 8. SO, D is the correct answer.

Question 22
If in a certain code language, “DREAM” is coded as “71692” and “CHILD” is coded as “98547”, then how “LEADER” will be coded in that language?
  • A.130761
  • B.637196
  • C.637936
  • D.894761
Correct Answer: 130761

From “DREAM → 71692”: D=7, R=1, E=6, A=9, M=2

From “CHILD → 98547”: C=9, H=8, I=5, L=4, D=7

So “LEADER” (L E A D E R) → 4 6 9 7 6 1 = 469761.

Question 23
Rohan buys an article at discount of 25%. At what percentage above the cost price should he sell it to make a profit of 25% over the original price?
  • A.68.5
  • B.67.5
  • C.65.5
  • D.66.67
Correct Answer: 66.67

MP = 100

CP for Rohan = 75

Profit = 25%

SP = 125

Percentage increase = 125-7575×100 = 66.67%

Question 24
Which of the following statement(s) is/are true?A. If an athlete runs 200 metres in 24 seconds, then his speed is 30 Km/hr.B. Sixty five percent of a number is 21 less than 4/5 of that number. The number is 150.C. A car is running at a speed of 108 Km/hr. The distance covered by car in 15 seconds is 450 metres.D. Difference between 2 numbers A and B is 1660. If 7.5% of A is 12.5% of B, the value of A & B is 4150 and 2200.Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B and C Only
  • B.B, C and D Only
  • C.A and C Only
  • D.B and D Only
Correct Answer: A and C Only

only A and C are correct.

Question 25
Match the List–I with List–IIList–I(Formula)A. Ifx5=y8, then (x + 5) :(y + 8)= ?B. If (x :y) =2 :1, then(x2-y2) : (x2+y2) = ?C. If (x2+4y2) = 4xy, thenx :y= ?D. IfA :B =3 :5 andB :C =8 :9, thenA :B :C= ?List–II(Answer)I.2 :1II.2 :3III.3 :5IV.5 :8Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A–IV, B–III, C–I, D–II
  • B.A–I, B–II, C–III, D–IV
  • C.A–II, B–III, C–I, D–IV
  • D.A–III, B–IV, C–I, D–II
Correct Answer: A–IV, B–III, C–I, D–II

A. (x + 5) : (y + 8)

Take x = 5k, y = 8k

Then (x + 5) : (y + 8) = (5k + 5) : (8k + 8)

= 5(k + 1) : 8(k + 1)

= 5 : 8

 

B. If x : y = 2 : 1 → x = 2k, y = k

Then

(x² − y²) : (x² + y²) = (4k² − k²) : (4k² + k²) = 3k² : 5k² = 3 : 5

 

C. ² + 4y² = 4xy

Bring all to one side: x² − 4xy + 4y² = 0

This is (x − 2y)² = 0 → x = 2y

So x : y = 2 : 1

 

D. A : B : C = 24 : 40 : 45.

Question 26
Which of the following is logically equivalent to the statement: “Some felines are not lions”?
  • A.Some felines are lions.
  • B.Some non-lions are not felines.
  • C.Some lions are not felines.
  • D.No felines are lions
Correct Answer: Some non-lions are not felines.

The original statement — “Some felines are not lions” — can be rewritten in logical form as:

→ “There exists at least one being that is a feline and not a lion.”

The logical equivalent of an O-type categorical proposition (“Some S are not P”) is its contrapositive form:

→ “Some non-P are not non-S.”

So:

“Some felines are not lions” becomes “Some non-lions are not non-felines.”

Hence, option (B) is logically equivalent to the given statement.

Question 27
Arrange the following in order of decreasing decoration:A. Carbonated drinksB. BeveragesC. Cold DrinksD. LiquidChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.C, A, B, D
  • B.D, A, B, C
  • C.A, C, B, D
  • D.D, B, A, C
Correct Answer: D, B, A, C

The key phrase is “decreasing denotation.”

 

That means we move from broadest (largest class) to most specific (smallest class).

Denotation = the range or number of things a term refers to.

So, “decreasing denotation” = broad → narrow.

 

The hierarchy

D. Liquid → Broadest (includes water, oil, beverages, etc.)

B. Beverages → Narrower (only liquids consumed for refreshment)

A. Carbonated drinks → Still narrower (only fizzy beverages)

C. Cold drinks → Narrowest among given options (a sub-type served chilled)

 

Therefore, in order of decreasing denotation

D → B → A → C

Question 28
“Every person ismortal,therefore it is obvious that someday the human race will disappear from earth.” Identify the logical fallacy committed in the above statement.
  • A.Fallacy of Accident
  • B.Straw man
  • C.Fallacy of Composition
  • D.Fallacy of Division
Correct Answer: Fallacy of Composition

The Fallacy of Composition occurs when a property true of each individual part is incorrectly assumed to be true of the whole group or class.

 

In this case:

The premise “Every person is mortal” is true for individuals.

The conclusion “Therefore, the human race will disappear” assumes that what is true of each person is also true of the entire species (the whole).

 

That’s exactly the Fallacy of Composition.

Question 29
Which of the following propositions are so related that if one of them is true, the other must be false, although they can both be false?(A) All novels are books.(B) Some novels are not books.(C) No novel is book.(D) Some novels are books.Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.B and D Only
  • B.C and D Only
  • C.A and C Only
  • D.A and B Only
Correct Answer: A and C Only

A. “All novels are books.” (A-type)

C. “No novel is book.” (E-type)

 

These are contraries: they cannot both be true, but they can both be false (e.g., if some novels are books and some aren’t, A is false and C is false).

Question 30
Which of the following arguments is fallacious according to Classical Indian School of Logic (Nyaya)?
  • A.Sound is eternal because it is audible.
  • B.Fire is cold because it is a substance.
  • C.All things are non-eternal because they are knowable.
  • D.Wherever there is fire there is smoke.
Correct Answer: Wherever there is fire there is smoke.

This is known as Asiddha Hetu (Unproved or Invalid Middle Term) or more specifically, a Fallacy of Reverse Vyāpti (wrong direction of universal relation).

 

Hence, it’s fallacious according to the Nyāya school.

Question 31
Which of the following is related to network security?
  • A.Firewall
  • B.Worms
  • C.Keyloggers
  • D.Trojan
Correct Answer: Firewall

(B) Worms, (C) Keyloggers, and (D) Trojan are types of malware, i.e., security threats, not security mechanisms.

 

Hence, only Firewall is related to network security protection.

Question 32
Which of the following is not an emerging technology?
  • A.Artificial Intelligence
  • B.Quantum Cryptography
  • C.3-D Holographic Imaging
  • D.Computer based on vacuum tubes
Correct Answer: Computer based on vacuum tubes

Emerging technologies are modern, evolving innovations such as Artificial Intelligence, Quantum Cryptography, and 3-D Holographic Imaging — all represent cutting-edge fields shaping the future.

 

Computers based on vacuum tubes belong to the first generation of computers (1940s–1950s) and are now completely obsolete, not emerging.

Question 33
Which of the following is correct increasing order of frequency of electromagnetic waves?(A) Light waves(B) Microwaves(C) Infrared waves(D) Radio wavesChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.D, B, C, A
  • B.A, B, C, D
  • C.B, A, C, D
  • D.A, D, C, B
Correct Answer: D, B, C, A

Radio waves → Microwaves → Infrared → Light waves.

Question 34
Which of the following statements are correct?A. Adobe Acrobat is an example of proprietary product.B. Microsoft Office is an example of commercial operating system.C. Linux is anopen sourcesoftware.D. Ubuntu is an example of an operating systemE. Firmware is an example of a mobile operating systemChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.D and E Only
  • B.C and D Only
  • C.A, C and E Only
  • D.A, C and D Only
Correct Answer: A, C and D Only

A. Adobe Acrobat → It is a proprietary product (owned by Adobe).

B. Microsoft Office → It is application software, not an operating system.

C. Linux → It is an open-source software.

D. Ubuntu → It is an operating system (based on Linux).

E. Firmware → It is software embedded in hardware, not a mobile OS.

Question 35
Match the List–I with List–IIList–I(Scientist)(A) Tim Berners Lee(B) Fred Cohen(C) Charles Babbage(D) John Von NeumannList–II(Contribution)(I) Computer Architecture(II) Father of modern computer(III) Virus(IV) World Wide WebChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A–IV, B–III, C–I, D–II
  • B.A–III, B–IV, C–I, D–II
  • C.A–IV, B–III, C–I, D–II
  • D.A–III, B–IV, C–II, D–I
Correct Answer: A–IV, B–III, C–I, D–II

A. Tim Berners Lee → (IV) World Wide Web — He invented the World Wide Web.

B. Fred Cohen → (III) Virus — He introduced the concept of computer viruses.

C. Charles Babbage → (II) Father of modern computer — Designed the Analytical Engine.

D. John Von Neumann → (I) Computer Architecture — Developed the Von Neumann architecture used in modern computers.

Question 36
As temperature increases, due to Global Warming, the release of methane from wetlands will increase, is an example of
  • A.Positive feedback
  • B.Negative feedback
  • C.Positive and negative feedback
  • D.Neither positive nor negative feedback
Correct Answer: Positive feedback

As temperature increases due to global warming, more methane (a greenhouse gas) is released from wetlands. This additional methane further increases the greenhouse effect, leading to even higher temperatures. Thus, the original change (warming) is amplified, making it a positive feedback mechanism.

Question 37
Match the LIST–I with LIST–IIList–I(Health-related terms)(A) Toxicology(B) Exposure Assessment(C) Risk Assessment(D) Risk ManagementList–II(Explanation)(I) Action taken to prevent environmental health hazard(II) Evaluation of the possible risk of a hazard(III) Science of effect of toxic substances(IV) Estimation of impacts of environmental contaminants on humansChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A–III, B–IV, C–II, D–I
  • B.A–III, B–IV, C–I, D–II
  • C.A–I, B–II, C–III, D–IV
  • D.A–II, B–III, C–IV, D–I
Correct Answer: A–III, B–IV, C–II, D–I

A. Toxicology → (III) Science of the effects of toxic substances.

B. Exposure Assessment → (IV) Estimation of impacts of environmental contaminants on humans.

C. Risk Assessment → (II) Evaluation of the possible risk of a hazard.

D. Risk Management → (I) Action taken to prevent environmental health hazards.

Question 38
Which of the following are body waves generated during an earthquake?(A) P–wave(B) S–wave(C)Lovewave(D) Raleigh waveChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A and B only
  • B.A, B and C only
  • C.B, C and D only
  • D.C and D only
Correct Answer: A and B only

P–wave (Primary wave) and S–wave (Secondary wave) are body waves, because they travel through the interior (body) of the Earth during an earthquake.

 

Love wave and Rayleigh wave are surface waves, as they travel along the Earth’s surface and cause most of the earthquake damage.

Question 39
Match the LIST–I with LIST–IIList–I(International Protocols/Conventions)(A) International Solar Alliance(B) Convention on Biodiversity(C) National Action Plan on Climate Change(D) Kyoto ProtocolList–II(Year of Adoption/Agreement)(I) 1997(II) 2015(III) 1992(IV) 2008Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A–III, B–II, C–IV, D–I
  • B.A–II, B–III, C–IV, D–I
  • C.A–II, B–III, C–I, D–IV
  • D.A–III, B–I, C–II, D–IV
Correct Answer: A–II, B–III, C–IV, D–I

A. International Solar Alliance → (II) 2015 — Launched in 2015 during the Paris Climate Conference (COP-21).

B. Convention on Biodiversity → (III) 1992 — Adopted at the Rio Earth Summit in 1992.

C. National Action Plan on Climate Change → (IV) 2008 — Announced by the Government of India in 2008.

D. Kyoto Protocol → (I) 1997 — Adopted in 1997 to set binding emission reduction targets for developed nations.

Question 40
Which of the following components of Electromagnetic Radiation reach earth as a part of solar radiation?A.Gamma RaysB.X–RaysC.Ultraviolet RadiationD.Visible RaysE. Infrared RadiationChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B and C only
  • B.C, D and E only
  • C.A, B, D and E only
  • D.A, B, C, D and E
Correct Answer: C, D and E only

Most Gamma rays and X-rays are absorbed by the Earth's atmosphere and do not reach the surface.

 

However, Ultraviolet (UV) radiation, Visible light, and Infrared radiation do reach the Earth as part of solar radiation.

Question 41
The sustainable Development Goal which covers lifelong learning is _______
  • A.Good Health and Well-being
  • B.Quality of Education
  • C.Gender Equality
  • D.Zero Hunger
Correct Answer: Quality of Education

Sustainable Development Goal 4 (SDG 4) focuses on Quality Education and explicitly includes the objective to “ensure inclusive and equitable quality education and promote lifelong learning opportunities for all.”

Question 42
HRAFLE stands for _______
  • A.Independent Regulatory Authority for Higher Education
  • B.Institutional Regulatory Authority for Higher Education
  • C.Internal Regulatory Authority for Higher Education
  • D.Intra–University Regulatory Authority for Higher Education
Correct Answer: Independent Regulatory Authority for Higher Education

HRAFLE stands for Higher Education Regulatory Authority for Learning and Evaluation, conceptualized as an Independent Regulatory Authority for Higher Education under the recommendations of the National Education Policy (NEP) 2020. Its purpose is to ensure autonomy, transparency, and quality in higher education regulation in India.

Question 43
Arrange the following Commissions and organizations chronologically according to their year of establishment:A.University Grants CommissionB.University Education CommissionC.All India Council of Technical EducationD.Education CommissionChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B, C, D
  • B.C, B, A, D
  • C.B, C, A, D
  • D.D, A, B, C
Correct Answer: C, B, A, D

C. AICTE – Initially set up in 1945 (All India Council for Technical Education)

B. University Education Commission – 1948–49 (Radhakrishnan Commission)

A. UGC – 1956 (University Grants Commission)

D. Education Commission – 1964–66 (Kothari Commission)

Question 44
In higher education, regulators perform the following functions –(A) Permission to grant degrees(B) Accreditation of faculty(C) Developing quality standards(D) Quality enhancementChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B and C only
  • B.D only
  • C.A, C and D only
  • D.A, B, C and D
Correct Answer: A, C and D only

In higher education, regulators such as UGC, AICTE, NCTE, and NAAC perform key functions like:

(A) Granting permission to award degrees (UGC’s role)

(C) Developing quality standards for institutions and programs

(D) Enhancing quality through monitoring, evaluation, and reforms

Question 45
Match the LIST–I with LIST–IIList–I(Types of Education)(A) Social Value Education(B) Spiritual Value Education(C) Cultural Value Education(D) Universal Value EducationList–II(I) Aware of the diversity, ideals and norms of the society(II) People realize heavy common values applicable to mankind(III) Make people better and more responsible citizens(IV) To keep mutual calm and awakeningChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A–I, B–II, C–III, D–IV
  • B.A–II, B–I, C–IV, D–III
  • C.A–IV, B–III, C–II, D–I
  • D.A–III, B–IV, C–I, D–II
Correct Answer: A–III, B–IV, C–I, D–II

A. Social Value Education → (III) Makes people better and more responsible citizens.

 

B. Spiritual Value Education → (IV) Helps to keep mutual calm and awakening.

 

C. Cultural Value Education → (I) Makes people aware of the diversity, ideals, and norms of society.

 

D. Universal Value Education → (II) Emphasizes common values applicable to all humankind.

Question 46
Read the following passage carefully and answer the questions:Does more education lead to greater democracy? Or are more democratic countries better at educating their citizens? A recent NBER paper compared a group of Kenyan girls in 69 primary schools whose students were randomly selected to receive a scholarship with similar students in schools which received no such financial aid. Previous studies had shown that the scholarship programme led to higher test scores and increased the likelihood that girls enrolled in secondary school.Overall, it significantly increased the amount of education obtained. For the new study the authors tried to see how the extra schooling had affected the political and social attitudes of the women in question. Findings suggested that education may make people more interested in improving their own lives but they may not necessarily see democracy as the way to do it.Even in established democracies, more education does not always mean either more active political participation or greater faith in democracy. Poorer and less educated people often vote in larger numbers than their more educated compatriots, who often express disdain for the messiness of democracy yearning for the kind of government that would deal strongly with the corrupt and build highways, railway lines and bridges at a dizzying pace of authoritarian China.The NBER paper selected girl-students as sample through _______ sampling technique.
  • A.Purposive
  • B.Snowball
  • C.Quota
  • D.Random
Correct Answer: Random

The question mentions that students were randomly selected to receive a scholarship among 69 primary schools. This clearly indicates the use of a random sampling technique.

 

In this method, each participant has an equal chance of being selected, ensuring that the sample is unbiased and representative of the population.

 

Hence, the NBER paper used random sampling for selecting girl students.

Question 47
Read the following passage carefully and answer the questions:Does more education lead to greater democracy? Or are more democratic countries better at educating their citizens? A recent NBER paper compared a group of Kenyan girls in 69 primary schools whose students were randomly selected to receive a scholarship with similar students in schools which received no such financial aid. Previous studies had shown that the scholarship programme led to higher test scores and increased the likelihood that girls enrolled in secondary school.Overall, it significantly increased the amount of education obtained. For the new study the authors tried to see how the extra schooling had affected the political and social attitudes of the women in question. Findings suggested that education may make people more interested in improving their own lives but they may not necessarily see democracy as the way to do it.Even in established democracies, more education does not always mean either more active political participation or greater faith in democracy. Poorer and less educated people often vote in larger numbers than their more educated compatriots, who often express disdain for the messiness of democracy yearning for the kind of government that would deal strongly with the corrupt and build highways, railway lines and bridges at a dizzying pace of authoritarian China.According to previous study, what lead to higher test scores among girl students?
  • A.Remedial classes
  • B.Parental encouragement
  • C.Scholarship programme
  • D.Counselling session
Correct Answer: Scholarship programme

According to the passage, previous studies had shown that the scholarship programme led to higher test scores and increased the likelihood that girls enrolled in secondary school. Thus, it was the scholarship programme that improved academic performance among the girl students.

Question 48
Read the following passage carefully and answer the questions:Does more education lead to greater democracy? Or are more democratic countries better at educating their citizens? A recent NBER paper compared a group of Kenyan girls in 69 primary schools whose students were randomly selected to receive a scholarship with similar students in schools which received no such financial aid. Previous studies had shown that the scholarship programme led to higher test scores and increased the likelihood that girls enrolled in secondary school.Overall, it significantly increased the amount of education obtained. For the new study the authors tried to see how the extra schooling had affected the political and social attitudes of the women in question. Findings suggested that education may make people more interested in improving their own lives but they may not necessarily see democracy as the way to do it.Even in established democracies, more education does not always mean either more active political participation or greater faith in democracy. Poorer and less educated people often vote in larger numbers than their more educated compatriots, who often express disdain for the messiness of democracy yearning for the kind of government that would deal strongly with the corrupt and build highways, railway lines and bridges at a dizzying pace of authoritarian China.The finding of the new study suggested that education may make people more interested in _______
  • A.Taking active part in politics
  • B.Improving their own lives
  • C.Supporting social causes
  • D.Getting selected in jobs
Correct Answer: Improving their own lives

According to the passage, the new study found that education may make people more interested in improving their own lives, but they may not necessarily see democracy as the way to do it.

Question 49
Read the following passage carefully and answer the questions:Does more education lead to greater democracy? Or are more democratic countries better at educating their citizens? A recent NBER paper compared a group of Kenyan girls in 69 primary schools whose students were randomly selected to receive a scholarship with similar students in schools which received no such financial aid. Previous studies had shown that the scholarship programme led to higher test scores and increased the likelihood that girls enrolled in secondary school.Overall, it significantly increased the amount of education obtained. For the new study the authors tried to see how the extra schooling had affected the political and social attitudes of the women in question. Findings suggested that education may make people more interested in improving their own lives but they may not necessarily see democracy as the way to do it.Even in established democracies, more education does not always mean either more active political participation or greater faith in democracy. Poorer and less educated people often vote in larger numbers than their more educated compatriots, who often express disdain for the messiness of democracy yearning for the kind of government that would deal strongly with the corrupt and build highways, railway lines and bridges at a dizzying pace of authoritarian China.The phrase “tendencies of democracy” used in the passage is referred to _______
  • A.Educated citizens participating less in society
  • B.Educated citizens showing concern for public representation of people
  • C.More educated are now interested in increasing inequality
  • D.Educated citizens do not vote in the elections
Correct Answer: Educated citizens participating less in society

The “tendencies of democracy” refer to the ideals of public participation, representation, and collective decision-making. The passage contrasts this by noting that more educated citizens are not necessarily more active in democratic processes, implying that true democratic tendencies involve concern for and participation in public representation.

Question 50
Read the following passage carefully and answer the questions:Does more education lead to greater democracy? Or are more democratic countries better at educating their citizens? A recent NBER paper compared a group of Kenyan girls in 69 primary schools whose students were randomly selected to receive a scholarship with similar students in schools which received no such financial aid. Previous studies had shown that the scholarship programme led to higher test scores and increased the likelihood that girls enrolled in secondary school.Overall, it significantly increased the amount of education obtained. For the new study the authors tried to see how the extra schooling had affected the political and social attitudes of the women in question. Findings suggested that education may make people more interested in improving their own lives but they may not necessarily see democracy as the way to do it.Even in established democracies, more education does not always mean either more active political participation or greater faith in democracy. Poorer and less educated people often vote in larger numbers than their more educated compatriots, who often express disdain for the messiness of democracy yearning for the kind of government that would deal strongly with the corrupt and build highways, railway lines and bridges at a dizzying pace of authoritarian China.Which of the following is true about China in the context of the passage?
  • A.China’s citizens want a more representative form of government
  • B.China has made high strides in infrastructure development
  • C.China passes through a great political transformation
  • D.Based on the progress it has made, China will not entertain any kind of political reform
Correct Answer: China has made high strides in infrastructure development

The passage mentions that educated citizens in democracies sometimes “yearn for the kind of government that would deal strongly with the corrupt and build highways, railway lines and bridges at a dizzying pace of authoritarian China.”

 

This clearly highlights China’s rapid infrastructure development under an authoritarian regime.

Quiz Attempt #119699

Total Questions: 50
Question 1
Study the data carefully and answer thequestions :The given data is regarding the number of paperback and hardbound books sold by four different books shops A, B, C andD :ShopsNumber of Hardbound books soldNumber of Paperback books soldA35002000B39005200C44005500D55006600Number of total books (hardbound and paperback together) sold by the highest selling shop is what percent higher than the lowest selling shop?
  • A.50%
  • B.60%
  • C.120%
  • D.150%
Correct Answer: 120%

 

Shops

Number of Hardbound books sold

Number of Paperback books sold

Total

A

3500

2000

5500

B

3900

5200

9100

C

4400

5500

9900

D

5500

6600

12100

Required % = 12100-55005500 × 100 = 120%

Question 2
Study the data carefully and answer thequestions :The given data is regarding the number of paperback and hardbound books sold by four different books shops A, B, C andD :ShopsNumber of Hardbound books soldNumber of Paperback books soldA35002000B39005200C44005500D55006600Number of hardbound books sold by shop A is approximately what percent less than the number of paperback books sold by shop C?
  • A.32
  • B.36
  • C.38
  • D.42
Correct Answer: 36

Required percentage = 5500-35005500×100 = 36%

Question 3
Study the data carefully and answer thequestions :The given data is regarding the number of paperback and hardbound books sold by four different books shops A, B, C andD :ShopsNumber of Hardbound books soldNumber of Paperback books soldA35002000B39005200C44005500D55006600What is the ratio between total number of hardbound books sold by shop C and D together and number of paperback books sold by shop D?
  • A.2 :1
  • B.5 :4
  • C.3 :2
  • D.9 :7
Correct Answer: 3 :2

Required ratio = (4400 + 5500) : (6600)

= 99 : 66

= 3 : 2

Question 4
Study the data carefully and answer thequestions :The given data is regarding the number of paperback and hardbound books sold by four different books shops A, B, C andD :ShopsNumber of Hardbound books soldNumber of Paperback books soldA35002000B39005200C44005500D55006600What is the ratio between total sale by shops A and C together to the total sale by shops B and D?
  • A.77 :106
  • B.73 :102
  • C.17 :33
  • D.21 :27
Correct Answer: 77 :106

 

Shops

Number of Hardbound books sold

Number of Paperback books sold

Total

A

3500

2000

5500

B

3900

5200

9100

C

4400

5500

9900

D

5500

6600

12100

 

Required ratio = (5500 + 9900) : (9100 + 12100)

= 154 : 212

= 77 : 106.

Question 5
Study the data carefully and answer thequestions :The given data is regarding the number of paperback and hardbound books sold by four different books shops A, B, C andD :ShopsNumber of Hardbound books soldNumber of Paperback books soldA35002000B39005200C44005500D55006600What is the difference between the average number of hardbound books sold by shops A, B and D and the average number ofpaper backbooks sold by shops C and D?
  • A.267
  • B.400
  • C.1570
  • D.1750
Correct Answer: 1750

Required difference = 5500+66002-3500+3900+55003

= 6050 – 4300

= 1750.

Question 6
Which of the following statement is false in the context of research?
  • A.Inductive and deductive reasoning are applied in the research process.
  • B.Verifiable findings are derived by the research process.
  • C.Research is conducted to find answers of meaningful questions scientifically.
  • D.It necessarily improves quality of functioning of the area in which it is conducted.
Correct Answer: It necessarily improves quality of functioning of the area in which it is conducted.

Research aims to generate new knowledge, insights, or understanding through systematic and scientific inquiry. However, it does not necessarily guarantee improvement in the functioning or performance of the area studied. The findings may or may not lead to immediate or direct practical improvements — their main purpose is to expand knowledge and understanding.

Question 7
Select correct order of finalizing a research problem:A. Defining the research problemB. Selecting the area of researchC. Finding the research gapD. Study of reference material and reports of previous researchesE. Identifying a research problemChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.B, C, D, A, E
  • B.D, B, C, E, A
  • C.B, D, C, E, A
  • D.D, B, A, C, E
Correct Answer: B, D, C, E, A

The logical order of finalizing a research problem is:

 

B. Selecting the area of research – First, a broad field or domain of interest is chosen.

D. Study of reference material and reports of previous researches – Review of existing literature to understand what has already been done.

C. Finding the research gap – Identifying areas that have not been explored or need further investigation.

E. Identifying a research problem – Narrowing down to a specific issue or question that needs to be addressed.

A. Defining the research problem – Clearly stating and framing the problem in precise and researchable terms.

Question 8
Which are the characteristics of research?A. It always aims to develop new theory.B. It has scientific process.C. Logical reasoning is used in decision making during research process.D. Hypothetical testing is done in every kind of research.E. It collects and analyses evidences to derive findings.Choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.B, C and D Only
  • B.A, B and C Only
  • C.B, C and E Only
  • D.C, D and E Only
Correct Answer: B, C and E Only

A. It always aims to develop new theory → Not always. Some research validates existing theories or applies them in new contexts.

 

B. It has scientific process → Research follows systematic and scientific steps.

 

C. Logical reasoning is used in decision making during research process → Both inductive and deductive reasoning are essential in research.

 

D. Hypothetical testing is done in every kind of research → Not in every research. Descriptive or exploratory research may not involve hypothesis testing.

 

E. It collects and analyses evidences to derive findings → Evidence-based analysis is a core feature of research.

 

Hence, B, C, and E are correct characteristics.

Question 9
In which conditions, Karl Pearson’s correlation coefficient can be calculated?A. If means of both the variables are equalB. If one variable is measured in interval scale and another is measured in ordinal scaleC. If there is linear relationship between two variablesD. If data are obtained in interval or ratio scale for both the variablesE. If direction of relationship between two variables is knownChoose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.C and D Only
  • B.C, D and E Only
  • C.B, D and E Only
  • D.A, C and E Only
Correct Answer: C and D Only

Karl Pearson’s correlation coefficient measures the degree and direction of a linear relationship between two continuous variables.

 

It is calculated under the following conditions:

C. If there is a linear relationship between two variables → Required condition.

D. If data are obtained in interval or ratio scale for both the variables → Pearson’s r requires numerical data with equal intervals.

Question 10
Match the List–I with List–IIList–I (Context of Research)(A) Researcher continuesdata collection and analysis till the satisfactory findings are derived(B) Study of changein emotional maturity of the students with passage of time(C) Study of the effect of one variable onothervariable in controlled situation(D) Study of social problems faced by working womenList–II (Method)(I) Survey(II) Experimental(III) Developmental(IV) Grounded theoryChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A–IV, B–III, C–I, D–II
  • B.A–III, B–IV, C–II, D–I
  • C.A–IV, B–III, C–II, D–I
  • D.A–III, B–IV, C–I, D–II
Correct Answer: A–IV, B–III, C–II, D–I

(A) Researcher continues data collection and analysis till the satisfactory findings are derived → (IV) Grounded Theory

In grounded theory, data collection and analysis occur simultaneously until theoretical saturation is reached.

 

(B) Study of change in emotional maturity of the students with passage of time → (III) Developmental

Developmental studies observe changes or growth over time.

 

(C) Study of the effect of one variable on another in a controlled situation → (II) Experimental

Experimental method manipulates one variable to study its impact on another.

 

(D) Study of social problems faced by working women → (I) Survey

Survey method is used to collect data from a group of people about social issues or opinions.

Question 11
Under which section of the UGC Act, Inter-University Centres (IUCs) were established?
  • A.12 (ccc)
  • B.12 (B)
  • C.12 (a)
  • D.12 (h)
Correct Answer: 12 (ccc)

Under section 12(ccc) of the University Grants Commission Act, the UGC is empowered to “establish … institutions for providing common facilities, services and programmes for a group of universities or for the universities in general” — which is the legal provision used for setting up the Inter‑University Centres (IUCs).

Question 12
The Rigveda comprises _______ hymns.
  • A.1028
  • B.10600
  • C.1064
  • D.11300
Correct Answer: 1028

The Rigveda is the oldest of the four Vedas and consists of 1,028 hymns (Suktas) divided into 10 Mandalas (books).

 

These hymns are composed in praise of various deities like Agni, Indra, Varuna, and Soma, reflecting early Vedic religious life and philosophy.

Question 13
Arrange chronologically the establishment of given digital initiatives:A. National Digital Library (N.D.L.)B.ShodhgangaC. Academic Bank of Credit (A.B.C.)D. DikshaChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.C, D, B, A
  • B.D, B, C, A
  • C.B, D, A, C
  • D.B, C, A, D
Correct Answer: B, D, A, C

Shodhganga — around

DIKSHA — launched on 5 September 2017.

National Digital Library (NDLI) — formally launched 19 June 2018.

Academic Bank of Credit (ABC) — initiated in July 2021.

Question 14
Major thrusts of National Policy on Education (NPE), 1986, were:A. State level planning and coordination through state council for higher educationB. Expansion of open universities and distance education systemC. Establishment of National Assessment Centre PARAKHD. Conferring autonomous status on selected collegesE. Establishment of two multidisciplinary education and research universities (MERU) in each stateChoose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, C and D Only
  • B.C, D and E Only
  • C.A, B and D Only
  • D.B, C, D and E Only
Correct Answer: A, B and D Only

The National Policy on Education (NPE), 1986 emphasized several reforms to strengthen higher education in India.

 

A. State level planning and coordination through state council for higher education → True. NPE 1986 recommended setting up State Councils of Higher Education for coordination and planning at the state level.

 

B. Expansion of open universities and distance education system → True. The policy stressed open learning and distance education to increase access to higher education.

 

C. Establishment of National Assessment Centre PARAKH → False. PARAKH was proposed under NEP 2020, not NPE 1986.

 

D. Conferring autonomous status on selected colleges → True. NPE 1986 promoted autonomy of colleges and universities to enhance academic freedom and quality.

 

E. Establishment of two multidisciplinary education and research universities (MERU) in each state → False. This was also proposed under NEP 2020, not NPE 1986.

Question 15
Match the List–I with List–IIList–I (Institutions of National Importance (INI) Acts)(A) National Institute of Technology Act(B) Indian Institute of Management Act(C) Indian Institutes of Information Technology Act(D) Institutes of Technology ActList–II (Year of Enactment)(I) 2017(II) 1961(III) 2007(IV) 2014Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A–III, B–I, C–IV, D–II
  • B.A–II, B–III, C–IV, D–I
  • C.A–IV, B–I, C–II, D–III
  • D.A–II, B–IV, C–I, D–III
Correct Answer: A–III, B–I, C–IV, D–II

List–I (Institutions)

Year (List–II)

(A) National Institute of Technology Act

(III) 2007

(B) Indian Institute of Management Act

(I) 2017

(C) Indian Institutes of Information Technology Act

(IV) 2014

(D) Institutes of Technology Act

(II) 1961

 

Question 16
What is the full form of ARPANET?
  • A.Advanced Research Project Agency Network
  • B.Advanced Resource Project Agency Network
  • C.Applied Research Project Agency Network
  • D.American Research Project Agency Network
Correct Answer: Advanced Research Project Agency Network

ARPANET stands for Advanced Research Projects Agency Network.

It was developed in the late 1960s by the U.S. Department of Defense’s ARPA (now DARPA) and is considered the precursor to the modern Internet, as it was the first network to implement the TCP/IP protocol suite for data communication between computers.

Question 17
Which of the following is not an element of communication within the communication process cycle?
  • A.Channel
  • B.Receiver
  • C.Sender
  • D.Time
Correct Answer: Time

The communication process cycle consists of key elements such as —

 

  • Sender (initiates the message),
  • Message,
  • Channel (medium used for transmission),
  • Receiver, and
  • Feedback (response from receiver).

 

While time may influence communication effectiveness, it is not considered a formal element of the communication process model.

Question 18
Arrange the following steps in model of listening in sequence:A. InterpretingB. RespondingC. RememberingD. HearingE. UnderstandingChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.E, C, A, B, D
  • B.D, E, C, A, B
  • C.D, A, B, C, E
  • D.A, B, D, E, C
Correct Answer: D, E, C, A, B

The sequence of steps in the listening process follows a logical order from receiving sound to responding meaningfully:

 

D. Hearing – The physical act of receiving sound waves through the ears.

E. Understanding – Comprehending the meaning of what is heard.

C. Remembering – Retaining the information for future use.

A. Interpreting – Assigning meaning, considering context and emotions.

B. Responding – Giving feedback or reaction to the message.

 

Hence, the correct order is D → E → C → A → B.

Question 19
What are the factors to be considered while selecting a communication media?A. No need to think about receiverB. ReliabilityC. It should be costlyD. ConfidentialityE. AvailabilityChoose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B and C Only
  • B.B, C and D Only
  • C.C, D and E Only
  • D.B, D and E Only
Correct Answer: B, D and E Only

While selecting an appropriate communication medium, the following factors are important:

 

B. Reliability → The medium should ensure accurate and dependable message delivery.

D. Confidentiality → Sensitive or private information must remain secure during communication.

E. Availability → The medium must be accessible and usable by both sender and receiver.

Question 20
Match List – I with List – II:List – IA. The source is not visible to the receiver because of Geographical distanceB. The people are having individual differences, motivation and attitude and anxiety and prejudiceC. With faulty expression, poor translation, ambiguous wordsD. With poor quality of audio and video signals, the message may not be sent to target groupList – III. Technical Barriers to CommunicationII. Linguistic Barriers to CommunicationIII. Psychological Barriers to CommunicationIV. Physical Barriers to CommunicationChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A–IV, B–III, C–II, D–I
  • B.A–IV, B–I, C–III, D–II
  • C.A–II, B–I, C–IV, D–III
  • D.A–III, B–II, C–I, D–IV
Correct Answer: A–IV, B–III, C–II, D–I

 

List–I (Barrier Description)

Matching Type

Reason

A. The source is not visible to the receiver because of geographical distance

IV. Physical Barrier

Physical or environmental barriers arise due to distance, noise, or poor infrastructure.

B. The people are having individual differences, motivation, attitude, anxiety and prejudice

III. Psychological Barrier

Psychological factors like emotions, attitudes, and perceptions hinder communication.

C. Faulty expression, poor translation, ambiguous words

II. Linguistic Barrier

Language-related problems or unclear wording create linguistic barriers.

D. Poor quality of audio and video signals affects message transmission

I. Technical Barrier

Technical failures or device limitations obstruct communication.

 

Question 21
What is the sum of the first 15 terms of the following series?2², 3², 4², 5², ………
  • A.1261
  • B.1240
  • C.1239
  • D.1495
Correct Answer: 1495

2² + 3² + 4² + 5²+ ……… = 12 + 2² + 3² + 4² + 5² + ………+ 162 – 1

Sum of squares of first n natural numbers = n(n+1)(2n+1)6

Sum = 16(16+1)(32+1)6 – 1 = 1496 – 1 = 1495

Question 22
A sum of Rs. 10,000 is invested for a term of 2½ years at an interest rate of 8% compounded annually.The amount on maturity will be:
  • A.Rs. 12520.50
  • B.Rs. 12024.62
  • C.Rs. 12130.56
  • D.Rs. 11664.48
Correct Answer: Rs. 12130.56

Since compounding is annual, interest for half year is simple interest on the amount after 2 years.

Amount after 2 years = 10000 (1.08)2 = 11664

SI for 0.5 years = 11664×0.5×8100 = 466.56

Amount = 11664 + 466.56 = 12130.56.

Question 23
Arrange the areas for following shapes in descending order of their values:A. The area of the curved surface of a cylindrical wire of radius 1.0 mm and length 3.5 cmB. The surface of a spherical ball of radius 3.5 mmC. The area of a rhombus having diagonals 1.5 cm and 1.8 cmD. The area of a circle of diameter 7.0 mmChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.D, B, C, A
  • B.A, B, C, D
  • C.B, A, C, D
  • D.C, A, B, D
Correct Answer: A, B, C, D

A. Area = 2πrh = 2 × 227 × 110 × 3.5 = 2.2 cm2

B. Area = 4πr2 = 4 × 227 × (0.35)2 = 1.54 cm2

C. Area = 12 × d1 × d2 = 12 × 1.5 × 1.8 = 1.35 cm2

D. Area = πr2 = 227 × (0.35)2 = 0.385 cm2

Thus, the correct order is A, B, C, D.

Question 24
Identify the correct statement:A. If2x=2562; then x =152B. ⅓ of 50% of 150 is greater than576C. In the merit list of an examination result, the rank of a student is 5th from the top among 20 students. His rank from the bottom of the list is at 15th position.D. In a class of 30 students, the average of weights of 20 students is 45 kg and the rest of students have an average weight of 40 kg. The average weight of the class is 42.5 kg.Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B and C Only
  • B.B, C and D Only
  • C.A, B and D Only
  • D.A and B Only
Correct Answer: A and B Only

A. 2x = 2562

or 2x = 282

or 2x = 215/2

or x = 152

 

B. ⅓ of 50% of 150 = 25 > 576

 

C. From bottom his rank will be 16th

 

D. Average weight of class = 20×45+10×4030 = 130030 ≠ 42.5

Thus, only A and B are correct.

Question 25
Match List – I with List – IIList – IA. The numerator of a fraction is increased by 25% and the denominator is increased by 50%, leading to a value of 5/3. The original fraction is ________.B.413– 312= ________.C. The fraction equivalent to 40% is ________.D.0.064(3.25×3.20-3.20×3.05)= ________.List – III.110II.25III.56IV. 2Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A–II, B–III, C–IV, D–I
  • B.A–III, B–II, C–IV, D–I
  • C.A–IV, B–III, C–I, D–II
  • D.A–IV, B–III, C–II, D–I
Correct Answer: A–IV, B–III, C–II, D–I

A. let original fraction = xy

Now, 1.25x1.5y = 53

or xy = 5×1.53×1.25 = 7.53.75 = 2

 

B. 413 – 312 = 133 - 72 = 56

 

C. 40% = 40100 = 25

 

D. 0.064(3.25 × 3.20 - 3.20 × 3.05) = 110

Question 26
Vyapti in Indian Logic refers to:
  • A.Logical contradiction
  • B.Direct perception
  • C.Invariable concomitance
  • D.Verbal testimony
Correct Answer: Invariable concomitance

In Indian Logic (Nyaya Philosophy), Vyapti refers to the invariable and universal relation between the hetu (reason) and the sadhya (probandum).

 

It means that wherever the reason is present, the probandum is also present — there is a constant and inseparable connection between them.

Question 27
In a categorical proposition, the subject and predicate are connected by:
  • A.A question
  • B.A fallacy
  • C.A copula
  • D.A mood
Correct Answer: A copula

In a categorical proposition, the subject and predicate are linked by a copula, which expresses the relation of affirmation or denial between them.

 

All birds are animals.

Here: Subject = birds

Predicate = animals

Copula = are (it connects subject and predicate)

 

So, the copula is the word (usually is, are, was, were, etc.) that shows whether the subject is affirmed or denied of the predicate.

Question 28
Arrange the steps of evaluating a deductive argument:A. Assess the truth of premisesB. Identify premises and conclusionC. Test logical structureD. Determine soundnessChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B, C, D
  • B.A, C, B, D
  • C.B, C, A, D
  • D.D, B, A, C
Correct Answer: B, C, A, D

The logical order of evaluating a deductive argument is:

 

B. Identify premises and conclusion – First, recognize what statements serve as premises and what serves as the conclusion.

C. Test logical structure – Next, check whether the argument is logically valid (i.e., whether the conclusion follows necessarily from the premises).

A. Assess the truth of premises – Then, verify whether the premises themselves are factually true.

D. Determine soundness – Finally, decide if the argument is sound, meaning both valid and with true premises.

Question 29
Which of the following are considered as fallacies of relevance?A. Ad hominemB. False causeC. Straw manD. Red herringChoose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.A and D Only
  • B.B and C Only
  • C.A, C and D Only
  • D.A, B and C Only
Correct Answer: A, C and D Only

Fallacies of relevance occur when the premises or arguments are not logically relevant to the conclusion — they distract attention from the real issue.

 

A. Ad hominem → Attacking the person instead of addressing the argument.

 

B. False cause → This is a fallacy of weak induction (not relevance); it assumes a causal link without proof.

 

C. Straw man → Misrepresenting someone’s argument to make it easier to attack.

 

D. Red herring → Diverting attention from the main issue by introducing an irrelevant topic.

Question 30
Match List – I with List – IIList – IA.AsiddhaB.BadhitaC.ViruddhaD.SavyabhicharraList – III. Irrelevant middle termII. Unproven middle termIII. Contrary middle termIV. Contradicted middle termChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A–I, B–II, C–III, D–IV
  • B.A–II, B–IV, C–III, D–I
  • C.A–II, B–III, C–I, D–IV
  • D.A–III, B–IV, C–II, D–I
Correct Answer: A–II, B–IV, C–III, D–I

These terms refer to hetvabhasas (fallacies of inference) in Indian logic (Nyaya system) — all related to defects in the middle term (hetu).

 

List–I (Fallacy)

Meaning

List–II (Match)

A. Asiddha

The middle term is unproven or not established in the subject.

II – Unproven middle term

B. Badhita

The middle term is contradicted by direct perception or stronger evidence.

IV – Contradicted middle term

C. Viruddha

The middle term leads to an opposite (contrary) conclusion.

III – Contrary middle term

D. Savyabhichara

The middle term is irrelevant because it is not invariably connected to the predicate (deviates).

I – Irrelevant middle term

 

Question 31
To experience the educational value, one must extract its net meaning through:
  • A.Reflections
  • B.Communication
  • C.Consequences
  • D.Decisions
Correct Answer: Reflections

In the philosophy of education—especially as emphasized by John Dewey—the educational value of an experience is realized only when a learner reflects upon it. Reflection helps in drawing meaning, connecting experience with prior knowledge, and guiding future actions.

 

Thus, to truly experience the educational value of any learning activity, one must extract its net meaning through reflection.

Question 32
The study of how the mind creates knowledge has resulted in what are currently referred to as ________ view of Education.
  • A.Pragmatic
  • B.Idealistic
  • C.Metacognitive
  • D.Constructive
Correct Answer: Constructive

The study of how the mind creates knowledge led to the development of the constructivist view of education.

 

According to constructivism, learners actively construct their own understanding and knowledge of the world through experiences and reflection, rather than merely absorbing information.

This approach emphasizes active learning, problem-solving, and connecting new information with prior understanding.

 

Hence, the correct answer is Constructive view of Education.

Question 33
Arrange the following in sequence as they are introduced in increasing order of age of the students:A. Taxonomy of Educational ObjectivesB. Team TeachingC. Personalised system of InstructionsD. Concept of Interaction model of TeachingChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, D, B, C
  • B.B, A, D, C
  • C.C, A, D, B
  • D.C, D, A, B
Correct Answer: B, A, D, C

Although Bloom’s Taxonomy (1956) is slightly earlier than the Trump Plan (1957–58) for team teaching, team teaching as a formal instructional strategy gained wider practical adoption before Bloom’s taxonomy became globally recognized in classrooms.

 

Chronologically by widespread educational implementation and recognition, the order is:

 

B. Team Teaching → A. Bloom’s Taxonomy → D. Interaction Model → C. Personalized System of Instruction.

Question 34
Find out the ‘RIGHT’ combinations below:A. Learning a second language takes little time and efforts – MythB. All bilinguals easily maintain both languages – TrueC. Learning a second language takes little time and efforts – TrueD. All bilinguals easily maintain both languages – MythChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A and D Only
  • B.B and C Only
  • C.A and B Only
  • D.C and D Only
Correct Answer: A and D Only

A. Learning a second language takes little time and efforts – Myth

→ In reality, learning a new language requires time, practice, and consistent effort.

 

B. All bilinguals easily maintain both languages – True → Not true; many bilinguals experience language dominance or attrition (loss of proficiency in one language).

 

C. Learning a second language takes little time and efforts – True

→ This is a myth, not a true statement.

 

D. All bilinguals easily maintain both languages – Myth

→ Correct, maintaining both languages fluently over time is difficult.

 

Hence, the correct combination is A and D only.

Question 35
Match List – I with List – IIList – IA. Goals are decided in the context of the needs of a nationB. Feedback is obtained at local levelC. Team TeachingD. Time for completion of a task is same for all studentsList – III. Modern Teaching TechnologyII. Traditional Teaching TechnologyIII. Instructional TechnologyIV. Educational TechnologyChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A–IV, B–II, C–I, D–III
  • B.A–IV, B–III, C–I, D–II
  • C.A–II, B–I, C–IV, D–III
  • D.A–III, B–I, C–IV, D–II
Correct Answer: A–IV, B–III, C–I, D–II

 

List – I

Meaning / Explanation

Correct Match

A. Goals are decided in the context of the needs of a nation

This refers to broad, system-level educational planning — setting national priorities and aims. That’s a function of Educational Technology.

IV

B. Feedback is obtained at local level

In Instructional Technology, teaching–learning at the micro level is constantly improved through feedback and evaluation within classroom settings.

III

C. Team Teaching

It’s a feature of Modern Teaching Technology, which emphasizes collaboration, resource sharing, and learner-centred approaches.

I

D. Time for completion of a task is same for all students

This is typical of Traditional Teaching Technology, where all students work at the same pace, following fixed schedules and teacher-centred methods.

II

 

Question 36
An IP address consists of a:
  • A.16-bit integer
  • B.32-bit integer
  • C.64-bit integer
  • D.96-bit integer
Correct Answer: 32-bit integer

An IPv4 (Internet Protocol version 4) address consists of a 32-bit integer, usually written as four numbers separated by dots — for example: 192.168.1.1

Question 37
CD-ROM stands for:
  • A.Compressed Disk Read Only Memory
  • B.Compact Device for Reading out Messages
  • C.Compact Device for Read/Write Over Mobiles
  • D.Compact Disk Read Only Memory
Correct Answer: Compact Disk Read Only Memory

CD-ROM stands for Compact Disk Read Only Memory.

It is a pre-pressed optical disc that contains data which can be read (but not written or erased) by a computer. CD-ROMs are commonly used for storing software, games, multimedia, and large data files.

Question 38
Choose the ‘WRONG’ statement:A. Machine Language is alow levellanguageB. ‘FORTRAN’ is ahigh levellanguageC. ‘C’ is alow levellanguageD. ‘SQL’ is alow levellanguageChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A and B Only
  • B.B and C Only
  • C.A and C Only
  • D.C and D Only
Correct Answer: C and D Only

A. Machine Language is a low level language → True. It consists of binary code instructions directly understood by the computer.

 

B. FORTRAN is a high level language → True. It was one of the earliest high-level programming languages.

 

C. ‘C’ is a low level language → Wrong. ‘C’ is a high-level programming language, though it has some low-level features.

 

D. ‘SQL’ is a low level language → Wrong. SQL (Structured Query Language) is a high-level declarative language used for managing databases.

 

Hence, the wrong statements are C and D only.

Question 39
Choose the correct statements:A. MS-Word saves the files in ‘.doc’ formatB. SQL server is a local network serverC. ‘MATLAB’ is a mathematical softwareD. Bootstrap loader is an example of entertainment softwareChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A and B Only
  • B.A and C Only
  • C.C and D Only
  • D.A and D Only
Correct Answer: A and C Only

A. MS-Word saves the files in ‘.doc’ format → True.

Microsoft Word traditionally saves documents as .doc (older versions) and .docx (newer versions).

 

B. SQL server is a local network server → Incorrect.

SQL Server is a database management system, not specifically a local network server (it can be hosted locally or remotely).
