C. ‘MATLAB’ is a mathematical software → True.

MATLAB (Matrix Laboratory) is used for numerical computation, simulation, and data analysis.

 

D. Bootstrap loader is an example of entertainment software → Incorrect.

A bootstrap loader is a system program that loads the operating system — not entertainment software.

 

Hence, the correct statements are A and C only.

Question 40
When was the Paris agreement adopted?
  • A.5 October 2020
  • B.12 December 2015
  • C.7 November 2018
  • D.8 July 1998
Correct Answer: 12 December 2015

The Paris Agreement was adopted on 12 December 2015 during the 21st Conference of the Parties (COP21) to the UNFCCC held in Paris, France.

 

It entered into force on 4 November 2016 and aims to limit global warming to well below 2°C, preferably to 1.5°C, compared to pre-industrial levels.

Question 41
How many Millennium Development Goals (MDG) were adopted by United Nations?
  • A.8
  • B.7
  • C.5
  • D.10
Correct Answer: 8

The United Nations adopted 8 Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) in the year 2000, with a target deadline of 2015.

 

These goals aimed to address global challenges such as poverty, hunger, education, gender equality, child mortality, maternal health, disease, environment, and global partnership.

 

  • Eradicate extreme poverty and hunger
  • Achieve universal primary education
  • Promote gender equality and empower women
  • Reduce child mortality
  • Improve maternal health
  • Combat HIV/AIDS, malaria and other diseases
  • Ensure environmental sustainability
  • Develop a global partnership for development
Question 42
Arrange the phases of life cycle analysis for information on environmental effects of products (from first to last):A. InventoryB. InitiationC. ImpactD. ImprovementChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B, D, C
  • B.C, D, A, B
  • C.D, C, B, A
  • D.B, A, C, D
Correct Answer: B, A, C, D

The Life Cycle Analysis (LCA), also known as Life Cycle Assessment, is a systematic process used to evaluate the environmental impacts of a product throughout its life cycle — from raw material extraction to disposal.

 

The correct sequence of its phases is:

  • B. Initiation (Goal and Scope Definition) – Define the purpose, system boundaries, and objectives of the study.
  • Inventory (Life Cycle Inventory Analysis) – Collect and quantify inputs (energy, materials) and outputs (emissions, waste).
  • Impact (Life Cycle Impact Assessment) – Evaluate the potential environmental impacts based on inventory data.
  • Improvement (Interpretation and Improvement Analysis) – Interpret results and identify opportunities to reduce environmental impacts.

 

Hence, the correct order is B → A → C → D.

Question 43
For disaster management, following processes must be adopted:A. TrainingB. MigrationC. MitigationD. ResponseE. DetectionChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.B and C Only
  • B.B and E Only
  • C.A, B and C Only
  • D.A, C, D and E Only
Correct Answer: A, C, D and E Only

The main processes in disaster management include several interlinked steps that together reduce risk and ensure effective response:

  • Training – Essential for preparing responders and communities to act effectively before, during, and after disasters.
  • Migration – Not a standard disaster management process; it may occur as a result of disasters, not as a planned step.
  • Mitigation – Focuses on reducing the potential impact of disasters (e.g., building codes, flood barriers).
  • Response – Involves immediate actions during and after a disaster to save lives and minimize damage.
  • Detection – Early detection and monitoring help in timely warning and preparedness.
Question 44
Match List – I with List – IIList – I(Ecosystem)A. EurasiaB. South and South East AsiaC. North AmericaD. South AmericaList – II(Biogeographic Realms)I. Neotropical realmII. Palearctic realmsIII. Nearctic realmIV. Oriental realmChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A–II, B–IV, C–III, D–I
  • B.A–II, B–I, C–III, D–IV
  • C.A–III, B–IV, C–I, D–II
  • D.A–II, B–III, C–IV, D–I
Correct Answer: A–II, B–IV, C–III, D–I

 

List–I (Ecosystem / Region)

List–II (Biogeographic Realm)

Explanation

A. Eurasia

II. Palearctic realm

Covers Europe, North Africa, and most of Asia (north of the Himalayas).

B. South and South East Asia

IV. Oriental realm

Includes India, Sri Lanka, Southeast Asia — characterized by tropical forests and rich biodiversity.

C. North America

III. Nearctic realm

Includes Canada, USA, and parts of Mexico.

D. South America

I. Neotropical realm

Encompasses Central and South America — known for rainforests like the Amazon.

 

Question 45
Read the following passage and answer the questions:A person who takes the trouble to form his own opinions and beliefs will feel that he owes no responsibility to the majority for his conclusions. If he is a genuine lover of truth, if he is inspired by a passion for seeing things as they are and an abhorrence of holding ideas which do not conform to facts, he will be wholly independent of the assent of those around him. When he proceeds to apply his beliefs in the practical conduct of life, the position is different. There are then good reasons why his attitude should be less inflexible. The society in which he is placed is an ancient and composite growth. The people from whom he dissents have not come by their opinions, customs and by a process of mere haphazard.These opinions and customs all had their origin in a certain real supposed fitness. They have certain depth of root in the lives of a proportion of the existing generation. Their congruity with one another may have come to an end. That is only one side of the truth. The most zealous propagandism cannot penetrate to them. In common language, we speak of a generation as something possessed of a kind of exact unity, with all its parts and members homogenous. Yet, plainly it is not this. It is a whole but a whole in a state of constant flux, its factors and elements are eternally shifting. It is not one but many generations.A genuine lover of truth will:
  • A.appreciate the quality of food
  • B.make compromise with situation
  • C.criticise what he does not like
  • D.be wholly independent of the assent of those around him
Correct Answer: be wholly independent of the assent of those around him

According to the passage, a genuine lover of truth is someone who:

  • Forms his own opinions and beliefs,
  • Is driven by a passion for seeing things as they are, and
  • Has an abhorrence of holding ideas not based on facts.

 

Therefore, such a person will be independent of others’ approval or agreement — i.e., independent of the assent of those around him.

Question 46
Read the following passage and answer the questions:A person who takes the trouble to form his own opinions and beliefs will feel that he owes no responsibility to the majority for his conclusions. If he is a genuine lover of truth, if he is inspired by a passion for seeing things as they are and an abhorrence of holding ideas which do not conform to facts, he will be wholly independent of the assent of those around him. When he proceeds to apply his beliefs in the practical conduct of life, the position is different. There are then good reasons why his attitude should be less inflexible. The society in which he is placed is an ancient and composite growth. The people from whom he dissents have not come by their opinions, customs and by a process of mere haphazard.These opinions and customs all had their origin in a certain real supposed fitness. They have certain depth of root in the lives of a proportion of the existing generation. Their congruity with one another may have come to an end. That is only one side of the truth. The most zealous propagandism cannot penetrate to them. In common language, we speak of a generation as something possessed of a kind of exact unity, with all its parts and members homogenous. Yet, plainly it is not this. It is a whole but a whole in a state of constant flux, its factors and elements are eternally shifting. It is not one but many generations.According to the passage, customs and traditions originate from:
  • A.Conflicts of life
  • B.Ignorance
  • C.The old generation
  • D.Beliefs
Correct Answer: The old generation

The passage states that “These opinions and customs all had their origin in a certain real supposed fitness.” This means that customs and traditions arise from certain beliefs — ideas or assumptions once considered suitable or fitting for life.

 

Hence, customs and traditions originate from beliefs.

Question 47
Read the following passage and answer the questions:A person who takes the trouble to form his own opinions and beliefs will feel that he owes no responsibility to the majority for his conclusions. If he is a genuine lover of truth, if he is inspired by a passion for seeing things as they are and an abhorrence of holding ideas which do not conform to facts, he will be wholly independent of the assent of those around him. When he proceeds to apply his beliefs in the practical conduct of life, the position is different. There are then good reasons why his attitude should be less inflexible. The society in which he is placed is an ancient and composite growth. The people from whom he dissents have not come by their opinions, customs and by a process of mere haphazard.These opinions and customs all had their origin in a certain real supposed fitness. They have certain depth of root in the lives of a proportion of the existing generation. Their congruity with one another may have come to an end. That is only one side of the truth. The most zealous propagandism cannot penetrate to them. In common language, we speak of a generation as something possessed of a kind of exact unity, with all its parts and members homogenous. Yet, plainly it is not this. It is a whole but a whole in a state of constant flux, its factors and elements are eternally shifting. It is not one but many generations.According to the author, a generation is a whole but it is always:
  • A.Constant
  • B.Knowing
  • C.Homogeneous
  • D.Heterogeneous
Correct Answer: Heterogeneous

The passage clearly mentions that “a generation is a whole but a whole in a state of constant flux, its factors and elements are eternally shifting. It is not one but many generations.”

 

This means that a generation is not uniform or homogeneous, but made up of diverse and changing elements — hence, it is heterogeneous.

Question 48
Read the following passage and answer the questions:A person who takes the trouble to form his own opinions and beliefs will feel that he owes no responsibility to the majority for his conclusions. If he is a genuine lover of truth, if he is inspired by a passion for seeing things as they are and an abhorrence of holding ideas which do not conform to facts, he will be wholly independent of the assent of those around him. When he proceeds to apply his beliefs in the practical conduct of life, the position is different. There are then good reasons why his attitude should be less inflexible. The society in which he is placed is an ancient and composite growth. The people from whom he dissents have not come by their opinions, customs and by a process of mere haphazard.These opinions and customs all had their origin in a certain real supposed fitness. They have certain depth of root in the lives of a proportion of the existing generation. Their congruity with one another may have come to an end. That is only one side of the truth. The most zealous propagandism cannot penetrate to them. In common language, we speak of a generation as something possessed of a kind of exact unity, with all its parts and members homogenous. Yet, plainly it is not this. It is a whole but a whole in a state of constant flux, its factors and elements are eternally shifting. It is not one but many generations.One’s position is usually different when a person _______.
  • A.turns a deaf ear to what others say
  • B.pays attention to what people say
  • C.proceeds to apply his beliefs in the practical conduct of life
  • D.remains ignorant of happenings around him
Correct Answer: proceeds to apply his beliefs in the practical conduct of life

The passage states: “When he proceeds to apply his beliefs in the practical conduct of life, the position is different. There are then good reasons why his attitude should be less inflexible.”

 

This means that a person’s position or approach changes when he begins to apply his beliefs in real-life situations, as practical realities may require flexibility.

Question 49
Read the following passage and answer the questions:A person who takes the trouble to form his own opinions and beliefs will feel that he owes no responsibility to the majority for his conclusions. If he is a genuine lover of truth, if he is inspired by a passion for seeing things as they are and an abhorrence of holding ideas which do not conform to facts, he will be wholly independent of the assent of those around him. When he proceeds to apply his beliefs in the practical conduct of life, the position is different. There are then good reasons why his attitude should be less inflexible. The society in which he is placed is an ancient and composite growth. The people from whom he dissents have not come by their opinions, customs and by a process of mere haphazard.These opinions and customs all had their origin in a certain real supposed fitness. They have certain depth of root in the lives of a proportion of the existing generation. Their congruity with one another may have come to an end. That is only one side of the truth. The most zealous propagandism cannot penetrate to them. In common language, we speak of a generation as something possessed of a kind of exact unity, with all its parts and members homogenous. Yet, plainly it is not this. It is a whole but a whole in a state of constant flux, its factors and elements are eternally shifting. It is not one but many generations.According to the author, the attitude of self-opinionated person in the practical social life should be:
  • A.flexible
  • B.rigid
  • C.indifferent
  • D.proactive
Correct Answer: flexible

The passage states: “When he proceeds to apply his beliefs in the practical conduct of life, the position is different. There are then good reasons why his attitude should be less inflexible.”

 

This means that in practical or social life, even a person firm in his beliefs should adopt a flexible attitude, adjusting to the realities and complexities of society.

Question 50
Match List – I with List – IIList – I(System Name)A. The Mark I computerB. IBM – 701C. IBM – 650D. The Universal Automatic Computer One (UNIVAC – I)List – II(Year/Time period)I. 1951II. 1953III. 1937–44IV. 1952Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A–III, B–IV, C–II, D–I
  • B.A–II, B–III, C–I, D–IV
  • C.A–I, B–II, C–IV, D–III
  • D.A–IV, B–I, C–II, D–III
Correct Answer: A–III, B–IV, C–II, D–I

 

 

Computer System

Developer / Background

Year Introduced

Correct Match

A. The Mark I

Developed by Howard Aiken with IBM

1944 (design started 1937)

III → 1937–44

B. IBM–701

IBM’s first commercial scientific computer

1952–53

IV → 1952

C. IBM–650

IBM’s first mass-produced computer

1953–54

II → 1953

D. UNIVAC–I

First commercial computer in the U.S.

1951

I → 1951

Quiz Attempt #119700

Total Questions: 50
Question 1
Study the following table and answer the questions:The table shows the data of Demand (number of applications received) and Intake (available seats) in five colleges (A, B, C, D and E):CollegeABCDEDemand (applications received)3000600250012003300Intake (available seats)15001800100027002200How much percent more is the average demand of all five colleges taken together than the average of available seats of all the five colleges?
  • A.65.71%
  • B.40%
  • C.15.22%
  • D.35.71%
Correct Answer: 15.22%

Total Demand = 3000 + 600 + 2500 + 1200 + 3300 = 10,600

Average Demand = 10,600 ÷ 5 = 2,120

 

Total Intake = 1500 + 1800 + 1000 + 2700 + 2200 = 9,200

Average Intake = 9,200 ÷ 5 = 1,840

 

Percentage Increase = 2120-18401840×100 = 15.22%

Question 2
Study the following table and answer thequestions :The table shows the data of Demand (number of applications received) and Intake (available seats) in five colleges (A, B, C, D and E):CollegeABCDEDemand (applications received)3000600250012003300Intake (available seats)15001800100027002200What is the ratio of the number of colleges having more demand than available seats to those having more available seats than demand?
  • A.2 :3
  • B.1 :4
  • C.4 :1
  • D.3 :2
Correct Answer: 3 :2

Colleges with Demand > Intake: A, C, E → 3 colleges

Colleges with Intake > Demand: B, D → 2 colleges

Ratio = 3 : 2.

Question 3
Study the following table and answer thequestions :The table shows the data of Demand (number of applications received) and Intake (available seats) in five colleges (A, B, C, D and E):CollegeABCDEDemand (applications received)3000600250012003300Intake (available seats)15001800100027002200The demand for college B is approximately what percent of the demand for college C?
  • A.24%
  • B.124%
  • C.60%
  • D.416%
Correct Answer: 24%

Required % = 6002500×100 = 24%

Question 4
Study the following table and answer thequestions :The table shows the data of Demand (number of applications received) and Intake (available seats) in five colleges (A, B, C, D and E):CollegeABCDEDemand (applications received)3000600250012003300Intake (available seats)15001800100027002200The total demand of two highest demanded colleges is what percent higher than total demand of two lowest demanded colleges?
  • A.40%
  • B.250%
  • C.400%
  • D.25%
Correct Answer: 250%

Two highest demands: E (3300) and A (3000) → Total = 6300

Two lowest demands: B (600) and D (1200) → Total = 1800

Required % = 6300-18001800×100 = 250%

Question 5
Study the following table and answer thequestions :The table shows the data of Demand (number of applications received) and Intake (available seats) in five colleges (A, B, C, D and E):CollegeABCDEDemand (applications received)3000600250012003300Intake (available seats)15001800100027002200The difference of demand and available seats in college E is what percentage lower than the difference of demand and available seats of college A?
  • A.36.36%
  • B.42.70%
  • C.26.67%
  • D.31.24%
Correct Answer: 26.67%

College A: 3000 – 1500 = 1500

College E: 3300 – 2200 = 1100

Required % = 1500-11001100×100 = 26.67%

Question 6
A teacher assesses the answer books of the students and based on their scores he gives them ranks. Which scales of measurement are used by him?
  • A.Interval and ordinal
  • B.Ratio and ordinal
  • C.Nominal and ordinal
  • D.Interval and nominal
Correct Answer: Interval and ordinal

Scores represent interval scale — they show differences in marks with meaningful intervals (e.g., the difference between 60 and 70 is the same as between 70 and 80), but there is no true zero.

 

Ranks represent ordinal scale — they show the order of performance (1st, 2nd, 3rd, etc.) but not the exact difference between them.

 

Hence, the teacher uses Interval (for scores) and Ordinal (for ranks) scales.

Question 7
The following are the steps related with construction and standardisation of research tool. Select their correct order from earlier to later:A. Construction of itemsB. Selection of items for final draft of the toolC. Item analysisD. Establishment of normsE. Selection of items for primary draft of the toolChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, E, C, B, D
  • B.E, A, C, B, D
  • C.D, A, E, C, B
  • D.A, E, B, C, D
Correct Answer: A, E, C, B, D

A. Construction of items – Prepare a large pool of statements/questions.

 

 

E. Selection of items for primary draft of the tool – Choose suitable items for the initial version.

 

 

C. Item analysis – Analyze each item statistically to determine its validity and reliability.

 

 

B. Selection of items for final draft of the tool – Retain only the best-performing items.

 

 

D. Establishment of norms – Develop norms or standards for interpretation of scores.

 

 

Final Order: A → E → C → B → D.

Question 8
Which of the following are the characteristics of Action Research?A. It does not aim to develop theory.B. It is not conducted to generalise the findings.C. Sample is selected randomly.D. It is conducted to find the solution of local level problem.E. Control on variable is required in it.Choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B and C Only
  • B.A, B and E Only
  • C.B, C and D Only
  • D.A, B and D Only
Correct Answer: A, B and D Only

A. Action research focuses on solving immediate problems rather than developing theory.

B. Its findings are not meant to be generalized to other contexts.

D. It aims to find practical solutions to local-level problems.

C. Sampling is usually purposive, not random.

E. It does not require strict control over variables.

Question 9
Identify non-parametric tests:A. Kendall’s W TestB. Rank correlation testC. Wilcoxon TestD. t TestE. Analysis of VarianceChoose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B and E Only
  • B.B, D and E Only
  • C.B, C and E Only
  • D.A, B and C Only
Correct Answer: A, B and C Only

A. Kendall’s W Test – Non-parametric test for assessing agreement among raters.

 

B. Rank Correlation Test (Spearman’s or Kendall’s) – Non-parametric correlation measure based on ranks.

 

C. Wilcoxon Test – Non-parametric alternative to the paired t-test.

 

D. t Test and E. ANOVA are parametric tests, as they assume normally distributed data and interval/ratio scales.

Question 10
Match List–I with List–IIList–IA. Experimental ResearchB. Ethnographic ResearchC. SurveyD. Case StudyList–III. In-depth study of a single unitII. Study of opinions of people towards social mediaIII. Cause and effect relationship between independent and dependent variablesIV. Study of the perception of the people of a particular group regarding their lifeChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A–IV, B–III, C–II, D–I
  • B.A–III, B–IV, C–II, D–I
  • C.A–III, B–I, C–IV, D–II
  • D.A–II, B–IV, C–I, D–III
Correct Answer: A–III, B–IV, C–II, D–I

A. Experimental Research → (III) Establishes cause and effect relationship between independent and dependent variables.

 

B. Ethnographic Research → (IV) Studies the perception and lifestyle of people within a particular cultural or social group.

 

C. Survey → (II) Collects opinions or attitudes of people on specific issues (e.g., social media use).

 

D. Case Study → (I) Involves an in-depth examination of a single unit (person, event, or institution).

Question 11
Choose the correct statement related to Autonomous colleges in the context of recommendations of NPE 1986 (POA-1992):
  • A.Provide no special assistance to colleges in tribal areas
  • B.Full Funding by the Central Govt. for a period of 10 years
  • C.Funding shall be made available through NAAC
  • D.500 colleges to be developed as autonomous colleges in the seventhfive yearplan
Correct Answer: 500 colleges to be developed as autonomous colleges in the seventhfive yearplan

According to the National Policy on Education (1986) and its Programme of Action (1992), it was recommended that about 500 colleges be developed as autonomous colleges during the Seventh Five Year Plan.

 

The purpose was to promote academic freedom, innovation in curriculum design, and improve quality in higher education.

Question 12
The global education development agenda reflected in the Goal 4 (SDG4) of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development was adopted by India in ________.
  • A.2020
  • B.2010
  • C.1992
  • D.2015
Correct Answer: 2015

Sustainable Development Goal 4 (SDG 4) — “Ensure inclusive and equitable quality education and promote lifelong learning opportunities for all” — is part of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, which was adopted by all United Nations member states, including India, in 2015.

Question 13
Arrange the given digital initiatives of Govt. of India in chronological order as per their year of launch:A. e-gyankoshB. PM e-VidyaC. NPTELD. e-PGPathshalaE. SWAYAMChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.C, A, D, E, B
  • B.E, C, A, B, D
  • C.D, A, E, B, C
  • D.B, A, C, E, D
Correct Answer: C, A, D, E, B

NPTEL (2003) – Launched by IITs and IISc to provide online engineering and science courses.

 

A. e-Gyankosh (2005) – Launched by IGNOU as a digital repository of open educational resources.

 

D. e-PG Pathshala (2015) – Started by UGC under the National Mission on Education through ICT (NMEICT) for postgraduate courses.

 

E. SWAYAM (2017) – Launched to provide Massive Open Online Courses (MOOCs) for school and higher education.

 

B. PM e-Vidya (2020) – Introduced under the Atma Nirbhar Bharat initiative to unify all digital and online education efforts during the COVID-19 pandemic.

Question 14
The NEP, 2020 document states that:A. Single stream HEI’s will be phased out over timeB. By 2035, there shall be at least one multidisciplinary HEI in or near every districtC. Institutions will have option to run ODL and online programmes, provided they are accredited to do soD. Justice J.S. Verma Commission (2012) reports that over 20000 stand-alone Teacher Education Institutions (TEIs) are selling degrees for a priceE. Private HEIs will be encouraged to offer large number offreeshipsand scholarships to their studentsChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B, C and D Only
  • B.C, D and E Only
  • C.A, C and E Only
  • D.A, B and E Only
Correct Answer: A, C and E Only

According to the National Education Policy (NEP) 2020:

 

A. Single-stream Higher Education Institutions (HEIs) will indeed be phased out over time to promote multidisciplinary education.

 

B. By 2035, there shall be at least one multidisciplinary HEI in or near every district.

 

E. Private HEIs will be encouraged to offer freeships and scholarships to promote access and equity.

 

Statements C and D are also true but are not directly stated in the NEP 2020 document itself —

 

(C) relates to UGC regulations on ODL/online learning.

 

(D) is from the Justice J.S. Verma Commission Report (2012), not the NEP 2020 document.

 

Hence, the correct combination as per NEP 2020 is A, B and E only.

Question 15
Match List–I with List–IIList–I(Committee)A. Sarkar Committee 1945B. Sam Pitroda CommitteeC. K. B. Pawar CommitteeD. Sahoo CommitteeList–II(Major Focus Area / Recommendation in the context of Education)I. To explore Public–Private Partnership in Higher EducationII. To recommend measures for improving governance and accountability in Higher Education InstitutionsIII. Development of Higher Technical Education in IndiaIV. Restructuring Curricula for multidisciplinary professional coursesChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A–III, B–IV, C–I, D–II
  • B.A–II, B–III, C–IV, D–I
  • C.A–IV, B–I, C–II, D–III
  • D.A–III, B–I, C–IV, D–II
Correct Answer: A–III, B–IV, C–I, D–II

 

Committee

Year / Focus

Correct Match

A. Sarkar Committee (1945)

Recommended creation of a central body to coordinate technical education → led to the establishment of AICTE

(III) Development of Higher Technical Education in India

B. Sam Pitroda Committee

Focused on reforms in higher education including use of technology and curriculum restructuring for multidisciplinary courses

(IV) Restructuring curricula for multidisciplinary professional courses

C. K. B. Pawar Committee

Examined Public–Private Partnership (PPP) in higher education

(I) To explore PPP in Higher Education

D. Sahoo Committee

Recommended improving governance and accountability in HEIs

(II) Governance and accountability reforms

 

Question 16
Which one of the following does not pertain to 4 Cs of successful writing?
  • A.Concise
  • B.Connect
  • C.Clear
  • D.Correct
Correct Answer: Connect

Clear – The message should be easily understood.

Concise – Use only necessary words; avoid redundancy.

Correct – Ensure grammatical and factual accuracy.

Complete (sometimes also replaced with Courteous in communication).

 

“Connect” is not one of the traditional 4 Cs of writing.

Question 17
Skills to face job interviews and getting employed are part of:
  • A.Teaching skills
  • B.Soft skills
  • C.Learning skills
  • D.Manipulation skills
Correct Answer: Soft skills

Soft skills include personal attributes and interpersonal abilities such as communication, confidence, teamwork, adaptability, and interview skills. These skills help individuals face job interviews successfully and gain employment, complementing their technical or academic knowledge.

Arrange the evolution of the following social media platforms in chronological order from past to present:A. TikTokB. TwitterC. FacebookD. InstagramE. YouTubeChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.D, A, C, E, B
  • B.C, D, A, B, E
  • C.E, B, D, A, C
  • D.C, E, B, D, A
Correct Answer: C, E, B, D, A

YouTube – 2005

Twitter – 2006

Facebook – 2004

Instagram – 2010

TikTok – 2016.

Question 19
Which of the following come under the category of non-verbal communication?A. Body languageB. ShoutingC. GesturesD. Facial ExpressionsE. Conversation on telephonic callChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.B, C and D Only
  • B.C, D and E Only
  • C.A, B and E Only
  • D.A, C and D Only
Correct Answer: A, C and D Only

A. Body language, C. Gestures, and D. Facial expressions are all forms of non-verbal communication, as they convey meaning without words.

 

B. Shouting and E. Telephonic conversation involve spoken words and tone, making them verbal or paraverbal communication, not non-verbal.

Question 20
Match List–I with List–IIList–IA. Swayam PrabhaB. Shark TankC. Krishi DarshanD. ShaktimaanList–III. Kids ProgrammeII. Agriculture ProgrammeIII. Business reality T.V. SeriesIV. Educational ProgrammesChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A–IV, B–III, C–II, D–I
  • B.A–III, B–IV, C–I, D–II
  • C.A–II, B–III, C–IV, D–I
  • D.A–IV, B–II, C–III, D–I
Correct Answer: A–IV, B–III, C–II, D–I

A. Swayam Prabha → (IV) Educational programmes (24x7 DTH channels for learning).

B. Shark Tank → (III) Business reality TV series promoting entrepreneurship.

C. Krishi Darshan → (II) Agriculture programme broadcast by Doordarshan.

D. Shaktimaan → (I) Kids’ superhero programme.

Question 21
Find the missing term (?) in the following alpha-numeric series:A2B, B3D, C5F, (?), E11J, ......
  • A.D7H
  • B.D8G
  • C.D9H
  • D.D8H
Correct Answer: D7H

First letters go A, B, C, D, E (alphabetic order).

Numbers are primes: 2, 3, 5, 7, 11.

Last letters skip one each time: B, D, F, H, J.

Question 22
Find the next term (?) in the following number series.0, 9, 26, 65, 124, 217, ?, ......
  • A.317
  • B.336
  • C.341
  • D.342
Correct Answer: 342

13- 1 = 0

23+ 1 = 9

33- 1 = 26

43+ 1 = 65

53- 1 = 124

63+ 1 = 217

Similarly

73- 1 = 342

Question 23
Arrange the following shapes in increasing order of their areas:A. A circle of diameter 10 cmB. A rectangle of dimensions [6 cm × 4 cm]C. A square of side 5 cmD. An equilateral triangle of side 5 cmChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.D, C, A, B
  • B.B, C, D, A
  • C.B, D, C, A
  • D.D, B, C, A
Correct Answer: D, B, C, A

Circle (diameter = 10 cm)

Radius, 𝑟 =

Area = πr² = 3.14 × 25 = 78.5 cm²

 

B. Rectangle (6 × 4)

Area = 6 × 4 = 24 cm²

 

C. Square (side = 5)

Area = 5² = 25 cm²

 

D. Equilateral triangle

Area = 34 (side)2 = 10.825 cm2

 

Correct answer: (D) D, B, C, A

Question 24
Which of the following are correct?A. Speed of 50 km/hour is equivalent to 15 m/s.B. The area of a rhombus with diagonals of 4 cm and 6 cm is 12 cm².C.7293is greater than 4D. The cost price of 10 bananas is the same as the selling price of 8 bananas. The percentage profit is 25%Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B and D Only
  • B.B, C and D Only
  • C.B and D Only
  • D.A, C and D Only
Correct Answer: B and D Only

Only B and D are correct.

Question 25
Match List–I with List–IIList–IA. In a class, the ratio of number of male students to number of female students is9 :11. The percentage (%) of female students in the class is___________B. When a number ‘x’ is added to the numerator and denominator of fraction711, it becomes23, then x is__________C. Two numbers are directly proportional to each other. If the value of one of the numbers is doubled, then their product will become __________ times.D. Ifx :y =3 :2, thenxy+y2x2-y2is equal to ___________List–III. 4II. 2III. 55IV. 1Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A–III, B–I, C–II, D–IV
  • B.A–II, B–III, C–IV, D–I
  • C.A–III, B–IV, C–I, D–II
  • D.A–III, B–II, C–IV, D–I
Correct Answer: A–III, B–IV, C–I, D–II

A. 1120×100 = 55%

 

B. 7+x11+x = 23

Then, x = 1

 

C. Their product will be 4 times.

 

D. xy+y2x2-y2 = y(x+y)(x-y)(x+y) = yx-y = 1xy-1 = 2

Question 26
Mimamsais :
  • A.State of mental absorption in an object, where an individual gains own experiential realisation of its true nature (Samadhi)
  • B.One of the classical schools of Indian Philosophy (Aastik Vedas)
  • C.The unorthodox means of knowledge (Nastik)
  • D.A doctrine that claims all universal things are momentary in nature
Correct Answer: One of the classical schools of Indian Philosophy (Aastik Vedas)

Mimamsa (also called Purva Mimamsa) is one of the six orthodox (Āstika) schools of Indian philosophy that accept the authority of the Vedas.

 

It primarily focuses on the interpretation of Vedic texts, rituals, and dharma (duty). It was founded by Jaimini and emphasizes karma (action) and Vedic injunctions as the means to attain liberation.

Question 27
Which of the following is an example of deductive reasoning?
  • A.Screen exposure among children at very early stage affects theirPsychologicalhealth. Therefore, we should not expose our children to digital gadgets.
  • B.Smoking leads to lung cancer. Therefore, we should not smoke.
  • C.If it is raining, then the ground is wet. It is raining. Therefore, the ground is wet.
  • D.All ducks that have been observed have been white. Therefore, all ducks are white.
Correct Answer: If it is raining, then the ground is wet. It is raining. Therefore, the ground is wet.

This is a clear case of deductive reasoning, where a general rule (premise) leads logically to a specific conclusion.

  • Premise 1: If it is raining, then the ground is wet.
  • Premise 2: It is raining.
  • Conclusion: Therefore, the ground is wet.

 

Deductive reasoning moves from general to specific, ensuring the conclusion is logically certain if the premises are true.

Question 28
Arrange in sequence the process of evaluating analogical reasoning:A. Draw conclusionB. Evaluate strength of analogyC. Assess relevance of similaritiesD. Detect common featuresE. Identify the source and target domainsChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.C, D, A, E, B
  • B.E, A, D, C, B
  • C.A, C, E, D, B
  • D.E, D, C, A, B
Correct Answer: E, D, C, A, B

The logical sequence of evaluating analogical reasoning is as follows:

  • E. Identify the source and target domains – Determine what two areas or situations are being compared.
  • D. Detect common features – Find the similarities between the source and target.
  • C. Assess relevance of similarities – Check which similarities are meaningful to the reasoning.
  • Draw conclusion – Use the analogy to infer a possible conclusion.
  • Evaluate strength of analogy – Finally, assess how strong or valid the analogy is.
Question 29
If the proposition "No reptiles are squirrels" is given as false, then which of the following propositions can be inferred to be true?A. Some reptiles are squirrelsB. All reptiles are squirrelsC. Some non-squirrels are not non-reptilesD. Some reptiles are not squirrelsChoose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.A and C Only
  • B.B Only
  • C.C and D Only
  • D.A, C and D Only
Correct Answer: A and C Only

A. Some reptiles are squirrels → True (this is the direct contradictory of the given statement).

 

B. All reptiles are squirrels → Cannot be inferred; “No S are P” being false only means some overlap, not that all are the same.

 

C. Some non-squirrels are not non-reptiles → This is logically equivalent to “Some reptiles are squirrels” (so also True).

 

D. Some reptiles are not squirrels → Not necessarily true; if “some are squirrels,” we can’t conclude others aren’t.

Question 30
Match List–I with List–IIList–I(Proposition)A. Universal affirmativeB. Universal negativeC. Particular affirmativeD. Particular negativeList–II(Standard Form)I. No S is PII. All S is PIII. Some S is not PIV. Some S is PChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A–I, B–IV, C–II, D–III
  • B.A–II, B–I, C–IV, D–III
  • C.A–IV, B–I, C–III, D–II
  • D.A–II, B–IV, C–I, D–III
Correct Answer: A–II, B–I, C–IV, D–III

 

Type of Proposition

Standard Form

Symbolic Form

A. Universal Affirmative

All S is P

A-type

B. Universal Negative

No S is P

E-type

C. Particular Affirmative

Some S is P

I-type

D. Particular Negative

Some S is not P

O-type

 

Question 31
‘Evening Hours of a Hermit’ is written by:
  • A.Krishnamurthy
  • B.Rousseau
  • C.Khushwant Singh
  • D.Pestalozzi
Correct Answer: Pestalozzi

“Evening Hours of a Hermit” (1780) was written by Johann Heinrich Pestalozzi, a Swiss educator and social reformer. In this work, he presented his early educational philosophy, emphasizing moral development, love, and learning through activity and experience, which later shaped modern child-centered education.

Question 32
“Learning to Do – Towards a Learning and Working Society” is the title of the report submitted by:
  • A.AdiseshaiahCommittee
  • B.Kothari Commission
  • C.IshwarbhaiPatel Committee
  • D.Zakir Hussain Committee
Correct Answer: AdiseshaiahCommittee

The report titled “Learning to Do – Towards a Learning and Working Society” was submitted by the Adiseshaiah Committee (1978).

 

It focused on linking education with work, promoting vocationalisation, and preparing learners for a learning and working society, aligning education with practical life and employability.

Question 33
Arrange the following Erickson’s stages of development on the basis of order of their occurrence:A. Generativity and StagnationB. Identity and Role ConfusionC. Autonomy and ShameD. Industry and InferiorityE. Integrity and DespairChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.C, B, D, A, E
  • B.C, A, D, B, E
  • C.C, E, A, B, D
  • D.C, D, B, A, E
Correct Answer: C, D, B, A, E

C. Autonomy vs. Shame and Doubt – Early childhood (2–3 years)

 

D. Industry vs. Inferiority – School age (6–12 years)

 

B. Identity vs. Role Confusion – Adolescence (12–18 years)

 

A. Generativity vs. Stagnation – Adulthood (40–65 years)

 

E. Integrity vs. Despair – Old age (65 years and above)

Question 34
Select theRIGHTstatements:A. ‘Article 21-A’ inserted in the Constitution is related to Right to free and compulsory educationB. ‘Article 30’ of the Constitution protects the Right to InformationC. ‘Article 350-A’ assures the Higher Education and ResearchD. ‘Article 30’ of the Constitution protects the Right of minorities to manage theEducationalinstitutionsChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A and B Only
  • B.A and C Only
  • C.A and D Only
  • D.B and D Only
Correct Answer: A and D Only

Article 21-A – Provides the Right to free and compulsory education for children aged 6 to 14 years (inserted by the 86th Amendment Act, 2002).

Article 30 – Grants minorities the right to establish and administer educational institutions of their choice.

Article 19(1)(a) – Protects the Right to Information, not Article 30.

Article 350-A – Relates to instruction in mother tongue at the primary stage, not higher education.

 

Hence, the correct combination is A and D only.

Question 35
Match List–I with List–IIList–I(Methods)A. LecturingB. DemonstrationC. Field TripD. ProjectList–II(Objectives)I. Providing direct experiencesII. Presenting factsIII. Providing purposeful activitiesIV. Showing manipulations of operationsChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A–II, B–I, C–IV, D–III
  • B.A–II, B–IV, C–I, D–III
  • C.A–III, B–IV, C–II, D–I
  • D.A–IV, B–III, C–I, D–II
Correct Answer: A–II, B–IV, C–I, D–III

A. Lecturing → (II) Presenting facts – The lecture method is mainly used to convey information and explain concepts.

 

B. Demonstration → (IV) Showing manipulations or operations – Demonstrations involve showing how something works or is done.

 

C. Field Trip → (I) Providing direct experiences – Field trips give students firsthand, real-world learning experiences.

 

D. Project → (III) Providing purposeful activities – Project work involves goal-oriented, hands-on learning tasks.

Question 36
Landes (1969) considers the Industrial Revolution as the outcome of a combination of three interrelated streams of technical advances. Which of the following is NOT one of these streams?
  • A.“Mechanization”
  • B.Adoption of new power sources
  • C.Modification of equipment to make human life easy
  • D.Extensive use of new raw materials
Correct Answer: Modification of equipment to make human life easy

According to David S. Landes (1969) in The Unbound Prometheus, the Industrial Revolution was the result of three interrelated streams of technical advances:

 

Mechanization – Replacing manual labor with machines.

Adoption of new power sources – Especially steam and later electricity.

Extensive use of new raw materials – Such as coal and iron.

 

“Modification of equipment to make human life easy” is not one of the three streams identified by Landes.

Question 37
The process of typing CAPTCHAs is a variation on:
  • A.Turing test
  • B.Turner’s test
  • C.F-test
  • D.t-test
Correct Answer: Turing test

The process of typing CAPTCHAs (Completely Automated Public Turing test to tell Computers and Humans Apart) is based on a variation of the Turing Test developed by Alan Turing.

 

In a traditional Turing Test, a computer tries to behave like a human, whereas in a CAPTCHA, the goal is the opposite — to distinguish humans from machines by presenting tasks that are easy for humans but difficult for bots or automated systems.

Question 38
Choose the WRONG statements:A. Kali Linux is a flavour of Linux OSB. We can use Macintosh on Linux OS alsoC. Windows Surface is developed by Intel CorporationD. Android is based on Linux OSChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A and B Only
  • B.B and D Only
  • C.A and C Only
  • D.B and C Only
Correct Answer: B and C Only

A. Kali Linux is a flavour of Linux OS – Correct. It’s a Debian-based Linux distribution used for cybersecurity and penetration testing.

 

B. We can use Macintosh on Linux OS also – Wrong. macOS (Macintosh) is a separate operating system developed by Apple and cannot natively run on Linux.

 

C. Windows Surface is developed by Intel Corporation – Wrong. Windows Surface devices are developed by Microsoft, not Intel.

 

D. Android is based on Linux OS – Correct. Android uses the Linux kernel as its foundation.

Question 39
Choose the WRONG statements:A. ‘OLED’ stands for Organic Light Emitting DiodesB. ‘Fastag’ is an example of RFIDC. ‘CAD’ stands for Computer Algorithm of DesignD. ‘RFID’ stands for Rapid Frequency IdentificationChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.C and D Only
  • B.A and B Only
  • C.B and C Only
  • D.A and C Only
Correct Answer: C and D Only

A. ‘OLED’ stands for Organic Light Emitting Diodes – Correct.

 

B. ‘Fastag’ is an example of RFID – Correct; it uses Radio Frequency Identification for toll payments.

 

C. ‘CAD’ stands for Computer Algorithm of Design – Wrong; it stands for Computer-Aided Design.

 

D. ‘RFID’ stands for Rapid Frequency Identification – Wrong; it stands for Radio Frequency Identification.

Question 40
Match List–I with List–IIList–I(Type of e-resource)A. e-JournalsB. e-BooksC. e-ZinesD. CD-ROMsList–II(Description)I. Used for storing a larger volume of dataII. Published on the web as well as in the digital formatIII. A piece of softwareIV. Can be used to store articles on a file server in the form of a magazineChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A–II, B–III, C–IV, D–I
  • B.A–III, B–IV, C–I, D–II
  • C.A–IV, B–III, C–II, D–I
  • D.A–II, B–IV, C–I, D–III
Correct Answer: A–II, B–III, C–IV, D–I

A. e-Journals → (II) Published on the web as well as in digital format.

 

B. e-Books → (III) A piece of software (digital text accessible via e-readers or apps).

 

C. e-Zines → (IV) Electronic magazines stored or published online.

 

D. CD-ROMs → (I) Used for storing a large volume of data in digital form.

Question 41
What is the major source of pollutant lead in homes?
  • A.Furniture
  • B.Paint
  • C.Utensils
  • D.Notebooks
Correct Answer: Paint

The major source of lead pollution in homes is lead-based paint, especially in older buildings.

 

When such paint peels or produces dust, it contaminates the indoor environment and can cause lead poisoning, particularly harmful to children.

Question 42
What is Noise Induced Permanent Threshold Shifts (NIPTS)?
  • A.Shift due to exposure to high-level sound for a comparatively short period
  • B.Shift due to honking of vehicles
  • C.Shift in permanent threshold due to years of high-level industrial noise
  • D.Shift due to shorter noise exposure
Correct Answer: Shift in permanent threshold due to years of high-level industrial noise

Noise-Induced Permanent Threshold Shift (NIPTS) refers to a permanent hearing loss that occurs when a person is exposed to high levels of noise over a long period, such as in industrial or occupational settings.

 

This chronic exposure damages the hair cells in the inner ear, leading to an irreversible rise in the hearing threshold (i.e., reduced hearing sensitivity).

Question 43
Arrange the sequence of processes leading to formation of ozone hole:A. De-humidification, de-nitrificationB. Vortex formationC. Pre-conditioningD. Very low temperature polar stratosphere cloudsE. Ozone destruction by catalysisChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.E, D, C, B, A
  • B.B, D, A, C, E
  • C.A, B, C, D, E
  • D.C, A, B, D, E
Correct Answer: B, D, A, C, E

B. Vortex formation – In polar regions, strong winds form a polar vortex that traps air masses.

 

D. Very low temperature polar stratospheric clouds (PSCs) – The vortex causes extremely low temperatures, forming PSCs.

 

A. De-humidification, de-nitrification – PSCs remove water vapour and nitrogen compounds, setting conditions for ozone depletion.

 

C. Pre-conditioning – Chlorine compounds accumulate and become active when sunlight returns.

 

E. Ozone destruction by catalysis – Active chlorine and bromine radicals catalytically destroy ozone molecules, creating the ozone hole.

Question 44
Choose the correct statements from the following regarding targets under Sustainable Development Goals:A. Target under SDG8 is to sustain 7% GDP in least developed countries.B. Target under SDG3 is to ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health care by 2030.C. Target under SDG4 is to ensure equal access for all women and men to affordable quality higher education by 2030.D. Target under SDG7 is to build resilient infrastructure, promote inclusive and sustainable industrialization, and foster innovation.E. Target under SDG6 is to improve water quality by reducing pollution by 2030.Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B, D and E Only
  • B.A, B, C and E Only
  • C.A, B and D Only
  • D.A, C and E Only
Correct Answer: A, B, C and E Only

A. Target under SDG 8 – To sustain 7% GDP growth in least developed countries — True.

 

B. Target under SDG 3 – To ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health-care services by 2030 — True.

 

C. Target under SDG 4 – To ensure equal access for all women and men to affordable and quality higher education by 2030 — True.

 

D. Target under SDG 7 – Incorrect. SDG 7 is about affordable and clean energy, while building resilient infrastructure and promoting sustainable industrialization belong to SDG 9.

 

E. Target under SDG 6 – To improve water quality by reducing pollution by 2030 — True.

 

Hence, the correct combination is A, B, C and E only.

Question 45
Match List–I with List–IIList–I(Type of Disaster)A. Biological DisasterB. Geophysical DisasterC. Hydro-Meteorological DisasterD. Anthropogenic DisasterList–II(Consequences)I. Flood, drought, stormII. Epidemic, insect infestationIII. Transport disaster, riotsIV. Earthquake, volcano, landslideChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A–IV, B–III, C–II, D–I
  • B.A–II, B–IV, C–III, D–I
  • C.A–II, B–IV, C–I, D–III
  • D.A–I, B–III, C–II, D–IV
Correct Answer: A–II, B–IV, C–I, D–III

A. Biological Disaster → (II) Epidemics, pandemics, insect infestations.

 

B. Geophysical Disaster → (IV) Earthquakes, volcanic eruptions, landslides.

 

C. Hydro-Meteorological Disaster → (I) Floods, droughts, storms, cyclones.

 

D. Anthropogenic Disaster → (III) Human-made events like transport accidents, industrial disasters, riots.

Question 46
Read the following passage and answer the questions (46–50):The stock-taking done at the first national convention on Consumer Protection served to highlight the areas slated for special attention to sustain the momentum of the movement of genuine concern for people’s interests. Spreading awareness about the rights of consumers has rightly been identified as the first priority.While this may not be a difficult task in urban areas, where the movement is concentrated at present, taking it to the vast rural hinterlands calls for a multi-media approach in which radio and television have a crucial role to play. The involvement of the 500-odd consumer organizations in the country in publicising the concept offair tradepractices and the remedies available against their violation will prove rewarding, if the message is conveyed through village bodies. Government efforts remain confined at best to setting up the infrastructure after the formal launch of the movement with the enactment of the Consumer Protection Act. The mounting backlog of cases in consumer courts points to the need for toning up the district-level redressal machinery.The first national convention on consumer protection has:
  • A.Highlighted the areas of special attention
  • B.Spread awareness about consumer rights
  • C.Provided guidelines to do away with substandard products
  • D.Criticised the Govt. apathy towards bringing awareness among consumers
Correct Answer: Highlighted the areas of special attention

The passage clearly states that the first national convention on consumer protection “served to highlight the areas slated for special attention.”

 

It focused on identifying key priority areas such as spreading consumer awareness and strengthening redressal mechanisms, not on criticizing the government or providing product guidelines.

Question 47
Read the following passage and answer the questions (46–50):The stock-taking done at the first national convention on Consumer Protection served to highlight the areas slated for special attention to sustain the momentum of the movement of genuine concern for people’s interests. Spreading awareness about the rights of consumers has rightly been identified as the first priority.While this may not be a difficult task in urban areas, where the movement is concentrated at present, taking it to the vast rural hinterlands calls for a multi-media approach in which radio and television have a crucial role to play. The involvement of the 500-odd consumer organizations in the country in publicising the concept offair tradepractices and the remedies available against their violation will prove rewarding, if the message is conveyed through village bodies. Government efforts remain confined at best to setting up the infrastructure after the formal launch of the movement with the enactment of the Consumer Protection Act. The mounting backlog of cases in consumer courts points to the need for toning up the district-level redressal machinery.For bringing awareness among consumers, whose role, according to the author, is more crucial?
  • A.Religious scriptures
  • B.Radio and television
  • C.Newspapers and textbooks
  • D.Heads of the villages or Sarpanch
Correct Answer: Radio and television

According to the passage, spreading consumer awareness in rural areas requires a multi-media approach, and radio and television are said to have a crucial role to play in reaching the vast rural population effectively.

Question 48
Read the following passage and answer the questions (46–50):The stock-taking done at the first national convention on Consumer Protection served to highlight the areas slated for special attention to sustain the momentum of the movement of genuine concern for people’s interests. Spreading awareness about the rights of consumers has rightly been identified as the first priority.While this may not be a difficult task in urban areas, where the movement is concentrated at present, taking it to the vast rural hinterlands calls for a multi-media approach in which radio and television have a crucial role to play. The involvement of the 500-odd consumer organizations in the country in publicising the concept offair tradepractices and the remedies available against their violation will prove rewarding, if the message is conveyed through village bodies. Government efforts remain confined at best to setting up the infrastructure after the formal launch of the movement with the enactment of the Consumer Protection Act. The mounting backlog of cases in consumer courts points to the need for toning up the district-level redressal machinery.Government contributed to the consumer protection movement by:
  • A.Toning up a district-level machinery
  • B.Cleaning the backlog cases in consumer courts
  • C.Setting up requisite infrastructure
  • D.Enactment of the Consumer Protection Act
Correct Answer: Setting up requisite infrastructure

In the passage, it says:

“Government efforts remain confined at best to setting up the infrastructure after the formal launch of the movement with the enactment of the Consumer Protection Act.”

 

This means while the Act formally launched the movement, the specific contribution of the government that the author highlights is the setting up of the requisite infrastructure, not the Act itself.

Question 49
Read the following passage and answer the questions (46–50):The stock-taking done at the first national convention on Consumer Protection served to highlight the areas slated for special attention to sustain the momentum of the movement of genuine concern for people’s interests. Spreading awareness about the rights of consumers has rightly been identified as the first priority.While this may not be a difficult task in urban areas, where the movement is concentrated at present, taking it to the vast rural hinterlands calls for a multi-media approach in which radio and television have a crucial role to play. The involvement of the 500-odd consumer organizations in the country in publicising the concept offair tradepractices and the remedies available against their violation will prove rewarding, if the message is conveyed through village bodies. Government efforts remain confined at best to setting up the infrastructure after the formal launch of the movement with the enactment of the Consumer Protection Act. The mounting backlog of cases in consumer courts points to the need for toning up the district-level redressal machinery.What, according to the author, will prove rewarding with reference to consumer protection?
  • A.Remedies against the violation offair tradepractices
  • B.Setting up more and more LokAdalats
  • C.Weekly campaign for bringing awareness
  • D.Rigorous punishment to the erring officials
Correct Answer: Remedies against the violation offair tradepractices

According to the passage:

“The involvement of the 500-odd consumer organizations in the country in publicising the concept of fair trade practices and the remedies available against their violation will prove rewarding, if the message is conveyed through village bodies.”

 

Thus, the author clearly states that spreading awareness about fair trade practices and the remedies against their violation will prove rewarding for the consumer protection movement.

Question 50
Read the following passage and answer the questions (46–50):The stock-taking done at the first national convention on Consumer Protection served to highlight the areas slated for special attention to sustain the momentum of the movement of genuine concern for people’s interests. Spreading awareness about the rights of consumers has rightly been identified as the first priority.While this may not be a difficult task in urban areas, where the movement is concentrated at present, taking it to the vast rural hinterlands calls for a multi-media approach in which radio and television have a crucial role to play. The involvement of the 500-odd consumer organizations in the country in publicising the concept offair tradepractices and the remedies available against their violation will prove rewarding, if the message is conveyed through village bodies. Government efforts remain confined at best to setting up the infrastructure after the formal launch of the movement with the enactment of the Consumer Protection Act. The mounting backlog of cases in consumer courts points to the need for toning up the district-level redressal machinery.Ensuring consumer protection in rural areas requires:
  • A.Establishing rural courts
  • B.Use of different media
  • C.Increasing LokAdalats
  • D.Empowering the Panchayats
Correct Answer: Use of different media

The passage states that spreading consumer awareness in rural areas “calls for a multi-media approach in which radio and television have a crucial role to play.”

Hence, using different media (radio, television, etc.) is essential to ensure consumer protection and awareness in rural regions.

Quiz Attempt #119701

Total Questions: 50
Question 1
Study the table given below and answer the questions that follow:The table below shows the cost price (in Rupees) and sale price (in Rupees) of four items for five years.YearItem AItem BItem CItem DCost PriceSale PriceCost PriceSale PriceCost PriceSale PriceCost PriceSale Price201520000023000010000011000025000287502500028750201614000016100015000016500027500316252750031900201721000024150016000017600040000440003000035100201818500021275019000020900033300382954000047200201917000019550019950022144534000391003400040460Which item maintains profit in the same percentage on cost every year?
  • A.A
  • B.B
  • C.C
  • D.D
Correct Answer: A

Profit % on cost for A each year = SP-CPCP×100 = 230000-200000200000×100 = 15%

and similarly for all years it comes out to 15%. For the other items, the percentage changes in at least one year. Thus, correct answer is option A.

Question 2
Study the table given below and answer the questions that follow:The table below shows the cost price (in Rupees) and sale price (in Rupees) of four items for five years.YearItem AItem BItem CItem DCost PriceSale PriceCost PriceSale PriceCost PriceSale PriceCost PriceSale Price201520000023000010000011000025000287502500028750201614000016100015000016500027500316252750031900201721000024150016000017600040000440003000035100201818500021275019000020900033300382954000047200201917000019550019950022144534000391003400040460Which item has profit in the same percentage on cost during first two and last two years only?
  • A.A
  • B.B
  • C.C
  • D.D
Correct Answer: C

This is for Item C.

Question 3
Study the table given below and answer the questions that follow:The table below shows the cost price (in Rupees) and sale price (in Rupees) of four items for five years.YearItem AItem BItem CItem DCost PriceSale PriceCost PriceSale PriceCost PriceSale PriceCost PriceSale Price201520000023000010000011000025000287502500028750201614000016100015000016500027500316252750031900201721000024150016000017600040000440003000035100201818500021275019000020900033300382954000047200201917000019550019950022144534000391003400040460Profit of which item increases by one percent every year?
  • A.A
  • B.B
  • C.C
  • D.D
Correct Answer: D

For Item D:

2015 = 28750-2500025000×100 = 15%

2016 = 31900-2750027500×100 = 16%

2017 = 35100-2000030000×100 = 17%

2018 = 47200-4000040000×100 = 18%

2019 = 40460-3400034000×100 = 19%

The profit percentage increases exactly by 1% every year.

Question 4
Study the table given below and answer the questions that follow:The table below shows the cost price (in Rupees) and sale price (in Rupees) of four items for five years.YearItem AItem BItem CItem DCost PriceSale PriceCost PriceSale PriceCost PriceSale PriceCost PriceSale Price201520000023000010000011000025000287502500028750201614000016100015000016500027500316252750031900201721000024150016000017600040000440003000035100201818500021275019000020900033300382954000047200201917000019550019950022144534000391003400040460Which item has 1% gain in the percentage of profit in the last year than its percentage of profit in the first year?
  • A.A
  • B.B
  • C.C
  • D.None of these
Correct Answer: B

Item A:

2015 = 230000-200000200000×100 = 15%

2019 = 195500-170000170000×100 = 15%

 

Item B:

2015 = 110000-100000100000×100 = 10%

2019 = 221445-199500199500×100 = 11%

 

Item C:

2015 = 28750-2500025000×100 = 15%

2019 = 39100-3400034000×100 = 15%

 

Item D:

2015 = 28750-2500025000×100 = 15%

2019 = 40460-3400034000×100 = 19%

Thus, Item B shows 1% gain.

Question 5
Study the table given below and answer the questions that follow:The table below shows the cost price (in Rupees) and sale price (in Rupees) of four items for five years.YearItem AItem BItem CItem DCost PriceSale PriceCost PriceSale PriceCost PriceSale PriceCost PriceSale Price201520000023000010000011000025000287502500028750201614000016100015000016500027500316252750031900201721000024150016000017600040000440003000035100201818500021275019000020900033300382954000047200201917000019550019950022144534000391003400040460What is the percentage of profit of sale price of item D in 2019 on the cost of 2015?
  • A.38.21%
  • B.57.29%
  • C.61.84%
  • D.68.21%
Correct Answer: 61.84%

required percentage = 40460-2500025000×100 = 61.84%.

Question 6
In which type of research, researcher observes the subjects by being a part of their group?
  • A.Action research
  • B.Ethnographic research
  • C.Descriptive survey
  • D.Experimental research
Correct Answer: Ethnographic research

In ethnographic research, the researcher immerses themselves in the natural setting of the group, becomes a part of their daily activities, and observes their behaviour, culture, and interactions from an insider’s perspective.

Question 7
Arrange the following steps of research in order of their occurrence:A. Deriving findingsB. Interpretation of the resultsC. Formulation of the hypothesisD. Defining the research problemE. Measuring the dependent variableChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.D, C, E, B, A
  • B.D, C, B, E, A
  • C.C, D, B, E, A
  • D.E, D, C, B, A
Correct Answer: D, C, E, B, A

Correct logical order of research steps:

 

D – Defining the research problem

(First, the researcher identifies and defines the problem.)

 

C – Formulation of the hypothesis

(After defining the problem, a hypothesis is formed.)

 

E – Measuring the dependent variable

(Data is collected by measuring variables.)

 

B – Interpretation of the results

(After analysis, results are interpreted.)

 

A – Deriving findings

(Final conclusions or findings are derived.)

Question 8
Which are the conditions for using parametric test for data analysis?A. N > 30B. Data follows normal distributionC. All the parameters must be knownD. Dependent variable is measured in interval or ratio scaleE. Homogeneity of varianceChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B and D Only
  • B.B, D and E Only
  • C.B, C and D Only
  • D.A, C and E Only
Correct Answer: B, D and E Only

For parametric tests, the commonly accepted conditions are:

 

  • Data follows normal distribution → (B)
  • Dependent variable is measured on interval or ratio scale → (D)
  • Homogeneity of variance (equal variances across groups) → (E)

 

N > 30 (A) is NOT a strict requirement; small samples can also use parametric tests if assumptions are met.

Question 9
Which of the following are the characteristics of distribution free non-parametric tests?A. They can be applied on original data obtained in any kind of scale.B. They require homogeneity of variance.C. They do not need any particular type of distribution.D. They cannot be used, if sample is selected randomly.E. They are quicker and easier than parametric tests.Choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B and C Only
  • B.D and E Only
  • C.C and E Only
  • D.A and E Only
Correct Answer: C and E Only

A is not acceptable because non-parametric tests are mainly suitable for nominal and ordinal data, not “any kind of scale.”

 

B is incorrect because non-parametric tests do not require homogeneity of variance.

 

C is correct because non-parametric tests do not assume any specific distribution.

 

D is incorrect because non-parametric tests can be used with randomly selected samples.

 

E is correct because non-parametric tests are simpler, quicker, and easier to apply than parametric tests.

 

Correct statements: C and E only.

Question 10
Match List – I with List – IIList – IA. Study of the lifestyle of Indian people between 1900 to 1947B. Testing significance of difference between job satisfaction of government and non-government employeesC. Study of effectiveness of Yoga exercises on mental health of policemenD. Study of nomadic people’s perception regarding their life in real situationList – III. Descriptive researchII. Ethnographic researchIII. Historical researchIV. Experimental researchChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A–II, B–III, C–IV, D–I
  • B.A–III, B–I, C–IV, D–II
  • C.A–IV, B–I, C–III, D–II
  • D.A–III, B–II, C–IV, D–I
Correct Answer: A–III, B–I, C–IV, D–II

A. Study of the lifestyle of Indian people between 1900 to 1947

→ This is a Historical research (because it studies the past).

 

B. Testing significance of difference between job satisfaction of government and non-government employees

→ This is Descriptive research (comparison of groups using statistical tests).

 

C. Study of effectiveness of Yoga exercises on mental health of policemen

→ This is Experimental research (cause–effect with intervention).

 

D. Study of nomadic people’s perception regarding their life in real situation

→ This is Ethnographic research (studying culture/life of a group in natural setting).

 

Correct matching:

A–III, B–I, C–IV, D–II.

Question 11
As per NEP 2020 document, National Research Foundation (NRF) will be governed by:
  • A.Council of ministers from state and centre
  • B.Committee of experts from UGC members
  • C.Rotating board of Governors consisting the best researchers and innovators across fields
  • D.Board of Governors from Department of Science and Technology
Correct Answer: Rotating board of Governors consisting the best researchers and innovators across fields

NEP 2020 states that the NRF will be led by a rotating Board of Governors made up of top researchers and innovators from different fields. This ensures expert, diverse, and high-quality leadership in promoting research across India.

Question 12
Which ancient University was located in present day Odisha and was prominent centre of Buddhist learning?
  • A.Nadia
  • B.Nalanda
  • C.Vikramshila
  • D.Pushpagiri
Correct Answer: Pushpagiri

Pushpagiri was an ancient Buddhist university located in present-day Odisha. It was a major centre of Buddhist studies and flourished alongside Nalanda and Vikramshila. Archaeological evidence from Lalitgiri, Ratnagiri, and Udayagiri supports its historical significance.

Question 13
Chronologically arrange the following organisations in order of their year ofestablishment :A. Niti AayogB. Planning CommissionC. University Grants Commission (UGC)D. Indian Council of Social Science Research (ICSSR)Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.B, C, A, D
  • B.D, C, B, A
  • C.D, B, A, C
  • D.B, C, D, A
Correct Answer: B, C, D, A

Planning Commission – 1950

UGC – 1956

ICSSR – 1969

NITI Aayog – 2015

 

Chronological order (earliest to latest):

B → C → D → A.

Question 14
Choose the correct statements about MOOC.A. Blackboard was formed in 1999 and became a public company in 2004B. ‘Connectivism and connected knowledge’ was first course to be called MOOCC. Stephen Downes coined the term ‘X-MOOC’ in 2012D.FutureLearnwas formed by U.K. Open University in December, 2012E. Open2Study was formed by Open University, U.S.A. in 2013Choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B, D, E Only
  • B.B, D, E Only
  • C.B, C, D Only
  • D.B, C, D, E Only
Correct Answer: B, C, D Only

B. ‘Connectivism and Connected Knowledge’ was first course to be called MOOC

This is correct. CCK08 (2008) by George Siemens & Stephen Downes is recognised as the first MOOC.

 

C. Stephen Downes coined the term ‘X-MOOC’ in 2012

For UGC NET and education literature, this statement is treated as correct. Downes is associated with distinguishing cMOOC vs xMOOC during 2012.

 

D. FutureLearn was formed by U.K. Open University in December 2012

This is correct.

Question 15
Match List – I with List – IIList – I(Education Commission)A. University Education CommissionB. Secondary Education CommissionC. Indian Universities CommissionD. National Knowledge CommissionList – II(Chairman)I. Mr. Sam PitrodaII. Thomas RaleighIII. Dr. S. RadhakrishnanIV. Dr. L. MudaliarChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A–II, B–IV, C–III, D–I
  • B.A–III, B–IV, C–II, D–I
  • C.A–II, B–I, C–III, D–IV
  • D.A–III, B–II, C–IV, D–I
Correct Answer: A–III, B–IV, C–II, D–I

A. University Education Commission (1948–49) – chaired by Dr. S. Radhakrishnan

 

B. Secondary Education Commission (1952–53) – chaired by Dr. L. Mudaliar

 

C. Indian Universities Commission (1902) – chaired by Thomas Raleigh

 

D. National Knowledge Commission (2005) – chaired by Sam Pitroda

 

So, the correct sequence is:

A–III, B–IV, C–II, D–I.

Question 16
Which one of these is a way to overcome communication barriers?
  • A.Respect each other’s differences
  • B.Using a translator
  • C.Not communicating to all
  • D.Using your own language for comfort
Correct Answer: Respect each other’s differences

Communication barriers reduce when people respect cultural, emotional, and personal differences. It helps create openness and understanding, which improves effective communication.

Question 17
Before the discovery of the paper, the people used to write on _______.
  • A.Mango leaf
  • B.Palm leaf
  • C.Lotus leaves
  • D.Banana leaf
Correct Answer: Palm leaf

Before paper was invented, people in ancient India commonly wrote on palm leaves, which were durable and easy to prepare for writing. These manuscripts are still found in many old temples and libraries.

Question 18
Arrange in sequence the following steps in the process of communication according to Shannon–Weaver model:A. FeedbackB. DestinationC. ReceptionD. TransmitterE. SourceChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, D, C, B, E
  • B.E, D, C, B, A
  • C.C, D, E, A, B
  • D.E, C, B, A, D
Correct Answer: E, D, C, B, A

According to the Shannon–Weaver model, the correct sequence of communication is:

  • Source → E
  • Transmitter → D
  • Reception (Receiver) → C
  • Destination → B
  • Feedback → A

 

Thus, the correct order is: E → D → C → B → A.

Question 19
Which among the following are the types of communication?A. GroupB. DreamingC. InterpersonalD. ReadingE. IntrapersonalChoose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, C, E Only
  • B.A, B, C Only
  • C.C, D, E Only
  • D.B, C, D Only
Correct Answer: A, C, E Only

A. Group communication – a valid type

C. Interpersonal communication – between two or more people

E. Intrapersonal communication – communication within oneself

 

B. Dreaming is not considered a formal type of communication.

D. Reading is a skill, not a type of communication.

Question 20
Match List – I with List – IIList – IA. Social mediaB. WebsiteC. E-mailD. SMSList – III. Method of sending longer messages along with attachment(s) via internetII. A method of sending small text messages from one mobile to anotherIII. Meta PlatformIV. A page or collection of pages on the internet about a particular subjectChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A–III, B–II, C–IV, D–I
  • B.A–III, B–IV, C–I, D–II
  • C.A–IV, B–III, C–II, D–I
  • D.A–II, B–I, C–III, D–IV
Correct Answer: A–III, B–IV, C–I, D–II

A. Social media → Meta Platform

B. Website → A page or collection of pages on the internet

C. E-mail → Method of sending longer messages with attachments

D. SMS → Small text messages from one mobile to another

 

So the correct pairing is:

A–III, B–IV, C–I, D–II.

Question 21
If PACE is coded as 2561925, then BALL will be coded as:
  • A.41144144
  • B.161141144
  • C.41441144
  • D.41641144
Correct Answer: 41144144

P = 16th letter → 16² = 256

A = 1st letter → 1² = 1

C = 3rd letter → 3² = 9

E = 5th letter → 5² = 25

 

Similarly,

B = 2nd letter → 2² = 4

A = 1st letter → 1² = 1

L = 12th letter → 12² = 144

L = 12th letter → 12² = 144

 

Code → 41144144.

Question 22
A shopkeeper procures milk at the cost of ₹60 per kg. After adulterating it with water (free of cost), he sells the milk to the customers at the price of ₹62 per kg, and makes a profit of 10%.In what ratio does he mix milk and water?
  • A.56 :1
  • B.31 :2
  • C.59 :1
  • D.41 :1
Correct Answer: 31 :2

Let milk and water be in the ratio x:y

CP = 621.1 = 62011

Then, 60xx+y = 62011

or

660x = 620x + 620y

or 40x = 620 y

or x: y = 620 : 40 = 31 : 2.

Question 23
Arrange the following in increasing order of their values:A.160.32×40.36B.125813+2713C.(1024)-15D.8125-13Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.B < D < A < C
  • B.B < C < D < A
  • C.C < D < B < A
  • D.C < B < D < A
Correct Answer: B < C < D < A

A. 160.32×40.36 = 21.28×20.72 = 4

B. 125813+2713 = 1252+3 = 15

C. (1024)-15 = (210)-15 = 14

D. 8125-13 = 52

So, the correct order is B < C < D < A

Question 24
Identify the correct statements.A. 3 successive discounts of 20%, 25% and 20% are equivalent to a single discount of 65%.B. The value of3433×196is equal to 98.C. A movement of 180° by minute hand results in 30° movement of hour hand.D. The total surface area of a solid cube of side 5 cm is 150 cm².Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B and C Only
  • B.B and C Only
  • C.A, C and D Only
  • D.B and D Only
Correct Answer: B and D Only

A. Three successive discounts of 20%, 25% and 20%

Net price factor = 0.8 × 0.75 × 0.8 = 0.48 → discount = 52%, not 65%. So A is false.

 

B. 3433×196 = 7 × 14 = 98

 

C. Minute hand moves 180° → that is 30 minutes.

Hour hand moves 0.5° per minute → in 30 minutes it moves 15°, not 30°. So C is false.

 

D. Total surface area of cube of side 5 cm= 6(5)2 = 150cm2

Thus, B and D are correct.

Question 25
Match List – I with List – IIList – IA. The compound interest on a sum of ₹200 at an interest rate of 10% compounded annually for two years is ₹__________B. The angle (in degree) traversed by the hour hand of a clock when the minute hand moves by 90° is_______________C. Average of 2, 6, 3, 4 and 5 is______________D. The next term in the series –1, 3, 7, ?List – III. 4II. 7.5III. 11IV. 42Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A–II, B–IV, C–I, D–III
  • B.A–IV, B–II, C–I, D–III
  • C.A–III, B–IV, C–I, D–II
  • D.A–II, B–IV, C–III, D–I
Correct Answer: A–IV, B–II, C–I, D–III

A. Compound interest on ₹200 at 10% for 2 years

After two years, the interest earned becomes ₹42 → matches IV

 

B. When minute hand moves 90 degrees

That is equal to 15 minutes. In 15 minutes, the hour hand moves 7.5 degrees → matches II

 

C. Average of 2, 6, 3, 4, 5

Their total is 20 and there are 5 numbers, so the average is 4 → matches I

 

D. Next term in –1, 3, 7, ?

Each time the number increases by 4, so the next term is 11 → matches III

 

So, the correct matching is:

 

A–IV, B–II, C–I, D–III.

Question 26
The term for universal concomitance in Indian Logic is:
  • A.Hetu
  • B.Drishtanta
  • C.Sadhya
  • D.Vyapti
Correct Answer: Vyapti

In Indian Logic, Vyapti means universal concomitance – a constant and invariable relationship between Hetu (reason) and Sadhya (proposition). It ensures that wherever the reason exists, the conclusion must also exist.

Question 27
Which means of knowledge (pramana) involves deriving knowledge from linguistic utterances of reliable persons?
  • A.Anumana
  • B.Arthapatti
  • C.Pratyaksha
  • D.Shabda
Correct Answer: Shabda

Shabda pramana refers to gaining valid knowledge through the words or statements of a trustworthy or authoritative person. It is the means of knowledge based on verbal testimony.

Question 28
Arrange the steps of constructing an analogical argument in correct sequence.A. Identify the target caseB. Evaluate relevance of the analogyC. Establish the shared attributeD. Draw an analogyE. Identify the known caseChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, E, D, C, B
  • B.D, E, A, C, B
  • C.B, C, D, A, E
  • D.E, A, C, D, B
Correct Answer: E, A, C, D, B

Identify the known case → E

Identify the target case → A

Establish the shared attribute → C

Draw an analogy → D

Evaluate the relevance of the analogy → B

 

So, the correct order is:

E → A → C → D → B.

Question 29
Which characteristics define an ideal analogy in logic?A. Shared attributesB. Similar structureC. Dissimilar subjectD. Clear relationChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A and B Only
  • B.A, B and C Only
  • C.A and C Only
  • D.A, B and D Only
Correct Answer: A, B and D Only

To form an ideal analogy in logic, the following must be present:

  • Shared attributes – The two things compared must have common features.
  • Similar structure – Their relationship or pattern should be similar.
  • Clear relation – The connection between compared elements should be clear and meaningful.

 

C (“Dissimilar subject”) is not required. Some differences may exist, but they are not a defining characteristic.

Question 30
Match List – I with List – IIList – I(Figures of Categorical Syllogism)A. FirstB. SecondC. ThirdD. FourthList – II(Structure)I. M–P, S–M → S–PII. P–M, S–M → S–PIII. M–P, M–S → S–PIV. P–M, M–S → S–PChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A–I, B–II, C–III, D–IV
  • B.A–II, B–I, C–IV, D–III
  • C.A–I, B–IV, C–II, D–III
  • D.A–IV, B–I, C–III, D–II
Correct Answer: A–I, B–II, C–III, D–IV

The standard structures of the four figures of categorical syllogism are:

 

First figure: M–P, S–M → S–P
