Second figure: P–M, S–M → S–P

Third figure: M–P, M–S → S–P

Fourth figure: P–M, M–S → S–P

 

Now let us match them:

A. First figure → I

B. Second figure → II

C. Third figure → III

D. Fourth figure → IV

 

So the correct matching is:

A–I, B–II, C–III, D–IV

Question 31
Spearman attributed in general factor of intelligence to ________, a concept that believed to be originated with Aristotle.
  • A.Hemispheric energy
  • B.Soul energy
  • C.Internal energy
  • D.Mental energy
Correct Answer: Mental energy

Spearman believed that the general factor (g) of intelligence comes from a single source he called “mental energy.” This idea traces back to Aristotle, who suggested that a central mental power underlies all intellectual activities.

Question 32
While defining relationship between Teachers and children, ________ use it as socially constructed development.
  • A.Ainsworth
  • B.Vygotsky
  • C.Bronfenbrenner
  • D.Dewey
Correct Answer: Vygotsky

Vygotsky explained that learning and development happen through social interaction. The teacher–child relationship is a socially constructed process where guidance, dialogue, and culture shape the child’s development.

Question 33
Arrange the following Committees/Commissions in chronological order, from oldest to latest.A. Education Commission on moral and spiritual valuesB. National Policy on EducationC. Committee on Religious and Moral InstructionsD. Committee on Emotional IntegrationE. Secondary Education CommissionChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, E, C, D, B
  • B.E, C, D, A, B
  • C.A, C, E, D, B
  • D.E, C, A, D, B
Correct Answer: E, C, D, A, B

Secondary Education Commission (1952–53)

Committee on Religious and Moral Instruction (1959)

Committee on Emotional Integration (1961)

Education Commission on Moral and Spiritual Values (1964–66, part of Kothari Commission work)

National Policy on Education (1968)

 

So, the correct sequence is:

E → C → D → A → B.

Question 34
Select the wrong statement.A. In Flander’s system, there are 10 categories of interaction analysisB. Teaching behaviour is ‘molar’ and not ‘molecular’C. In the teaching behaviour, influence is aimed at both the pupil and the teacherD. Teaching behaviour is not like any other form of human behaviourChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A and B Only
  • B.A and C Only
  • C.B and D Only
  • D.B and C Only
Correct Answer: B and D Only

A. In Flander’s system, there are 10 categories of interaction analysis

This is correct. FIACS has 10 categories.

 

B. Teaching behaviour is ‘molar’ and not ‘molecular’

This is correct. Teaching behaviour is seen as a whole unit (molar), not in tiny fragments.

 

C. In the teaching behaviour, influence is aimed at both the pupil and the teacher

This is incorrect. Influence in teaching behaviour is primarily from teacher to pupil, not both ways.

 

D. Teaching behaviour is not like any other form of human behaviour

This is incorrect. Teaching behaviour is a form of human behaviour, although specialized.

Question 35
Match List – I with List – IIList – I(Match models with their exponents)A. Anxiety ReductionB. Assertive TrainingC. Direct TrainingD. Programmed InstructionList – III. Wolpe and LazarusII. B. F. SkinnerIII. Rinn and WolpeIV.LumsloaineChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A–III, B–IV, C–II, D–I
  • B.A–II, B–IV, C–I, D–III
  • C.A–III, B–I, C–IV, D–II
  • D.A–III, B–I, C–II, D–IV
Correct Answer: A–III, B–I, C–IV, D–II

A. Anxiety Reduction → Rinn and Wolpe

B. Assertive Training → Wolpe and Lazarus

C. Direct Training → Lumsdaine

D. Programmed Instruction → B. F. Skinne.

Question 36
Which of the following is not a characteristic of a computer?
  • A.It is free from monotony.
  • B.It is immensely versatile.
  • C.It has its own intelligence.
  • D.It is devoid of emotions
Correct Answer: It has its own intelligence.

A computer can work without getting tired (monotony-free), can perform many types of tasks (versatile), and has no emotions. But it does not have its own intelligence—it only follows the instructions given to it.

Question 37
MS-DOS stands for:
  • A.Microsoft Disk Operating System
  • B.Micro Software for Digital Operating Systems
  • C.Macro Software for Digital Operating Systems
  • D.Microsoft Digital Operating Systems
Correct Answer: Microsoft Disk Operating System

MS-DOS is an operating system developed by Microsoft, and it stands for Microsoft Disk Operating System.

Question 38
Choose the wrong statements.A. ‘CD’ is an example of optical deviceB. ‘Floppy’ is an example of magnetic deviceC. ‘Pen drive’ is an example of magnetic state deviceD. ‘Memory Card’ is an example of crystal state deviceChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A and B Only
  • B.C and D Only
  • C.B and D Only
  • D.B and C Only
Correct Answer: C and D Only

A. ‘CD’ is an optical device

This is correct. CDs use optical laser technology.

 

B. ‘Floppy’ is a magnetic device

This is correct. Floppy disks store data magnetically.

 

C. ‘Pen drive’ is a magnetic state device

Wrong. Pen drives use flash memory, not magnetic storage.

 

D. ‘Memory card’ is a crystal state device

Wrong. Memory cards also use flash memory, not crystal storage.

Question 39
Choose the wrong statements.A. ‘Brihaspati’ is anopen sourcee-learning platformB. ‘Lekhika-2007’ is a program developed by C-DACC. ‘Gyan-Dakshina’ is a bouquet of FM radio channelsD. ‘SakshatPortal’ was launched in 2014E. ‘Shruti-Drishti’ is developed for empoweringhearing impairedwomenChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B and D Only
  • B.C, D and E Only
  • C.B, C and D Only
  • D.A, C and E Only
Correct Answer: C, D and E Only

A. ‘Brihaspati’ is an open-source e-learning platform

Correct. Developed by IIT Kanpur.

 

B. ‘Lekhika-2007’ is a program developed by C-DAC

Correct. It is a language processing/document creation tool by C-DAC.

 

C. ‘Gyan-Dakshina’ is a bouquet of FM radio channels

Wrong. It is not related to FM radio channels.

 

D. ‘Sakshat Portal’ was launched in 2014

Wrong. Sakshat was launched around 2006, not 2014.

 

E. ‘Shruti-Drishti’ is developed for empowering hearing-impaired women

Wrong. Shruti–Drishti is actually developed for visually impaired persons, not hearing impaired.

Question 40
Match List – I with List – IIList – I(Output device)A. CRT monitorB. Flat-Panel monitorC. PrinterD. ProjectorList – II(Function)I. UsesaLCD screen to display outputII. Transforms a text document to a physical formatIII. Acts as a transmitterIV. Uses an electron beam to ‘paint’ a pictureChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A–II, B–III, C–IV, D–I
  • B.A–IV, B–I, C–II, D–III
  • C.A–III, B–IV, C–II, D–I
  • D.A–III, B–I, C–IV, D–II
Correct Answer: A–IV, B–I, C–II, D–III

A. CRT monitor → uses an electron beam to paint the picture → IV

B. Flat-Panel monitor → uses an LCD screen → I

C. Printer → converts text to physical format → II

D. Projector → acts as a transmitter/display device → III

 

So the correct matching is:

A–IV, B–I, C–II, D–III.

Question 41
What is teratogenic defect due to chemical agents?
  • A.Bone defect due to exposure to chemicals
  • B.Hemoglobinmalfunctioning due to chemicals
  • C.Bone marrow defect due to chemicals
  • D.Birth defect due to utero exposure to chemicals
Correct Answer: Birth defect due to utero exposure to chemicals

A teratogenic defect is a birth defect caused when a fetus is exposed to harmful chemicals, drugs, or other agents during pregnancy. These chemicals interfere with normal fetal development.

Question 42
Endocrine disruption chemicals:
  • A.Stimulate or retard production of hormones
  • B.Stimulate enzyme production
  • C.Inhibit DNA production
  • D.Increase m-RNA sequencing
Correct Answer: Stimulate or retard production of hormones

Endocrine-disrupting chemicals interfere with the hormone system. They can increase, decrease, or block hormone production, or mimic natural hormones, causing harmful effects on growth, reproduction, and development.

Question 43
Arrange the following environment related days in chronological orderA. World Health DayB. World Environment DayC. Earth DayD. World Ozone DayChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, C, B, D
  • B.D, C, A, B
  • C.B, D, C, A
  • D.C, D, A, B
Correct Answer: A, C, B, D

World Health Day → 7 April

Earth Day → 22 April

World Environment Day → 5 June

World Ozone Day → 16 September.

Question 44
Choose the correct statements from the following.A. Rivers are flowing water aquatic ecosystemsB. Ponds are still water aquatic ecosystemsC. Streams are still water aquatic ecosystemsD. Deltas are brackish water aquatic ecosystemsChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A and B Only
  • B.C and D Only
  • C.A, B and D Only
  • D.A, B and C Only
Correct Answer: A, B and D Only

A. Rivers are flowing water ecosystems

Correct – rivers come under lotic (flowing) water.

 

B. Ponds are still water ecosystems

Correct – ponds come under lentic (still) water.

 

C. Streams are still water ecosystems

Incorrect – streams are flowing (lotic) water like rivers.

 

D. Deltas are brackish water ecosystems

Correct – deltas mix river water and sea water, creating brackish conditions.

 

Correct statements: A, B and D.

Question 45
Match List – I with List – IIList – I(Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs))A. SDG 7B. SDG 6C. SDG 3D. SDG 5List – II(Objective)I. Clean water and sanitationII. Good health and well-beingIII. Gender equalityIV. Affordable energyChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A–IV, B–I, C–II, D–III
  • B.A–IV, B–II, C–III, D–I
  • C.A–II, B–IV, C–I, D–III
  • D.A–III, B–II, C–I, D–IV
Correct Answer: A–IV, B–I, C–II, D–III

SDG 7 → Affordable and Clean Energy

SDG 6 → Clean Water and Sanitation

SDG 3 → Good Health and Well-being

SDG 5 → Gender Equality.

Question 46
Read the following passage and answer thequestions :The reformer must know that what moves people is the authentic life, not mere writing. The newspaper and journals that Lokmanya Tilak and other reformers ran, the books they wrote, sold little, but had enormous effect. Their writing was known to reflect and be just an extension of, their exemplary lives. It was the authenticity of their lives which lent weight to their message, to their example. All knew that their lives were an integral whole — they were not moral in public life and lax in private, nor vice versa. They were not full of pious thoughts and scared resolutions within the walls of a temple.A writer who is merely entertaining his readers, even one who is merely informing them, can do what he wants with the rest of his life. But the writer, who sets out to use his pen to reform public life, cannot afford such dualities. Here is the testimony of one great man about the influence of another, Lokmanya Tilak.“I believe that an editor who has anything worth saying and who commands a clientele cannot be easily hushed. He delivered his finished message as soon as he is put under duress. The Lokmanya spoke more eloquently from the Mandalay fortress than through columns of the printed Kesari.”It is the ________ that influences the people more.
  • A.Reading habit
  • B.Writing ability
  • C.Revolutionary life
  • D.Authentic life
Correct Answer: Authentic life

The passage clearly states that people were influenced not by mere writing but by the authentic, exemplary lives of reformers like Lokmanya Tilak. Their actions and integrity gave power to their message.

Question 47
Read the following passage and answer thequestions :The reformer must know that what moves people is the authentic life, not mere writing. The newspaper and journals that Lokmanya Tilak and other reformers ran, the books they wrote, sold little, but had enormous effect. Their writing was known to reflect and be just an extension of, their exemplary lives. It was the authenticity of their lives which lent weight to their message, to their example. All knew that their lives were an integral whole — they were not moral in public life and lax in private, nor vice versa. They were not full of pious thoughts and scared resolutions within the walls of a temple.A writer who is merely entertaining his readers, even one who is merely informing them, can do what he wants with the rest of his life. But the writer, who sets out to use his pen to reform public life, cannot afford such dualities. Here is the testimony of one great man about the influence of another, Lokmanya Tilak.“I believe that an editor who has anything worth saying and who commands a clientele cannot be easily hushed. He delivered his finished message as soon as he is put under duress. The Lokmanya spoke more eloquently from the Mandalay fortress than through columns of the printed Kesari.”In the context of the passage, a reformer becomes effective if he is a:
  • A.Firebrand speaker
  • B.An author with an excellent style of writing
  • C.Person with consistency in his writing and life style
  • D.Reflective thinker
Correct Answer: Person with consistency in his writing and life style

The passage says reformers were effective because their lives matched their message. They were authentic, consistent, and morally whole — not different in public and private life.

Question 48
Read the following passage and answer thequestions :The reformer must know that what moves people is the authentic life, not mere writing. The newspaper and journals that Lokmanya Tilak and other reformers ran, the books they wrote, sold little, but had enormous effect. Their writing was known to reflect and be just an extension of, their exemplary lives. It was the authenticity of their lives which lent weight to their message, to their example. All knew that their lives were an integral whole — they were not moral in public life and lax in private, nor vice versa. They were not full of pious thoughts and scared resolutions within the walls of a temple.A writer who is merely entertaining his readers, even one who is merely informing them, can do what he wants with the rest of his life. But the writer, who sets out to use his pen to reform public life, cannot afford such dualities. Here is the testimony of one great man about the influence of another, Lokmanya Tilak.“I believe that an editor who has anything worth saying and who commands a clientele cannot be easily hushed. He delivered his finished message as soon as he is put under duress. The Lokmanya spoke more eloquently from the Mandalay fortress than through columns of the printed Kesari.”What made Tilak’s writings very effective?
  • A.They were reflective and truly represented his exemplary life
  • B.They were full of information
  • C.They were critical
  • D.They comprised of beautiful phrases and idioms
Correct Answer: They were reflective and truly represented his exemplary life

The passage says Tilak’s writings had enormous effect because they were an extension of his authentic and exemplary life. His life gave weight and power to his words, making them highly effective.

Question 49
Read the following passage and answer thequestions :The reformer must know that what moves people is the authentic life, not mere writing. The newspaper and journals that Lokmanya Tilak and other reformers ran, the books they wrote, sold little, but had enormous effect. Their writing was known to reflect and be just an extension of, their exemplary lives. It was the authenticity of their lives which lent weight to their message, to their example. All knew that their lives were an integral whole — they were not moral in public life and lax in private, nor vice versa. They were not full of pious thoughts and scared resolutions within the walls of a temple.A writer who is merely entertaining his readers, even one who is merely informing them, can do what he wants with the rest of his life. But the writer, who sets out to use his pen to reform public life, cannot afford such dualities. Here is the testimony of one great man about the influence of another, Lokmanya Tilak.“I believe that an editor who has anything worth saying and who commands a clientele cannot be easily hushed. He delivered his finished message as soon as he is put under duress. The Lokmanya spoke more eloquently from the Mandalay fortress than through columns of the printed Kesari.”In the context of passage, Tilak seemed to be:
  • A.A great writer
  • B.An effective teacher
  • C.A better speaker
  • D.A wonderful poet
Correct Answer: A better speaker

The passage states that Tilak “spoke more eloquently from the Mandalay fortress than through the printed columns of Kesari,” indicating that he was considered a more powerful and effective speaker than writer.

Question 50
Read the following passage and answer thequestions :The reformer must know that what moves people is the authentic life, not mere writing. The newspaper and journals that Lokmanya Tilak and other reformers ran, the books they wrote, sold little, but had enormous effect. Their writing was known to reflect and be just an extension of, their exemplary lives. It was the authenticity of their lives which lent weight to their message, to their example. All knew that their lives were an integral whole — they were not moral in public life and lax in private, nor vice versa. They were not full of pious thoughts and scared resolutions within the walls of a temple.A writer who is merely entertaining his readers, even one who is merely informing them, can do what he wants with the rest of his life. But the writer, who sets out to use his pen to reform public life, cannot afford such dualities. Here is the testimony of one great man about the influence of another, Lokmanya Tilak.“I believe that an editor who has anything worth saying and who commands a clientele cannot be easily hushed. He delivered his finished message as soon as he is put under duress. The Lokmanya spoke more eloquently from the Mandalay fortress than through columns of the printed Kesari.”Which of the following words used in the passage is synonymous with the word ‘holy’?
  • A.Authentic
  • B.Exemplary
  • C.Pious
  • D.Impure
Correct Answer: Pious

The word pious means holy, religious, or devoted, which matches the meaning of “holy” in the passage.

Quiz Attempt #119702

Total Questions: 50
Question 1
Study the table given below and answer the questions:The table gives the breakup of expenses (in percentage) incurred on various heads in organizing a cultural event in a college.HeadTent ItemSound SystemInvitationLightingFoodPoster MakingExpenses (%)20%15%10%20%25%10%If the college has paid ₹41,200 for Tent Items, then how much amount has been paid for Food?
  • A.₹32,960
  • B.₹51,500
  • C.₹41,200
  • D.₹10,300
Correct Answer: ₹51,500

Total Expense = 412000.2 = 206000

Food = 25% of 206000 = Rs. 51500.

Question 2
Study the table given below and answer the questions:The table gives the breakup of expenses (in percentage) incurred on various heads in organizing a cultural event in a college.HeadTent ItemSound SystemInvitationLightingFoodPoster MakingExpenses (%)20%15%10%20%25%10%If the amount paid for Lighting was ₹24,690, then how much total amount was paid for Tent Items and Poster Making?
  • A.₹24,690
  • B.₹12,345
  • C.₹37,035
  • D.₹49,380
Correct Answer: ₹37,035

Total Expense = 246900.2 = 123450

Tent and poster making = 30% of 123450 = Rs. 37035.

Question 3
Study the table given below and answer the questions:The table gives the breakup of expenses (in percentage) incurred on various heads in organizing a cultural event in a college.HeadTent ItemSound SystemInvitationLightingFoodPoster MakingExpenses (%)20%15%10%20%25%10%If the total expenditure was ₹43,000 (Forty-three thousand rupees), then what is the difference of amounts between the highest paid Head and two lowest paid Heads taken together?
  • A.₹2,150
  • B.₹4,650
  • C.₹4,300
  • D.₹8,600
Correct Answer: ₹2,150

Required Difference = (25 – 20) % of 43000 = Rs. 2150.

Question 4
Study the table given below and answer the questions:The table gives the breakup of expenses (in percentage) incurred on various heads in organizing a cultural event in a college.HeadTent ItemSound SystemInvitationLightingFoodPoster MakingExpenses (%)20%15%10%20%25%10%If the combined amount paid for the Tent Items and Lighting was ₹24,690, then how much combined amount was paid for Food and the Sound System?
  • A.₹12,345
  • B.₹24,690
  • C.₹37,035
  • D.₹49,380
Correct Answer: ₹24,690

Total expense = 246900.4 = 61725

Food and the Sound System = 40% of 61725 = Rs. 24690.

Question 5
Study the table given below and answer the questions:The table gives the breakup of expenses (in percentage) incurred on various heads in organizing a cultural event in a college.HeadTent ItemSound SystemInvitationLightingFoodPoster MakingExpenses (%)20%15%10%20%25%10%What is the difference between the expenses on Food and Poster Making, if we assume that the total expenses of the event were ₹67,880?
  • A.₹16,970
  • B.₹6,788
  • C.₹23,758
  • D.₹10,182
Correct Answer: ₹10,182

Required difference = 15% of 67880 = Rs. 10182.

Question 6
In which of the following acts, researcher does not maintain research ethics?
  • A.Converts interval scale data into ordinal scale data to apply non-parametric test
  • B.Does not disseminate the findings of research
  • C.Shares confidential information of the subjects with others
  • D.Collects data from secondary sources
Correct Answer: Shares confidential information of the subjects with others

(A) Converts interval data into ordinal data

This is a methodological choice, not an unethical act. Researchers often do this to use non-parametric tests. No ethical violation.

 

(B) Does not disseminate findings

Not unethical. A researcher may choose not to publish results (e.g., incomplete data, sponsor restrictions). It is not a breach of ethics.

 

(C) Shares confidential information of the subjects with others

This is a serious violation of research ethics. Confidentiality and privacy must always be protected.

 

(D) Collects data from secondary sources

This is allowed and does not violate ethics.

Question 7
Descriptions of some measurements are given below. Select correct order to arrange them from lower level of scales of measurement involved in them to higher level.A. Height of the students measured incentimetersB. Marks are given to the students after assessing their answer books of English languageC. Students are informed about their relative positions based on their performance in singing competitionD. Number of students of different subjects are counted in a particular collegeChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B, C, D
  • B.D, C, B, A
  • C.C, B, A, D
  • D.A, D, C, B
Correct Answer: D, C, B, A

The information about students’ relative positions in a singing competition represents ranking, so it belongs to the ordinal level.

 

Next comes the interval scale, where marks given to students fall, because marks have equal intervals but do not have a true zero.

 

Finally, both height in centimeters and number of students belong to the ratio scale, since these measurements have equal units and a meaningful zero point.

 

So, the correct order is C, B, A, D.

Question 8
Identify the sources of hypothesis formulation.A. Sampling method used for researchB. Reports of earlier researchC. Beliefs prevailing in the area of selected problemD. Prior experience of researcher in the area of selected problemE. Type of populationChoose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.B, C and D Only
  • B.B, C and E Only
  • C.A, C and E Only
  • D.C, D and E Only
Correct Answer: B, C and D Only

Sources that help a researcher formulate a hypothesis usually come from existing knowledge, beliefs, prior studies, and personal experience.

 

Reports of earlier research provide tested ideas and gaps that can inspire new hypotheses. Beliefs or commonly held assumptions in the area of the problem also guide the formation of tentative statements. Similarly, a researcher’s prior experience helps them identify patterns and predict relationships.

 

On the other hand, sampling method or type of population are methodological choices, not sources of hypothesis formulation.

 

Therefore, the correct sources are B, C and D only.

Question 9
Identify non-probability sampling methods.A. Systematic samplingB. Purposive samplingC. Quota samplingD. Stratified random samplingE. Snow-ball samplingChoose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.B, C and E Only
  • B.A, B and E Only
  • C.A, B and C Only
  • D.A, B, C and E Only
Correct Answer: B, C and E Only

Non-probability sampling methods are those in which every member of the population does not have a known or equal chance of being selected.

 

Purposive sampling is non-probability because the researcher selects participants based on judgment. Quota sampling is also non-probability as fixed numbers are taken from specific groups without random selection. Snowball sampling is non-probability because existing participants recruit future participants.

 

Systematic sampling and stratified random sampling both belong to probability sampling.

 

So, the correct non-probability methods are B, C and E only.

Question 10
Match List–I with List–IIList–I(Problem)A. Development of theory of relativityB. Comparison of the effect of two teaching methods on the achievement of students in a science subjectC. Study of the reasons of lack of commitment of the employees of an organization towards their dutiesD. Study of educational thoughts emerging from the speech of a social reformerList–II(Type of Research)I. Action researchII. Qualitative researchIII. Fundamental (basic) researchIV. Applied researchChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A–III, B–IV, C–I, D–II
  • B.A–IV, B–I, C–III, D–II
  • C.A–I, B–IV, C–II, D–III
  • D.A–III, B–II, C–IV, D–I
Correct Answer: A–III, B–IV, C–I, D–II

A. Development of the theory of relativity

This is an example of Fundamental (basic) research, because it aims at developing new theoretical knowledge without immediate practical application.

 

B. Comparison of the effect of two teaching methods on students’ achievement

This is Applied research, as it attempts to solve an educational problem by comparing teaching methods.

 

C. Study of reasons for lack of employee commitment

This focuses on understanding human behaviour and organizational issues, so it fits Qualitative research.

 

D. Study of educational thoughts from a reformer’s speech

Analyzing speech content and deriving educational ideas also falls under Qualitative research, but since only one statement must match II, we check the intended key:

The speech-based interpretative study is clearly Qualitative research, so D → II.

 

But C must match either Action or Applied. Studying commitment issues to improve organization performance fits Action research, because it aims to solve an immediate problem in an organization.

Question 11
Which of the following articles of the Indian Constitution is related to “Right of minorities to establish and administer educational institutions”?
  • A.Art. 28
  • B.Art. 29
  • C.Art. 30
  • D.Art. 31 A
Correct Answer: Art. 30

Article 30 of the Indian Constitution specifically grants minorities—whether based on religion or language—the right to establish and administer educational institutions of their choice.

Question 12
It is said thatTakshashilaUniversity was named after Taksha, son of ________.
  • A.BuddaguptaRaja
  • B.Kanda, the younger son ofGandharvas
  • C.Tathagata Gupta Raja
  • D.Bharata, the younger brother of Rama of Ramayana
Correct Answer: Bharata, the younger brother of Rama of Ramayana

According to ancient texts, Takshashila (Taxila) was named after Taksha, the son of Bharata, who was the younger brother of Lord Rama.

 

Taksha ruled the region, and the kingdom and city were named Taksha-khand and Taksha-shila, which later evolved into Takshashila.

Question 13
Arrange the following institutions chronologically as per their year of establishment:A. Banaras Hindu UniversityB. Jawaharlal Nehru UniversityC. Indian Institute of Science (IISc) BangaloreD. University of DelhiChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.B, C, D, A
  • B.C, A, D, B
  • C.C, B, A, D
  • D.D, A, B, C
Correct Answer: C, A, D, B

Indian Institute of Science (IISc), Bangalore – 1909

Banaras Hindu University (BHU) – 1916

University of Delhi (DU) – 1922

Jawaharlal Nehru University (JNU) – 1969

 

So, the correct chronological order is:

C → A → D → B.

Question 14
Choose the correct statements about Post-Vedic Education:A.Post-Vediceducation was not meant only for the sake of education. It was for the sake of life.B. Self-study was emphasized.C. Upanishads are known as ‘Para-Vidya’.D. The student who studied three Vedas was called ‘Vaidya’.E. Upanishads are considered to be above all kinds of material knowledge.Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B, C, D Only
  • B.A, C, D, E Only
  • C.B, C, D, E Only
  • D.A, B, C, E Only
Correct Answer: A, B, C, E Only

A. Post-Vedic education was not meant only for education but for life.

This is correct. Education focused on the overall development of personality and spiritual growth.

 

B. Self-study was emphasized.

True. Svādhyāya (self-study) was a key feature of Upanishadic education.

 

C. Upanishads are known as ‘Para-Vidya’.

Correct. Para-Vidya refers to higher knowledge (spiritual knowledge), which Upanishads represent.

 

D. The student who studied three Vedas was called ‘Vaidya’.

Incorrect. A student who mastered three Vedas was called Trayi-vidya or Trivedi, not Vaidya.

Vaidya means physician.

 

E. Upanishads are considered above all kinds of material knowledge.

Correct. They deal with spiritual and philosophical knowledge, superior to material (Apara-Vidya) knowledge.

 

So, the correct statements are: A, B, C and E.

Question 15
Match List–I with List–IIList–I(Language)A. BodoB. PunjabiC. SindhiD. NepaliList–II(Year of inclusion in Eighth Schedule)I. 1950II. 1967III. 1992IV. 2003Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A–III, B–II, C–IV, D–I
  • B.A–II, B–III, C–IV, D–I
  • C.A–IV, B–I, C–II, D–III
  • D.A–IV, B–III, C–I, D–II
Correct Answer: A–IV, B–I, C–II, D–III

Punjabi → 1967 (added by 21st Amendment)

Sindhi → 1967 (added by 21st Amendment)

Nepali → 1992 (added by 71st Amendment)

Bodo → 2003 (added by 92nd Amendmen.

Question 16
Which one among the following is not a barrier to communication?
  • A.Organizational
  • B.Personal
  • C.Cultural
  • D.Linguistic
Correct Answer: Personal

In many UGC/education frameworks, organizational, cultural, and linguistic barriers are categorized explicitly as formal communication barriers.

 

Personal barriers, however, are often treated separately as individual limitations (like attitude, emotions, or lack of listening skills), not as structural communication barriers.

Question 17
Which one of the following is not a social networking site?
  • A.YouTube
  • B.Facebook
  • C.Twitter
  • D.Khan Academy
Correct Answer: Khan Academy

YouTube, Facebook, and Twitter are all social networking or social media platforms where users interact, share content, and build networks.

 

Khan Academy, on the other hand, is an educational platform, not a social networking site.

Question 18
Arrange the following according to evolution of music players in chronological order, from past to present:A. Audio CassetteB. CDC. RadioD. GramophoneE. DVDChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.C, A, B, E, D
  • B.D, C, A, B, E
  • C.A, B, E, D, C
  • D.D, E, B, C, A
Correct Answer: D, C, A, B, E

Gramophone – Invented in the late 1800s

Radio – Became popular in the early 1900s

Audio Cassette – Introduced in the 1960s

CD (Compact Disc) – Came in the 1980s

DVD – Introduced in the mid-1990s

 

So, the correct chronological sequence is:

D → C → A → B → E

Question 19
Effective communication can be achieved by adopting the following strategies:A. Improving the clarity of message to communicateB. Selection of appropriate channel (technology) to communicateC. Using proper environment to facilitate communicationD. Creating anxiety and fear to facilitate communicationE. Providing overloaded information to communicateChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, C, D Only
  • B.A, B, C Only
  • C.B, C, D Only
  • D.C, D, E Only
Correct Answer: A, B, C Only

Effective communication requires clarity, appropriate channels, and a supportive environment.

 

A. Improving clarity of message → Helps communication

B. Selecting appropriate channel/technology → Helps communication

C. Using proper environment → Helps communication

D. Creating anxiety and fear → Hinders communication

E. Providing overloaded information → Confuses and blocks communication

 

So only A, B and C aid effective communication.

Question 20
Match List–I with List–IIList–I(Publication)A. FilmfareB. Dainik JagranC. The God of Small ThingsD. Chacha ChaudharyList–II(Type of Media)I. NewspaperII. BookIII. MagazineIV. ComicsChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A–I, B–II, C–III, D–IV
  • B.A–III, B–I, C–II, D–IV
  • C.A–III, B–II, C–IV, D–I
  • D.A–IV, B–I, C–II, D–III
Correct Answer: A–III, B–I, C–II, D–IV

Filmfare → a magazine

Dainik Jagran → a newspaper

The God of Small Things → a book

Chacha Chaudhary → a comic.

Question 21
Determine the next term (?) in the following letter series.BYD, EVJ, HSP, KPV, ?, ...
  • A.NMB
  • B.NMX
  • C.MNB
  • D.MBN
Correct Answer: NMB

First letters: B, E, H, K → positions 2, 5, 8, 11 → each time +3 → next is 14 → N

 

Second letters: Y, V, S, P → positions 25, 22, 19, 16 → each time −3 → next is 13 → M

 

Third letters: D, J, P, V → positions 4, 10, 16, 22 → each time +6 → next is 28 → wrap after Z (26), so 28 → 2 → B

 

So, next term will be NMB.

Question 22
Two identical containers P and Q contain mixture of milk and water in the ratio 1:1 and 3:1 respectively. In what ratio should mixtures be taken out from P and Q so that milk to water ratio becomes 5:4?
  • A.5:2
  • B.7:2
  • C.2:7
  • D.2:5
Correct Answer: 7:2

Required final ratio = 5 : 4

Let mixture taken from P = x and from Q = y.

Container P ratio = 1:1 → milk = 0.5, water = 0.5

Container Q ratio = 3:1 → milk = 0.75, water = 0.25

Now, 0.5x+0.75y0.5x+0.25y = 54

or xy = 7 : 2.

Question 23
Arrange the following fractions in decreasing order of their values.A.1318B.911C.1113D.78Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.C > D > B > A
  • B.D > C > A > B
  • C.D > A > B > C
  • D.D > C > B > A
Correct Answer: D > C > B > A

A. 1318 = 0.722

B. 911 = 0.818

C. 1113 = 0.846

D. 78 = 0.875

So, D > C > B > A.

Question 24
Identify the correct statements.A. The angle between the hour hand and the minute hand at 2:40 PM is 130°.B. If x³ = 1331, then x = 11.C. The area of a 1.0 m wide track around a rectangular sports field of dimensions 20 m × 18 m is 80 m².D.18thof100013is equal to 5.Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B and C Only
  • B.A, B, C and D
  • C.B, C and D Only
  • D.A, C and D Only
Correct Answer: B, C and D Only

At 2:40, the hour and minute hands make an angle of 160°, not 130°.

So this statement is false.

 

11 × 11 × 11 = 1331, so this statement is true.

 

Outer dimensions become 22 m × 20 m.

Outer area = 440 m², inner area = 360 m², difference = 80 m².

So this statement is true.

 

18 of 1000 is 125; cube root of 125 is 5.

So, this statement is true.

Question 25
Match List–I with List–IIList–I(Statements)A. Duration of 1 minute and 12 seconds is what percent of 1/2 hour?B. 30% of apples out of 30 are bad. The number of good apples is ____C. The population of a country increases from 25 million to 30 million. The percentage increase is ____D. 1.14 expressed as percent of 6.0 is ____List–II(Answers)I. 19II. 4III. 21IV. 20Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A–II, B–III, C–I, D–IV
  • B.A–II, B–III, C–IV, D–I
  • C.A–III, B–II, C–I, D–IV
  • D.A–IV, B–III, C–II, D–I
Correct Answer: A–II, B–III, C–IV, D–I

A. Percentage = 72180×100 = 4%

B. Good apples = 0.7 × 30 = 21

C. Percentage increase = 30-2525×100 = 20%

D. Required % = 1.146×100 = 19%.

Question 26
Which of the following is an analogous statement?
  • A.God is great
  • B.Man is like God
  • C.Gandhiji is the father of the nation
  • D.Man is mortal
Correct Answer: Man is like God

logic, an analogous statement compares one thing with another using similarity (often with words like “like” or “as”).

 

“Man is like God” is clearly making a comparison based on similarity, so it is an analogical statement.

 

The others are not analogies:

“God is great” – simple assertion

“Gandhiji is the father of the nation” – honorary/title statement

“Man is mortal” – universal factual statement.

Question 27
Which of the following is converse of ‘SomeR areF’?
  • A.Some F are not R
  • B.SomeR arenot F
  • C.No F is R
  • D.Some F are R
Correct Answer: Some F are R

The converse of a proposition is formed by interchanging the subject and the predicate.

Given statement:

Some R are F

Converse:

Some F are R.

Question 28
In constructing a categorical syllogism, arrange the following in order.A. Identify the minor premiseB. Identify the major premiseC. Determine the conclusionD. Check mood and figureChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B, D, C
  • B.B, A, D, C
  • C.D, A, B, C
  • D.A, C, D, B
Correct Answer: B, A, D, C

When constructing a categorical syllogism, the proper sequence is:

  • Identify the major premise – This contains the major term (predicate of the conclusion).
  • Identify the minor premise – This contains the minor term (subject of the conclusion).
  • Check the mood and figure – Mood depends on the types of propositions (A, E, I, O), and figure depends on the position of the middle term.
  • Determine the conclusion – Finally, derive the logical conclusion based on the premises.

 

So, the correct order is:

Major premise → Minor premise → Mood & figure → Conclusion.

Question 29
There are four arguments A, B, C and D in the context of the statement given below. You have to decide which of the argument(s) is/are strong.Statement: Should India go in for e-governance in all possible sectors?A. Yes, it will bring accuracy and efficiency in the work.B. No, e-governance requires a lot of money. We should not waste money on it.C. Yes, when developing countries are introducing computers in every field, how can India afford to lag behind.D. No, it will be an injustice to the monumental human resources which are at present utilized.Choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.AOnly
  • B.A and B Only
  • C.A and C Only
  • D.D Only
Correct Answer: AOnly

Argument A is strong because it directly highlights the main benefit of e-governance — better accuracy and efficiency. This is logical, relevant, and supports the purpose of the statement.

 

Argument B is weak because saying “we should not waste money” is vague and does not consider long-term benefits.

 

Argument C is weak because it relies on comparative pressure (“other countries are doing it”), which is not a strong, logical reason by itself.

 

Argument D is weak because calling e-governance “injustice to human resources” is emotional and not logically valid.

Question 30
Match List–I with List–IIList–I(Reasoning Type)A. Reasoning based upon resemblance to what has been observed in the pastB. Reasoning by the method of eliminationC. Reasoning with the support of what is found in the sphere of sensuous objectsD. Reasoning by keeping discussion within limits and by drawing attention to the point under discussionList–II(Sanskrit Term)I.SesavatII.PuravatIII. PratijnaIV.SamanayatrodstaChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A–I, B–IV, C–II, D–III
  • B.A–II, B–III, C–IV, D–I
  • C.A–II, B–I, C–IV, D–III
  • D.A–III, B–IV, C–II, D–I
Correct Answer: A–II, B–I, C–IV, D–III

A. Reasoning based upon resemblance to what has been observed in the past → Puravat (II)

Puravat means drawing inference from past events or previous observations.

 

B. Reasoning by the method of elimination → Sesavat (I)

Sesavat refers to inference based on remaining evidence after eliminating other possibilities.

 

C. Reasoning with support of sensuous objects (perception-based) → Samanayatrodsta (IV)

This means inference based on commonly observed characteristics in the physical/sensory world.

 

D. Reasoning by keeping discussion within limits / pointing to the topic → Pratijna (III)

Pratijna refers to a proposition or statement that sets the point of discussion.

 

Hence the final matching is:

A–II, B–I, C–IV, D–III.

Question 31
The teaching which involves the teacher posing questions to students as they attempt a task, is known as:
  • A.Co-operative Teaching
  • B.Peer Tutoring
  • C.Scaffolding
  • D.Directed Teaching
Correct Answer: Scaffolding

Scaffolding is a teaching approach where the teacher supports students by asking guiding questions while they work on a task. The teacher gradually reduces the support as students gain confidence and understanding. This method helps learners think, explore and solve problems independently.

Question 32
_______ is the ‘RIGHT’ instructional technology for the understanding level of teaching.
  • A.Branching
  • B.Linear
  • C.Programmed Instruction
  • D.Self Instruction
Correct Answer: Branching

At the understanding level of teaching, the goal is to help students clarify concepts, remove misconceptions, and understand why something is correct or incorrect.

 

Branching programming supports this because:

  • It provides different paths based on the learner’s response.
  • If a student makes a mistake, it gives remedial frames to correct misunderstanding.
  • If the student answers correctly, it moves ahead.
  • This helps in building conceptual clarity, which is the core of the understanding level.

 

So, branching is well suited for the understanding level, while linear programming fits better with the memory level.

Question 33
Arrange the components of Teaching process in order of occurrence, from initial to final.A. Performance AssessmentB. Instructional GoalC. Entering BehaviourD. Instructional ProcedureChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, C, D, B
  • B.C, A, D, B
  • C.B, C, D, A
  • D.B, C, A, D
Correct Answer: B, C, D, A

The teaching process follows a logical sequence:

 

Instructional Goal (B)

First, the teacher decides what is to be achieved — the learning objectives.

 

Entering Behaviour (C)

Next, the teacher checks the students’ prior knowledge, readiness, and background.

 

Instructional Procedure (D)

Then the actual teaching–learning process takes place (methods, strategies, activities).

 

Performance Assessment (A)

Finally, the teacher evaluates whether learning objectives have been achieved.

 

So, the correct order is:

B → C → D → A.

Question 34
Select the ‘RIGHT’ combination of statements.A. Role of Teacher’s personality is very important – IdealismB. Role of Teacher’s personality is of limited importance – PragmatismC. Role of Teacher’s personality is very important – PragmatismD. Role of Teacher’s personality is not of limited importance – NaturalismChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A and B Only
  • B.B and C Only
  • C.C and D Only
  • D.A and C Only
Correct Answer: A and B Only

A. Role of Teacher’s personality is very important – Idealism

This is correct because Idealism considers the teacher as a role model. The teacher’s character, values, and personality greatly influence students.

 

B. Role of Teacher’s personality is of limited importance – Pragmatism

This is also correct. Pragmatism focuses on learning by doing, experiences, and activities. Therefore, teacher’s personality is not central and has limited importance.

 

C. Role of Teacher’s personality is very important – Pragmatism

This is incorrect because Pragmatism does not give major importance to the teacher’s personality.

 

D. Role of Teacher’s personality is not of limited importance – Naturalism

This is also incorrect. Naturalism believes in free development of the child with minimum teacher interference, so the teacher’s personality is not important.

 

Therefore, the right combination is: A and B Only.

Question 35
Match List–I with List–IIList–I(Concept)A. An example of multisensory approach of learningB. Four quadrants of learningC. Academic Bank of CreditD. An example of software package on statistical analysisList–II(Association)I. MOOCII. PSPPIII. YouTubeIV. NEP–2020Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A–III, B–IV, C–II, D–I
  • B.A–II, B–I, C–IV, D–III
  • C.A–III, B–I, C–IV, D–II
  • D.A–IV, B–I, C–II, D–III
Correct Answer: A–III, B–I, C–IV, D–II

A. An example of multisensory approach of learning → YouTube (III)

YouTube uses audio + video together. This means learning through multiple senses, so it is a multisensory learning tool.

 

B. Four quadrants of learning → MOOC (I)

The Four-Quadrant approach (video, e-content, self-assessment, discussion) is used in MOOC platforms under SWAYAM.

 

C. Academic Bank of Credit → NEP–2020 (IV)

The Academic Bank of Credit (ABC) system was introduced in NEP 2020 to store and transfer students’ credits.

 

D. An example of software package on statistical analysis → PSPP (II)

PSPP is a free statistical software similar to SPSS.

Question 36
A standard address format that constitutes a reference to an internet resource is:
  • A.HTTP
  • B.ISP
  • C.FTP
  • D.URL
Correct Answer: URL

A URL (Uniform Resource Locator) is the standard address format used to identify and access a resource on the internet — such as a webpage, image, or file.

Question 37
VPN stands for:
  • A.Vast Public Networks
  • B.Virtual Public Networks
  • C.Vast Private Networks
  • D.Virtual Private Networks
Correct Answer: Virtual Private Networks

The correct answer is Option D.

Question 38
Choose the ‘WRONG’ statement.A. ‘JPEG’ stands for Joint Photographic Exchange GeneralB. ‘FTP’ stands for File Transfer ProtocolC. ‘GUI’ stands for General User InterfaceD. ‘FAT’ stands for File Allocation TableChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A and B Only
  • B.A and C Only
  • C.B and C Only
  • D.C and D Only
Correct Answer: A and C Only

A VPN (Virtual Private Network) creates a secure and private connection over a public network (like the internet). It protects your data and hides your IP address.

Question 39
Choose the ‘WRONG’ statement.A. ‘Bit’ is a unit of storageB. ‘Micron’ is a unit of weightC. ‘F1–3’ is a functional key on computer keyboardD. Pixel is related to resolution of cameraChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A and B Only
  • B.B and C Only
  • C.C and D Only
  • D.B and D Only
Correct Answer: B and C Only

A. ‘Bit’ is a unit of storage — WRONG

Bit is not a storage unit; it is a unit of information (binary digit). Storage units are byte, KB, MB, GB, etc.

 

B. ‘Micron’ is a unit of weight — WRONG

Micron (µm) is a unit of length, not weight.

 

C. ‘F1–3’ is a functional key on computer keyboard — CORRECT

Function keys run from F1 to F12.

 

D. Pixel is related to resolution of camera — CORRECT

Pixel measures image resolution.

Question 40
Match List–I with List–IIList–I(Item)A. YahooB. FirefoxC. SolitaireD.QuillbotList–II(Category)I. Web BrowserII. AI-Based Paraphrasing ToolIII. Search EngineIV. GameChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A–II, B–III, C–IV, D–I
  • B.A–III, B–I, C–IV, D–II
  • C.A–III, B–IV, C–I, D–II
  • D.A–IV, B–III, C–II, D–I
Correct Answer: A–III, B–I, C–IV, D–II

Yahoo → Search Engine (III)

Firefox → Web Browser (I)

Solitaire → Game (IV)

Quillbot → AI-Based Paraphrasing Tool (II)

Question 41
What is Eutrophication?
  • A.Low pH of water due to toxic material
  • B.Enhanced plant growth and subsequent oxygen depletion of water
  • C.Temperature above the normal range due to organic matter pollution
  • D.Increase in toxicity of water due to chemicals
Correct Answer: Enhanced plant growth and subsequent oxygen depletion of water

Eutrophication occurs when excess nutrients (mainly nitrates and phosphates from fertilizers, sewage, etc.) enter water bodies.

 

This causes overgrowth of algae and aquatic plants, and when these plants die and decompose, oxygen in the water gets depleted, harming aquatic life.

Question 42
Among these, which is the outermost layer of atmosphere?
  • A.Stratosphere
  • B.Mesosphere
  • C.Troposphere
  • D.Thermosphere
Correct Answer: Thermosphere

The layers of the atmosphere from lowest to highest are:

 

Troposphere

Stratosphere

Mesosphere

Thermosphere → outermost layer before space begins

 

Hence, Thermosphere is the outermost layer among the given options.

Question 43
Arrange Millennium Development Goals in increasing order according to their goal number.A. Reduce child mortalityB. Ensure environmental sustainabilityC. Promote gender equality and empower womenD. Improve maternal healthE. Achieve universal primary educationChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.E, B, D, A, C
  • B.E, C, A, D, B
  • C.A, B, C, D, E
  • D.B, C, D, E, A
Correct Answer: E, C, A, D, B

The Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) were numbered as follows:

 

  • Eradicate extreme poverty and hunger
  • Achieve universal primary education → E
  • Promote gender equality and empower women → C
  • Reduce child mortality → A
  • Improve maternal health → D
  • Combat HIV/AIDS, malaria and other diseases
  • Ensure environmental sustainability → B
  • Global partnership for development

 

So, arranging the given goals in increasing order of goal numbers:

E, C, A, D, B.

Question 44
Major philosophical approaches to environmental ethics are:A. AnthropocentrismB. EgocentrismC. BiocentrismD. EcocentrismChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B and D Only
  • B.A, B, C and D
  • C.A, C and D Only
  • D.A, B and C Only
Correct Answer: A, C and D Only

The major philosophical approaches in environmental ethics are:

  • Anthropocentrism – human-centred view
  • Biocentrism – all living beings have value
  • Ecocentrism – whole ecosystem has intrinsic value

 

Egocentrism is not an environmental ethics approach. It means being self-centred.

Question 45
Match List–I with List–IIList–I(Person)A. Salim AliB. Charles DarwinC. M.S. SwaminathanD.SunderlalBahugunaList–II(Field/Contribution)I. Agriculture ScientistII. OrnithologyIII. Chipko MovementIV. Origin of SpeciesChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A–II, B–IV, C–I, D–III
  • B.A–II, B–I, C–III, D–IV
  • C.A–II, B–III, C–IV, D–I
  • D.A–IV, B–II, C–I, D–III
Correct Answer: A–II, B–IV, C–I, D–III

Salim Ali → Ornithology (II)

He is known as the Birdman of India.

 

Charles Darwin → Origin of Species (IV)

He wrote “On the Origin of Species” and proposed the theory of evolution.

 

M.S. Swaminathan → Agriculture Scientist (I)

Known as the Father of the Green Revolution in India.

 

Sunderlal Bahuguna → Chipko Movement (III)

Environmentalist who led the movement to protect forests.

Question 46
Read the passage below and answer the questions:Every now and then some retired civil servants come out with their memoirs, painting a glorious picture of the heights of administrative efficiency reached during their reign. There is often the suggestion that had there not been so much political interference, things would have been even more fantastic. It is not unusual for the self-styled hero to blame not only interfering politicians but also fellow servants who were idiots or crooks for his failures. This attitude of smug satisfaction is unfortunately developed during the years of service. Self-preservation rather than service is encouraged by our whole system of rules and procedures.The remedy has to be drastic and quickly effective. The over-protection now granted to civil servants must end. Today to remove an erring civil servant is just not possible. And the only thing that has political authority in the Government, both in the state and at the centre, can do is to transfer the official from one job to another.The rules for taking disciplinary action are so complicated that, in the end, the defaulting civil servant gets away and gets his full emoluments even for the period of the disciplinary proceedings, thus making it a paid holiday for him.The result is that the administration has become rule-oriented and not result-oriented. Action is possible against the official who takes some interest in his work, but no action is ever taken against a person who does not deliver the goods. If the country is to adopt a result-oriented approach, it is necessary to link job performance with job retention.The existing system of administration seems to encourage civil servants:
  • A.To become self-styled heroes and dictate others
  • B.To project their performance which is actually superficial
  • C.To becomeself-centeredand remain concerned about their personal gains
  • D.To fight back the corrupt politicians
Correct Answer: To becomeself-centeredand remain concerned about their personal gains

The passage explains that civil servants often develop smug satisfaction, blame others for failures, and focus on self-preservation rather than service. The system encourages them to protect themselves because rules make it difficult to take action against them.

 

This shows that the system makes them self-centered and concerned about their own benefits, not public service.

Question 47
Read the passage below and answer the questions:Every now and then some retired civil servants come out with their memoirs, painting a glorious picture of the heights of administrative efficiency reached during their reign. There is often the suggestion that had there not been so much political interference, things would have been even more fantastic. It is not unusual for the self-styled hero to blame not only interfering politicians but also fellow servants who were idiots or crooks for his failures. This attitude of smug satisfaction is unfortunately developed during the years of service. Self-preservation rather than service is encouraged by our whole system of rules and procedures.The remedy has to be drastic and quickly effective. The over-protection now granted to civil servants must end. Today to remove an erring civil servant is just not possible. And the only thing that has political authority in the Government, both in the state and at the centre, can do is to transfer the official from one job to another.The rules for taking disciplinary action are so complicated that, in the end, the defaulting civil servant gets away and gets his full emoluments even for the period of the disciplinary proceedings, thus making it a paid holiday for him.The result is that the administration has become rule-oriented and not result-oriented. Action is possible against the official who takes some interest in his work, but no action is ever taken against a person who does not deliver the goods. If the country is to adopt a result-oriented approach, it is necessary to link job performance with job retention.What needs to be stopped by the government to correct the attitude of the civil servants?
  • A.Over-protection
  • B.Use of public transport for personal use
  • C.Grant of different types of additional leaves
  • D.Medical facilities
Correct Answer: Over-protection

The passage clearly states that “The over-protection now granted to civil servants must end.”

This over-protection prevents action against erring officials and encourages irresponsible behaviour.

 

Hence, the government needs to stop over-protection in order to correct the attitude of civil servants.

Question 48
Read the passage below and answer the questions:Every now and then some retired civil servants come out with their memoirs, painting a glorious picture of the heights of administrative efficiency reached during their reign. There is often the suggestion that had there not been so much political interference, things would have been even more fantastic. It is not unusual for the self-styled hero to blame not only interfering politicians but also fellow servants who were idiots or crooks for his failures. This attitude of smug satisfaction is unfortunately developed during the years of service. Self-preservation rather than service is encouraged by our whole system of rules and procedures.The remedy has to be drastic and quickly effective. The over-protection now granted to civil servants must end. Today to remove an erring civil servant is just not possible. And the only thing that has political authority in the Government, both in the state and at the centre, can do is to transfer the official from one job to another.The rules for taking disciplinary action are so complicated that, in the end, the defaulting civil servant gets away and gets his full emoluments even for the period of the disciplinary proceedings, thus making it a paid holiday for him.The result is that the administration has become rule-oriented and not result-oriented. Action is possible against the official who takes some interest in his work, but no action is ever taken against a person who does not deliver the goods. If the country is to adopt a result-oriented approach, it is necessary to link job performance with job retention.To adopt a result-oriented approach, Government must link:
  • A.Job performance with job satisfaction
  • B.Job performance with out of the way promotion
  • C.Job performance with job retention
  • D.Job performance with job appraisal
Correct Answer: Job performance with job retention

. “If the country is to adopt a result-oriented approach, it is necessary to link job performance with job retention.”

 

This means only those who perform well should continue in their jobs; poor performers should not be retained.

Question 49
Read the passage below and answer the questions:Every now and then some retired civil servants come out with their memoirs, painting a glorious picture of the heights of administrative efficiency reached during their reign. There is often the suggestion that had there not been so much political interference, things would have been even more fantastic. It is not unusual for the self-styled hero to blame not only interfering politicians but also fellow servants who were idiots or crooks for his failures. This attitude of smug satisfaction is unfortunately developed during the years of service. Self-preservation rather than service is encouraged by our whole system of rules and procedures.The remedy has to be drastic and quickly effective. The over-protection now granted to civil servants must end. Today to remove an erring civil servant is just not possible. And the only thing that has political authority in the Government, both in the state and at the centre, can do is to transfer the official from one job to another.The rules for taking disciplinary action are so complicated that, in the end, the defaulting civil servant gets away and gets his full emoluments even for the period of the disciplinary proceedings, thus making it a paid holiday for him.The result is that the administration has become rule-oriented and not result-oriented. Action is possible against the official who takes some interest in his work, but no action is ever taken against a person who does not deliver the goods. If the country is to adopt a result-oriented approach, it is necessary to link job performance with job retention.The expression ‘deliver the goods’ stands for:
  • A.Show good performance
  • B.Accept illegalfavors
  • C.To facilitate the concerned to drop the article(s) at the right place
  • D.To please one’s superiors
Correct Answer: Show good performance

In the passage, “deliver the goods” is used to criticize civil servants who do not deliver the goods. Here, the phrase means to perform well or produce the expected results.

Question 50
Read the passage below and answer the questions:Every now and then some retired civil servants come out with their memoirs, painting a glorious picture of the heights of administrative efficiency reached during their reign. There is often the suggestion that had there not been so much political interference, things would have been even more fantastic. It is not unusual for the self-styled hero to blame not only interfering politicians but also fellow servants who were idiots or crooks for his failures. This attitude of smug satisfaction is unfortunately developed during the years of service. Self-preservation rather than service is encouraged by our whole system of rules and procedures.The remedy has to be drastic and quickly effective. The over-protection now granted to civil servants must end. Today to remove an erring civil servant is just not possible. And the only thing that has political authority in the Government, both in the state and at the centre, can do is to transfer the official from one job to another.The rules for taking disciplinary action are so complicated that, in the end, the defaulting civil servant gets away and gets his full emoluments even for the period of the disciplinary proceedings, thus making it a paid holiday for him.The result is that the administration has become rule-oriented and not result-oriented. Action is possible against the official who takes some interest in his work, but no action is ever taken against a person who does not deliver the goods. If the country is to adopt a result-oriented approach, it is necessary to link job performance with job retention.‘A paid holiday’ as referred to by the author supports his argument that:
  • A.Despite disciplinary proceedings against him, the erring officer gets full emoluments
  • B.Tohonorthe effective officer, additional emoluments are given to the officer
  • C.Money given to the officers for celebrating their vacations
  • D.Money given in advance
Correct Answer: Despite disciplinary proceedings against him, the erring officer gets full emoluments

The author says that disciplinary proceedings take a long time and during this period, the erring officer still receives full salary, even though he is not doing any work.

 

So, it becomes like a paid holiday for him — he gets paid without performing duties.

Quiz Attempt #119703

Total Questions: 50
Question 1
Choose the ‘RIGHT’ statements:A. IoT term was first used by Ashton in context to supply chain management with RFID-tagsB. Bluetooth 4.0 is working on the frequency range of 2.4 MHzC. Gyroscope is normally related to the motion sensorsD. IPv6 is related to the coding of vaccines protocolE. GSM is global sequence of MechanicsChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A and B Only
  • B.D and E Only
  • C.A and C Only
  • D.B and D Only
Correct Answer: A and C Only

Statement A is correct because the term Internet of Things (IoT) was first introduced by Kevin Ashton in 1999 while discussing supply chain management using RFID tags. Statement C is also correct since a gyroscope is commonly used as a part of motion-sensing systems in devices like smartphones, drones and gaming controllers.

 

Statements B, D and E are incorrect. Bluetooth 4.0 does not operate at 2.4 MHz but at 2.4 GHz. IPv6 is not related to vaccine protocols; it is simply the newer version of the Internet Protocol. Similarly, GSM does not mean “global sequence of mechanics”; it stands for Global System for Mobile communication.

 

Therefore, the right combination is A and C.

Question 2
Study the table and answer the questions:DaysABCDEMonday139147211141184Tuesday141189164189151Wednesday115141159156136Thursday89223120147113Friday18793257160124What is the difference between total number of employees present in offices C and D together on Tuesday and total number of employees present in offices A and E together on Thursday?
  • A.147
  • B.271
  • C.151
  • D.171
Correct Answer: 151

Difference = 353 − 202 = 151.

Question 3
Study the table and answer the questions:DaysABCDEMonday139147211141184Tuesday141189164189151Wednesday115141159156136Thursday89223120147113Friday18793257160124What is the respective ratio between total number of employees present in office B on Wednesday and Thursday together and total number of employees present in office C on Monday and Friday together?
  • A.11 :13
  • B.9 :11
  • C.7 :9
  • D.7 :11
Correct Answer: 7 :9

Ratio = 364 : 468 = 7 : 9.

Question 4
Study the table and answer the questions:DaysABCDEMonday139147211141184Tuesday141189164189151Wednesday115141159156136Thursday89223120147113Friday18793257160124The number of employees present in office E on Monday is what percent more than the number of employees present in office C on Thursday?
  • A.34.78%
  • B.21.05%
  • C.55.25%
  • D.53.33%
Correct Answer: 53.33%

Required percentage = 184-120120×100 = 53.33%

Question 5
Study the table and answer the questions:DaysABCDEMonday139147211141184Tuesday141189164189151Wednesday115141159156136Thursday89223120147113Friday18793257160124What is the average number of employees present in office B on Monday, Tuesday and Friday?
  • A.143
  • B.159
  • C.153
  • D.173
Correct Answer: 143

Total = 147 + 189 + 93 = 429

Average = 429 ÷ 3 = 143.

Question 6
Study the table and answer the questions:DaysABCDEMonday139147211141184Tuesday141189164189151Wednesday115141159156136Thursday89223120147113Friday18793257160124The number of employees present in office A on Wednesday is what percent of the number of employees present in office D on Friday?
  • A.13978
  • B.7178
  • C.6323
  • D.6123
Correct Answer: 7178

Required percentage = 115160×100 = 71 78 %

Question 7
In the experiment of determining better ‘Yoga Exercise’ out of two that can reduce the fat of urban people of different age groups, which of the following is an intervening variable?
  • A.Area
  • B.Yoga Exercise
  • C.Food habit
  • D.Fat of the people
Correct Answer: Food habit

An intervening variable is something that affects the relationship between the independent and dependent variables.

 

Independent variable: Type of Yoga Exercise

Dependent variable: Fat reduction

Intervening variable: Something that influences fat reduction in between, such as lifestyle or food intake.

 

Among the given options, food habit directly affects fat level and interferes with the effect of yoga.

Question 8
Arrange the following from higher level to lower level of scales of measurement involved in them:A. Researcher divides the sample in two groups based on area of residence like ‘Urban’ and ‘Rural’ Area.B. A student has got 50 marks out of 60 marks in English language test.C. A cricketer is given tenth rank as an allrounder.D. The height of a particular building is double than all other buildings in a street.Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.D, C, B, A
  • B.A, B, D, C
  • C.C, B, A, D
  • D.D, B, C, A
Correct Answer: D, B, C, A

The highest level of measurement is the ratio scale, where true zero exists and numerical comparisons like “double” are meaningful.

Statement D talks about the height of a building being double, so it is ratio scale.

Statement B also has ratio scale because marks out of 60 have a true zero.

 

The next lower scale is the ordinal scale, where items are ranked.

Statement C gives the cricketer’s rank, so it is ordinal.

 

The lowest scale is the nominal scale, used for naming or categorizing.

Statement A divides people into Urban and Rural, so it is nominal.

 

So, the correct order from higher to lower is:

D → B → C → A.

Question 9
Which of the following factors affect the internal validity ofan experimental research?A. Placebo effectB. Instrument DecayC. Contemporary eventsD. Hawthorne effectE. Bias in selecting subjects in sampleChoose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.B, C and E Only
  • B.B, C and D Only
  • C.A, C and D Only
  • D.C, D and E Only
Correct Answer: B, C and E Only

Internal validity is reduced by factors that interfere with the true cause-effect link. Here, instrument decay (B), contemporary events (C), and selection bias (E) affect it.

Question 10
Which of the following programmes/software can be used for quantitative data analysis?A. MS WORDB. MS POWER POINTC. MS EXCELD. MS ACCESSE. SPSSChoose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, C, D and B Only
  • B.A, D and E Only
  • C.C, D and E Only
  • D.B, D and E Only
Correct Answer: C, D and E Only

For quantitative data analysis, the tools must be able to handle numbers, perform calculations, generate tables, or run statistical tests.

 

A. MS Word – Not used for quantitative analysis

B. MS PowerPoint – Not for analysis (only presentation)

C. MS Excel – Yes, widely used for quantitative analysis

D. MS Access – Yes, used for numerical data storage and queries

E. SPSS – Yes, a statistical software for quantitative analysis

 

So, correct tools are: C, D, E.

Question 11
Match List–I with List–IIList–I(Test Name)A. Mann WhitneyB. KendallC. BartlettD. Karl PearsonList–II(Associated with)I. Product Moment method of correlationII. Test of homogeneity of variancesIII. U TestIV. Tau TestChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A–III, B–II, C–IV, D–I
  • B.A–IV, B–III, C–II, D–I
  • C.A–III, B–IV, C–II, D–I
  • D.A–IV, B–I, C–III, D–II
Correct Answer: A–III, B–IV, C–II, D–I

A. Mann–Whitney → U Test

B. Kendall → Tau Test

C. Bartlett → Test of homogeneity of variances

D. Karl Pearson → Product Moment Correlation

Question 12
Which of the following programmes of UGC is not related to promotion of value and ethical practices?
  • A.Jeevan Kaushal
  • B.CARE
  • C.Mulya Pravah
  • D.National Resource Centre for Value Education (NRCVE)
Correct Answer: National Resource Centre for Value Education (NRCVE)

CARE (Consortium for Academic and Research Ethics) is related to improving the quality of research journals and preventing unethical publication practices. It is not a programme for promoting value or ethical education among students.

 

The other programmes—Jeevan Kaushal, Mulya Pravah, and NRCVE—are all designed to promote value education, ethics, and life skills.

Question 13
For the purpose of systematically fostering the culture of innovation in all HEIs, when did Ministry of Education establish ‘Innovation Cell’?
  • A.2016
  • B.2018
  • C.2019
  • D.2020
Correct Answer: 2018

The Ministry of Education (formerly MHRD) established the Innovation Cell in 2018 to systematically promote innovation, start-ups, and entrepreneurship across higher education institutions in India.

Question 14
Arrange the following commissions/committees (in field of education) in chronological order:A. GNANAM CommitteeB. Kothari CommissionC. National Knowledge CommissionD. MUDALIAR CommissionE. Yashpal Committee (Advice on Renovation and Rejuvenation of Higher Education)Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.D, A, C, E, B
  • B.B, D, C, E, A
  • C.B, D, A, C, E
  • D.D, B, A, C, E
Correct Answer: D, B, A, C, E

MUDALIAR Commission – 1952–53

KOTHARI Commission – 1964–66

GNANAM Committee – 1990 (on autonomy of higher education)

National Knowledge Commission – 2005–2009

Yashpal Committee – 2009.

Question 15
Which of the following institutions are among Top Ten institutions in the category of research institutions in India Ranking: 2024 released by NIRF?A. Indian Institute of Technology, DelhiB. Tata Institute of Fundamental ResearchC. Indian Institute of Technology, KanpurD. Indian Institute of Technology, IndoreE. Indian Institute of Technology, MadrasChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, C and D Only
  • B.B, D and E Only
  • C.B, C and D Only
  • D.A, C and E Only
Correct Answer: A, C and E Only

From the National Institutional Ranking Framework (NIRF) 2024 list for Research Institutions, the Top 10 include the following among your options:

  • Indian Institute of Technology, Delhi – ranked (Yes, in Top 10).
  • Tata Institute of Fundamental Research – ranked (Yes, in Top 10).
  • Indian Institute of Technology, Indore – ranked 26th, not in Top 10.
  • Indian Institute of Technology, Kanpur – ranked 7th (Yes, Top 10).
  • Indian Institute of Technology, Madras – Not listed within Top 10 of Research Institutions in that list.
Question 16
Match List–I with List–IIList–I(Four Independent Verticals of HECI)A. HEGCB. GECC. NACD. NHERCList–II(Major Function)I. Frame graduate attributesII. Common Single Point RegulatorIII. Funding and Financing of Higher EducationIV. Accreditation of InstitutionsChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A–II, B–I, C–IV, D–III
  • B.A–III, B–II, C–IV, D–I
  • C.A–IV, B–III, C–II, D–I
  • D.A–III, B–I, C–IV, D–II
Correct Answer: A–III, B–I, C–IV, D–II

HEGC – Higher Education Grants Council → Responsible for funding and financing

GEC – General Education Council → Frames graduate attributes, learning outcomes

NAC – National Accreditation Council → Responsible for accreditation

NHERC – National Higher Education Regulatory Council → Acts as single-point regulator.

Question 17
Which Model depicts communication as a process by which communicators send messages/feedback simultaneously to one another?
  • A.Socio-cultural
  • B.Socio-psychological
  • C.Interactional
  • D.Transactional
Correct Answer: Transactional

The Transactional Model of Communication shows communication as a simultaneous process where both people send and receive messages and feedback at the same time.

Question 18
Which one is not a type of communication modality?
  • A.Proxemics
  • B.Heptics
  • C.Chronotoxics
  • D.Gestures
Correct Answer: Chronotoxics

Common communication modalities include:

  • Proxemics – use of space
  • Haptics (written here as Heptics) – use of touch
  • Gestures – body movements

 

But Chronotoxics is not a communication modality.

Question 19
Arrange the following chronologically on the basis of their launch year:A.SwayamprabhaB. Krishi DarshanC.GyandarshanD. PMeVidyaChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.C, A, B, D
  • B.A, C, D, B
  • C.B, C, A, D
  • D.A, B, D, C
Correct Answer: B, C, A, D

Krishi Darshan – 1967

Gyandarshan – 2000

Swayamprabha – 2017

PM eVidya – 2020

Question 20
Which of the following are required to become a good listener?A. Keep quiet while listeningB. Listen with negative attitude towards the speakerC. Show interest in the speakerD. Focus on the dress and appearance of the speakerE. Keep your mind open to every subject and speakerChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B and C Only
  • B.B, C and D Only
  • C.A, C and E Only
  • D.C, D and E Only
Correct Answer: A, C and E Only

To be a good listener, the required qualities are:

  • Keep quiet while listening – correct
  • Show interest in the speaker – correct
  • E. Keep your mind open to every subject and speaker – correct

 

B (negative attitude) and D (focusing on dress) are NOT characteristics of good listening.

Question 21
Match List–I with List–IIList–IA. Public CommunicationB. Group CommunicationC. Intrapersonal CommunicationD. Interpersonal CommunicationList–III. Communicating with oneselfII. Face-to-face communication with another personIII. When many people participate in communication with each otherIV. One person speaking to a large number of peopleChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A–III, B–II, C–IV, D–I
  • B.A–IV, B–III, C–I, D–II
  • C.A–I, B–II, C–III, D–IV
  • D.A–IV, B–I, C–II, D–III
Correct Answer: A–IV, B–III, C–I, D–II

A. Public Communication → One person speaking to a large number of people → IV

B. Group Communication → Many people participating and communicating with each other → III

C. Intrapersonal Communication → Communicating with oneself → I

D. Interpersonal Communication → Face-to-face communication with another person → II

 

So the correct match is:

A–IV, B–III, C–I, D–II.

Question 22
A boat takes an hour to cover a certain distance downstream in a river. It takes 1½ hour to cover the same distance upstream. Assuming that the speed of boat is same in both directions, what is the ratio of speed of boat to that of stream in the river?
  • A.2 :3
  • B.5 :1
  • C.3 :2
  • D.5 :2
Correct Answer: 5 :1

Boat speed = b

Stream speed = s

Downstream speed = b + s = d ---(i)

Upstream speed = b – s = 23 d -----(ii)

Adding

2b = 53d

or b = 56d

s = d – b = 16d

b : s = 56d : 16d

= 5 : 1

Question 23
Two persons A and B finish a work in 10 days. A is twice as efficient as B. How many days A will take to finish the work, if he has to do it alone?
  • A.8 days
  • B.12 days
  • C.15 days
  • D.18 days
Correct Answer: 15 days

Lets B’s 1 day work is x, then A’s work will be 2x.

Together A + B finish in 10 days, so:

A’s work + B’s work = 110

or 2x + x = 110

or x = 130

So, A alone will finish the work in 15 days.

Question 24
Arrange the following in increasing order of their values:A. (0.1)³B. (1100)¹ᐟ²C. (0.005)¹ᐟ²D. (0.04)¹ᐟ²Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, C, D, B
  • B.A, C, B, D
  • C.D, B, C, A
  • D.C, B, D, A
Correct Answer: A, C, B, D

A. (0.1)³ = 0.001

C. (0.005)¹ᐟ² = √0.005 ≈ 0.0707

B. (1/100)¹ᐟ² = √(1/100) = 1/10 = 0.1

D. (0.04)¹ᐟ² = √0.04 = 0.2

 

Increasing order:

0.001 < 0.0707 < 0.1 < 0.2

So, the order is:

A, C, B, D.

Question 25
Identify the correct statements:A. (216)¹ᐟ³ > (169)¹ᐟ²B. The next term in the series 2, 7, 28, 63, 126, … is 217C. The area of equilateral triangle of side 10 cm is 253D. The average of the following observations –2, –1, 0, +1,+2, +3 is12Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.C and D Only
  • B.B, C and D Only
  • C.A and D Only
  • D.A, C and D Only
Correct Answer: C and D Only

A. (216)¹ᐟ³ > (169)¹ᐟ²

Cube root of 216 is 6 and square root of 169 is 13, so 6 is not greater than 13. This is false.

 

B. Next term in 2, 7, 28, 63, 126 is 217

Pattern is n³ ± 1:

1³+1=2, 2³−1=7, 3³+1=28, 4³−1=63, 5³+1=126, so next is 6³−1=215, not 217. This is false.

 

C. Area of equilateral triangle of side 10 cm is 25√3

Formula is (√3/4) × side² = (√3/4) × 100 = 25√3. This is true.

 

D. Average of –2, –1, 0, +1, +2, +3 is 1/2

Sum = 3, number of terms = 6, so average = 3/6 = 1/2. This is true.

 

Correct statements are C and D only.

Question 26
Match List–I with List–IIList–IA. (343)¹ᐟ³ – (81)¹ᐟ⁴ is equal to ____B. If 2⁸ × 4³ × 8³ = 2ˣ, thenx is equal to ____C.(101)2-(1)21.01+1is equal to ____D. A train moving with speed of 90 km/hour crosses a platform of length 100 m in 12 seconds. The length (m) of the train is ____List–III.1100II. 200III. 4IV. 23Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A–III, B–IV, C–I, D–II
  • B.A–II, B–IV, C–III, D–I
  • C.A–I, B–III, C–IV, D–II
  • D.A–III, B–IV, C–II, D–I
Correct Answer: A–III, B–IV, C–I, D–II

A. (343)¹ᐟ³ – (81)¹ᐟ⁴ = 7 – 3 = 4

 

B. 2⁸ × 4³ × 8³ = 2ˣ

or x = 8 + 6 + 9 = 23

 

C. 1.012-121.01+1 = 1.01-11 = 1100

 

D. 90 km/h = 25 m/s

Distance covered in 12 s = 25 × 12 = 300 m

Platform = 100 m

Train length = 300 – 100 = 200.

Question 27
In a group of 40 people, 25 people speak Hindi and 20 people speak both Hindi and Urdu. All the people speak at least one of the two languages. How many people speak Urdu?
